name: Volando Flying Roulette
description: This is an odd version of roulette. A British plane which is on a counter-weighted arm is "flown" in a circle over the playing surface. Players wager on where the plane will land. Payoffs are made based on the size of the area.

name: Im Fluge durch Grossdeutschland
description:
A reworking of classic games of flying around the world, but instead players just move around Germany. It came out at a time when German planes really couldn't go anywhere with a peaceful landing in mind.

Pictured in the book Games We Play.

name: Roly Poly
description:
From the publisher:
A novel game with Goblins. The figures are made to jump into the perforated board with a 5x5 grid.

Pictured in the book Games We Play, from the illustration, one can't figure out if the point is to get the correct hole in the board or avoid the holes in the board.

name: Nansen's Nordpolfahrt
description:
One of several roll-and-move games that came out between 1890 and 1910 as the public was enthralled with expeditions to the arctic.

The board features illustrations of the trip north, by ship, kayak, dogsled, and skis. The dice rolling journey covers the journey north and the return home.

The board is pictured in the book Games We Play.

name: Star Hopping
description: Pictured in the book Games We Play, this is a roll and move game played on two stars, one on the inside of each half of a box. It appears that players collect the tokens put out on each point of the star at the start of the game.

name: Game of Nuns
description: Featured in the book Games We Play as an example of an early game from Nuremberg. The game appears to be a four person game of checkers played on cross with 33 holes, and the playing pieces are pins about the size of golf tees. The board is actually the lid of a wooden box that holds the pieces. Unlike other games from this early 1800's Nuremberg period, there is a chance copies of this game exist, even in mint condition, because it looks to be all wood.

name: Flora, the Flower Game
description: Featured in the book Games We Play as an example of an early lithograph game published in Nuremberg, from the illustration it appears to be an early version of Tangoes, with red and blue geometric shapes that can be arranged to create "flowers."

name: New Question and Answer Game
description: Featured in the book Games We Play, one wonders if this was the first trivia game...but with the word New in the title perhaps it was the second. From the illustration, it appears that each lithographed card consists of one full-color humorous illustration and one question.

name: Battle of Talana Hill
description:
A wargame depicting the Battle of Talana Hill -- October 20, 1899.

A deck of playing cards determines who does what and when (if a red card is drawn, the British player activates one counter. If it is a black card, the Boer player activates one counter.)

Players win by obtaining more victory points than their opponent. Victory points are obtained for inflicting casualties.

name: Miltry
description: Very little is known about the game. The box describes it as "A Game of Warring Nations". The pieces are colored wooden pieces with flags of five countries attached (England, France, Germany, Austria Hungary, Russia). The game play is point to point with captures happening when there is no place to retreat to and controlled capitals are used to determine winners at the end of the game.

name: Champion European War Game
description:
The goal is to see which side can capture the other. Germany faces England, Belgium, France and Russia in four wars, the side that wins three battles wins the war and is the "Champion".

Each war is fought one at a time. The opponents each place a unit in the appropriate capital and play is determined by spinning the spinner. If there is a gap between units then the inner circle (movement) is used, otherwise a battle is fought and the outer ring is used.

The player that pushes the enemy army back and captures the enemy fort wins the war.

name: Dragon Racing
description:
Players roll dice and assign rolls to Speed, Dexterity (cornering), Fire Breath and Agility (dodging). They then race through a maze with fire breathing combat possibly occurring when two dragons meet.

The Print and Play version of the game can be downloaded from http://www.mmiparchive.papermakeit.com/28%20-%20Boardgames.h...

name: Panko or Votes for Women
description:
This card game from 1910 shows pictures of events happening in the suffrage "Votes for Woman" era. I don't know much more about the game except that a copy of it is in The Jon A. Lindseth Suffrage Collection.

The card game had set of 52 cards and features Emmeline Pankhurst and Winston Churchill. The cards are purple, green, and white. The game instructions were included in the box.

name: Race to the Fairy Castle
description: Race to the Fairy Castle is a simple roll and move game from Chad Valley. The object of the game is to reach the Fairy Castle, the ultimate destination for each player, by getting past dragons, goblins, fiery serpents, wolves and The Black Knight!!

name: The Cleveland Second Term Puzzle Game
description: The object of the Cleveland Second Term Puzzle is to navigate wooden balls through a wood and metal maze into the “President’s room.” This game was issued during Grover Cleveland’s 1892 re-election campaign. A copy of this game is in the Susan H. Douglas Political Americana Collection.

name: Pinocchio Race Game
description: This simple roll and move game is probably from the early to the mid 1950's. Game comes with a die, playing pieces and a board with spaces numbered 1 to 120. The board has a couple of detours that might have to be taken on the way to the finish line.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based, Racing

name: Days of Empire: Rules for Wargaming the Crimean War, 1854-1856
description:
These miniatures rules were designed specifically for the Crimean War period.

Days of Empire is a set of rules for 18mm wargaming. Cavalry and Infantry are represented by stands 50 of men. Artillery, Engineers and Staff are represented by stands of 10 men. An artillery gun model represents two actual guns.

name: Traka
description: An electronic number generator that comes packaged with sixteen games designed for it. The device has eight light-emitting diodes, numbered one through eight, which flash one at a time. The operator of the device presses a button to freeze the flashing to generate a number. A switch can alter the speed of the flashing to either fast or slow.

name: Pro Patria! Rules for Wargaming in the Age of Napoleon
description:
These miniatures rules were designed to be both simple and realistic.

Pro Patrica! is a set of rules for 15mm and 25/28mm wargaming. Cavalry and Infantry are represented by stands 50 of men. Artillery, Engineers and Staff are represented by stands of 10 men. An artillery gun model represents two actual guns.

name: Days of Glory: Rules for Wargaming the American Civil War
description:
These miniatures rules were designed specifically for the American Civil War period.

Days of Glory is a set of rules for 15mm wargaming at the regimental scale. Cavalry and Infantry stands represent 50 men each. Artillery, Engineers and Staff stand represent 10 men each. An artillery gun represents two actual guns.

name: Days of Iron: Rules for Wargaming the Franco-Prussian War
description:
These miniatures rules were designed specifically for the Franco Prussian War period.

Days of Iron is a set of rules for 15mm wargaming at the regimental scale. Cavalry and Infantry stands represent 50 men each. Artillery, Engineers, and Staff stands represent 10 men each. An artillery gun model represents three actual guns.

name: Cannonball Charlie
description:
Players spin to see what type of plastic brick to add to the wall being built in front of Charlie, who patiently bides his time in the shaft of an elastic-band loaded cannon. When a certain weight threshold is exceeded, the elastic band trigger is released, propelling Charlie into the wall and eliminating the player who caused this to occur from the game.

The remaining players reset the cannon, replace Charlie & rebuild the wall from scratch, again trying to prevent Charlie from crashing into and collapsing the wall.

The last player remaining is the winner.

name: Subdoku
description:
Subdoku takes the battleship game into a new dimension!
Nine pawns in three different colors. You can't place pawns of the same color in the same square, row or column.
With those Sudoku rules the battle become smarter and much more strategic then ever before. The battle of mind starts here…

name: Star Sight
description:
Star Sight is a space exploration and conquest game played on an enormous hexagonal array of triangles. Players gain points for building ships, creating space colonies, destroying opponents' units, and delivering cargo. The player with the most points after a predetermined number of turns is the winner.

Players command their fleet by simultaneously entering commands for their ships into logbooks, which are then revealed and adjudicated.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Secret Unit Deployment, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Dick Tracy: A "Sunday Funnies" Game
description:
From the box lid:

Track down arch criminals with America's #1 detective.

Meet up with some of the most famous villains in comic strip history. FLATTOP... MOLE... MUMBLES... PRUNEFACE... VITAMIN FLINTHEART... THE BROW... SHAKEY... LITTLEFACE. Go after them all.

Start from HQ and track 'em down one by one...go in and out of hiding places...pick up cards trying to get 4 that match. There may be some dangers along the way, so watch out. The first player to get 4 matching Criminal Cards and enter that criminal's hideout with those cards wins the game.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Holy Hack: Biblical Warfare 3000 B.C. to 600 B.C. -Hacking by the Book (Second Edition)
description:
From the rulebook: "Revised and expanded to include warfare in The Near East, Egypt and Africa in Old Testament Times. Includes general orders of battle, tactics, formations, revised casualty calculation method, diagrams, naval & siege rules, Divine Intervention, heroic challenges & Q.R.S.

"Originally published as `Holy Hack: Hacking By the Book Biblical Warfare.'"

This rulebook also features enhanced graphics throughout including color illustrations of examples using photographs of miniatures in play.

For support online, see http://www.classicalhack.com

name: Boy Scout Game
description:
This roll-and-move game is set in a Boy Scout camp and the surrounding farmground. One imagines it was either published in the first half of 1914, before WWI broke out, or had very limited sales.
Each player starts on his/her own (coloured)route; ending on a marked space follow instructions; first player entering the centre (camp of tents) is the winner.

name: With Rucksack and Guitar
description:
This roll-and-move game features hikers, who carry their guitar, flute, and rucksack, walking past the lakes, through the fields, and over the hills of Germany. The pawns match the art on the box, complete with lederhosen.

The date of publication is pinned at "around 1925" in the Spears history, Games We Play.

name: Ab auf die Insel
description:
Get onto the island:

Finally, the sun is shining nice and brightly and the swimming pool in the garden is inviting you to enjoy some splashing around. As today was really strenuous, you'd prefer to lie down on your inflatable super cool palm island in the swimming pool, together with your two friends, and just float around. Unfortunately, your other family members have the same idea. But since there's only one air mattress, the turmoil starts right at the edge of the pool. Everyone wants to get to the air mattress first, since he who comes last goes empty handed.

Contents:

1 Game board

1 Die

12 game pieces
mechanics: Area Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Lost in Space
description:
Creatures from another planet are lost in space. We have to take them home, using observation and grid references. An excellent introduction to using maps.

(From inside the box)

Lost in Space: A map reference game for any number of players

The six collecting boards form the plan of Fantasia. Each board is divided into nine grid squares, so that there are 54 grid squares in all. Each of the 54 picture cards shows, larger and more clearly, a creature from one of the grid squares, and on the back of the card the appropriate grid reference is shown.
The aim of the game is to match the creatures to the grid squares, either through observation or by using the grid references.

The attractive design of this game belies the degree of observational skill required. It reflects the difficulty of reading real maps and quickly teaches the value and simplicity of grid references.
mechanics: Pattern Building, Pattern Recognition, Set Collection, Tile Placement

name: The Animal Kingdom
description:
Similar to Jungle, the forerunner of Stratego.

Each player has 13 animals, with strengths ranging from 1 to 13. The players move their animals orthogonally one space per turn and compare strengths between animals when one moves into an occupied space. The higher strength wins and captures the other animal, except in the case of the mouse (strength 1) which can capture an elephant (strength 13).

There is a set of variant cards with the game which will offer some variety to the game by granting powers.

name: Krux
description:
The goal of the game is to push or pull an opponent's piece so that it lands in the central hole.

Players do not choose which pieces to move, they play in a fixed order. However, rings can be placed on the pieces to give them special move alternatives like jumping and picking up other pieces.

name: Tricky Topple
description: It appears to be a roll and move game with other features.

name: Grab-A-Tiger
description: This is a game where you have a spinner that tells you the color of the tiger's tail you have to grab. You grab it with something almost identical to a plastic clothes pin. The game is played in 3 rounds with the person catching the most tigers winning each round and 2 out of 3 rounds being the win.

name: SQR
description:
SQR Base is a turn-based strategy game for one or two players.

The game is played on a board made of square cells (though the board itself needn't be square). Each player will make a team of characters, the SQRs, to face an opponent. The object of the game can be either moving one or several neutral characters to a special cell, the Base (different for each player), defeating all the opponent's SQRs or conquering the opponent's Base.

name: Mickey Mouse Don't Wake the Dragon Game
description:
Each player takes turns to win charm cards & the player with the strongest charm wins the challenge, moves ahead one space or moves his opponent back one space.

The winner is the first player to save Minnie from the dragon.

Great nostalgic family fun !

Contents

1 x playing sheet
15 x Magic charm cards

4 x Playing pieces

1 x Spinner
categories: Children's Game, Memory, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Think a Dot
description: In turn, a player drops a marble in any one of the three holes at the top of the device. The device contains eight flip-flops; three on the top row, two on the middle row and three on the bottom row. A flip-flop will change a window’s color from one to the other every time a marble hits it. The marble will exit the device from the left or the right. A player may continue taking a turn as long as the marble exits the device from the side chosen by that player. The object of this puzzle-game is to get a pre-determined sequence of colors to be revealed in the eight windows.

name: The Game of Secession, or Sketches of the Rebellion
description: The Game of Secession was produced to support the Union cause. The gameboard featured a line of numbers from 1 to 135 and pictures of people and events from the Civil War. The game was found in the Civil War Scrapbook of Andrew Dickson White, the first President of Cornell University.

name: Quick! Put the kettle on
description:
This is a Snakes & Ladders-like game designed by cartoonist Simone Lia, themed around some of the recurring characters from her comic strips.

From the instructions:
"Each player chooses a character. There are six to choose from: Chip, Bean, Worm, Robot, Snail and Sad Cloud.

The aim of the game is to be the first player to get to square 40 to 'Put the kettle on'."

name: ABC: In the Jungle
description:
From the publishers homepage:

ABC – In The jungle is the ultimate connection between playing and learning and is therefore a must for all children in their preparation for school.

While playing "ABC – In The jungle" children get familiar with the letters in a fun and inspiring way. "ABC – In The jungle" can be played in 2 different ways, so children can play with family and friends over and over in various ways.

Furthermore you can adjust the length of each Game to whatever time frame you want: The number of cards you choose to use in each Game determines the playing time of each round of fun learning.

Gameplay
The order of which a card matches a square on the Game Board is determined by the starting letter of the words from the picture on the card or the other way around if the card is a letter. For example, the card with the letter Z matches the picture of a Zebra on a square on the board. The card with a picture of an Owl, matches the square on the board with the letter O.

2-GAMES-IN-1:

GET RID OF THE CARDS
Each payer is dealt a number of cards (for instance 4 cards each). In order to get rid of a card, a player must land on the matching square. The first player to get rid of all his / hers cards have won.

COLLECT THE MOST CARDS
4 cards are laid face up and now they players have to collect as many as possible by going to the square they match. When a player collects a card, a new card is turned face up. Before the game starts, the Players agree on the number of cards in total (for instance 12 cards). When all cards are collected, the player with the most cards has won the game.
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Educational, Word Game
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Tank Master
description:
Adapted from the old Macintosh Computer game, this game pits 2 or more players in a battle to see who can programme the most efficient tank. The tank with the most efficient yet adaptable programming and subroutines will dominate the battlefield and vanquish the other tanks.

Storyline
You are a battlefield commander of an evolutionary new tank in the battlefield of the future. Wars of today are fought by remote war machines. Pitted against you is your enemy, fielding their latest war machines. This will be a fight to the finish, the struggle for supremacy.

With your superior skills as a commander, you are to programme your tank and set it loose. Win or lose will depend on your intimate knowledge of your own tank's inherent abilities as well as your uncanny reading of what your opponent's tank will do and how you perceive it would react in battle.

Win or lose, after each round, redesign, re-programme, rework your tank's subroutines and primary programming to fine-tune your tank's performance. Remember, your enemy is doing the same thing. He would have watched the previous battle and noted his tank's and your tank's performance. He too will be working to reduce deficiencies and weak points in his own programming so as to triumph over yours. Then when you're both done with your re-programming, set let them go at it again! Send out prototype after prototype until either your tanks now reign supreme in every engagement, or they all lie devastated, crushed under the steel treads of better enemy tanks.

Programming is limited to the number of standard programming tiles available in the common pile but be wary of cumbersome programming that may make your tank less than efficient as it spends a fatally long among of time processing your programming while your opponent's more efficient design finds and destroys your tank!

Gentlemen, start your engines.... and let the games begin.

Game Pieces
1 dice (to determine your tank start position on the board)
1 main "battlefield" board - (for 2P board 17steps across, + 1P add 3steps across)
2 primary programming plates
8 subroutine programming plates; 2xFight, 2xEvade, 2xFlee, 2xDamaged
1 red team light tank
1 orange team light tank
1 red team heavy tank
1 orange team heavy tank
6 "damage" pins

A) 1 step Action Tiles
i) Move Forward 1 - (for 2P 5pcs, + 1P add 3pcs)
ii) Move Forward 2 - (for 2P 5pcs, + 1P add 3pcs)
iii) Move Forward 3 (only Light Tank) - (for 2P 3pcs, + 1P add 2pcs)
iv) Turn Left 1 (60 degrees) - (for 2P 5pcs, + 1P add 3pcs)
v) Turn Left 2 (120 degrees) (only Light Tank) - (for 2P 3pcs, + 1P add 2pcs)
vi) Turn Right 1 (60 degrees) - (for 2P 5pcs, + 1P add 3pcs)
vii) Turn Right 2 (120 degrees) (only Light Tank) - (for 2P 3pcs, + 1P add 2pcs)
viii) Reverse 1 - (for 2P 5pcs, + 1P add 3pcs)
ix) Complete Halt - (for 2P 3pcs, + 1P add 2pcs)
x) Detect Level 3 (Logic Gate) - (for 2P 5pcs, + 1P add 3pcs)

B) 2 step Action Tiles
i) Detect Level 4 (Logic Gate) (only Heavy Tank) - (for 2P 5pcs, + 1P add 3pcs)
ii) Fire - (for 2P 3pcs, + 1P add 2pcs)
iii) Shield Activated - (for 2P 5pcs, + 1P add 3pcs)
iv) Shield Deactivated - (for 2P 5pcs, + 1P add 3pcs)

C) Decision Tiles (goto)
i) FIGHT subroutine (Logic Gate) - (for 2P 5pcs, + 1P add 3pcs)
ii) FLEE subroutine - (for 2P 5pcs, + 1P add 3pcs)
iii) EVADE subroutine - (for 2P 5pcs, + 1P add 3pcs)
iv) return to PRIMARY - (for 2P 8pcs, + 1P add 5pcs)

notes:
1) Tank start positions are determined by a throw of the dice and placed on the corresponding number on the board
2) Action and Decision tiles are limited. Programming limited to total number of tiles on the board.
3) Tank collisions results in mutual destruction
4) Barrier/edge collisions results in halt in motion
5) Tank fire without prior detection of enemy does not hit
6) Tank fire disabled when shield is activated
7) Player to select target to hit if firing on multiple enemy
8) 2 step tile "Fire" hits on tile 2
9) 2 step tile "detect level 4" detects on both tiles 1 and 2
10) 2 step tile "shield activated" activates on tile 2
11) 2 step tile "shield deactivated" deactivates on tile 2
12) Fire range equal to detection range

name: Sock it To Me!  The "IN" Game for Swingers
description: Players take turns selecting plastic socks and if one contains the "it" disc, they must draw and "antic" card and do what that card says (e.g. "Act like a flower child") and keeps the card. If a "Sock it to me" card is drawn, the player must perform any antic the dealer wishes them to perform. Player with least amount of antic cards at end of the game wins.

name: Whip
description:
Winner is determined by whoever has all the cards at the end of the game. After cards are dealt equally to all players, they take turns laying one down. If someone notices two matching cards they yell Whip and takes both cards.

Cards contain very clever "whip" pictures and phrases. There are 9 sets of 4 cards each.

Only text on box is number 503. No publisher\manufacturer information on box or on instruction sheet.

This game is identical to the game of Snap

name: Uncle Wiggily's New Airplane Game
description:
From inside box cover:

The Story: That old rabbit gentleman, Uncle Wiggily, after many games and adventures, bought a farm and grew some carrots. He used to take his carrots to market in a wheelbarrow, but one day, over the radio, he heard that airships where much faster than wheelbarrows, so he bought himself something with which he could fly in the clouds.

So here we have a playing board to represent the country over which Uncle Wiggily flew from his carrot farm to the market where he sold his yellow vegetables. But the rabbit had so many adventures in his new airship as he did when hopping through the woods to cure his rheumatism at Dr. Possom's office. There were storms, waterspouts and he fell into tail spins and once had to jump in a parachute.

The moves are made by drawing cards. There are 105 white cards, each one telling you how many miles to hop Uncle Wiggily through the air. There are 35 red cards, which may move Uncle Wiggily ahead or perhaps delay hime for a turn or two, all according to luck.

The air path, from Uncle Wiggily's farm to the market is marked by sign boards each containing a letter instead of a number. And when these letters are separated into words, beginning at the farm, they spell out a funny little verse. See if you can write it down after the game.
categories: Animals, Aviation / Flight, Novel-based, Racing, Travel

name: Kruzifizz
description: A tactical dice game. Try to reach the opposite side of the board with your pieces. Each player controls his own pieces AND the 3rd party on the board - neutral pieces, moved by both players.

name: Four Horsemen: The New Game
description:
Each player possesses a horse farm with four blocks used for horses stamped with the individual name of the horses printed on them. Players move around the board to manage their horse farms.

The winner is the one with the most money at the end of the game.

This game was manufactured in Jamestown, ND.

name: War Bingo
description:
This colorful game of the latest American war machines will prove of interest to young and old alike.

There are ten types of pictures. Each player selects 15 at random and places them face down on bingo card. Then turns them face up and by discarding and getting new pictures, tries to create various picture combinations. Highest points awarded for 5 American Flags in a row. Winner is player with highest score.

name: Mish Mosh: The Jewish Word Game
description:
Mish Mosh - The Jewish Word Game includes rules in both Yiddish and English for the titular game Mish Mosh, which has striking similarities to Scrabble. There are also "student rules" that include three variants requiring increasing education:


Identifying the Alphabet - Simply select a letter from your tray, say what it is, then place it on the matching letter on the board. Congratulations! You just earned 5 points.
"Mish Moshing" the Language - Build sentences out of English words written somewhat phonetically with Hebrew letters.
Historical Mish Mosh - This variation can be played by any number of players. One player thinks of a "a famous Jewish Historical person", then spells his or her name with the tiles. (e.g. ABRAHAM) The next person must think of another whose name starts with the final letter of the previous one. (e.g. MOSHEH). This is an elimination game like HORSE: Each time you fail, you "earn" a letter of MISH MOSH. Once you have spelled the whole name, you are out.


Each tile has both the traditional print letter and its handwritten equivalent. There are no tiles for "final" forms of letters.

name: Horse Show
description:
"Buying, Selling and Trading Horses - From the Horse People"

This game is designed and published by Paul Burnham, American Saddlebred Training Stables, Jonesboro, GA.

This game provides players with an understanding of what horses and their breeders go through and deal with in the showing of horses - a sense of realism is hoped in case you want to know what it's really like owning a horse.

To win, a player must have a complete show string (one 5-gaited, one 3-gaited, one road horse, one fine harness, one pleasure horse and one risk horse) and a total of 500 points.

name: Roks
description:
Roks are domino-like pieces with Ace - King characters on each end. There are 36 pieces in the complete set.

There are eight games you can play with Roks:

Rokem - similar to normal dominos
Roker - variation to Rokem
Roket - Played with only 28 pieces and players bid on hands, using trump suits.
Orbit - 6 player bidding game played in teams,
Roks - 4 player game. Bid for a contracted number of tricks
Straights - 2 player game. Try to create 4 or more ROKS in a row with low end alike and high end descending.
Roksol - Solitaire game
Hilorok - similar to stud poker
mechanics: Hand Management, Pattern Recognition, Tile Placement

name: Speculation
description:
Speculation is the simple fast moving stock market game that embraces the quick fluctuations in price typical of the market of speculative securities.

The object of the game is for each player to increase his beginning net worth of $12,000 by "buying low" and "selling high" as prices of individual securities rise and fall on the Market Board.

The wooden market board is used to track the price of each stock (eight areas are Advertising, Aircraft, Automobile, Cosmetics, Electronics, Mining, Paper & Petroleum). Users keep track of game play on their Security Record sheets.

Winner is determined by calculating each individual's net worth consisting of both cash and the current market value of the securities they hold.

name: Super Fun
description: Objective is to match card combinations to the game board squares. Remove golf tees from the game bard by creating number combinations with the cards - using addition, subtraction and multiplication. Players are awarded points based on the color of their tees. Winner has highest amount of points.

name: Game of Telegrams
description:
Players complete to be the first to create 10 word telegrams using cards with words provided.

Game No. 1 is played creating any 10 word humorous or serious telegram, as the player chooses. Game No. 2 is played re-creating telegram messages printed on each form.

name: Roulette Baseball
description: Roulette Baseball, © Wm. Bartholomae produced in 1929 was a very simple spin the spinner to get the results game. There were more than 30 results that were possible when the spinner stopped. No skill involved, simply spin the spinner and see what happens to your team.

name: Blitz: The Air Raid Game
description:
Blitz is played on a board with 60 squares. Each squares represents a property or building such as railway stations, shops, etc. Each property has a value as marked.

The four center squares in the board are not marked and are used to start the game. The game is played with 60 bombs (red on one end and black on the other). To start the game 4 bombs (2 red end up and 2 black end up) are placed in the center four squares diagonally opposite each other. The attacker (using the red end) places a red bomb on any square where it will bracket a black bomb between it and a red bomb already on the map. When he does this he flips the black bomb over to red. The defender (using black) does the same with his black bomb, being sure to bracket a red bomb with his black. If a player is unable to find a legal place he loses his turn.

Play continues alternately until all 60 squares are filled. At that point the bombs are removed and the points on the squares underneath are totaled up. The high points wins.

name: Hold the Fort
description:
From the rules: There are 50 pieces or "men" constituting the Attacking Force use and Three "Officers" constituting the Garrison of the Fort.

Place the 50 pieces on the black spots outside the fort, the defender places the 3 officers on any of the dots on the front rampart of the fort.

The object of the attacking force is by solidly pressing forward to fill the 13 spaces of the fort.

The object of the garrison is to destroy the advancing force by jumping over and removing pieces so that the attacker cannot win the game.

Each player moves alternately. The defender can move on black and red lines in any direction. The defender can also jump over and remove any enemy on an adjacent spot if a vacant spot exists beyond. The attacker cannot jump and cannot move backward on the red lines.
categories: Abstract Strategy, American Civil War, Wargame

name: Bomber Attack
description: A very simple game where players move down a path based on a spin of the spinner. Actions can result based on where the space landed on by each player.

name: Pirogue: The Trinidad and Tobago Tarpon Tournament
description:
Pirogue: The Trinidad and Tobago Tarpon Tournament is a trick-taking game inspired by big game Tarpon fishing in the warm, blue waters of Trinidad and Tobago. The name of the game references the local hand-made flat-bottom wood boats used for fishing in the shallows of the surrounding Caribbean and Atlantic waters.

The play of Pirogue will be challenging play and good fun for gamers who enjoy games such as Tichu, Sticheln, Pinochle, Mü & Mehr, Spades, or Oh Hell! The game will also be a great companion for sportsmen who want to play a card game which couples concentration and skill with the same sense of anticipation and suspense found in a real big game fishing tournament.

One of the most important things for the first-time Pirogue player to learn is the abilities of the SPECIAL cards. Each SPECIAL card adds a different and subtle tactical twist to the game. Some cards even have different strengths depending on whether the card is the lead card in the trick or a following card.

Unique to Pirogue is the HOOK card. The HOOK card is a unique trick-taking device specific to the game. The HOOK card addresses the unpredictability and surprise found in sport fishing while adding another level of tactical play. The HOOK card also assists in removing the predictable run of the table for the strongest of hands because even the lowest SUITED card is a dangerous threat. Recognizing the strength of a well balanced hand over what may seem like a traditionally strong hand is an important part of understanding Pirogue play and key to successfully making a bid.

Also distinctive to Pirogue is linked play between partnerships and individuals. In big game fishing tournaments, prizes are awarded for both best boat and best angler. The game of Pirogue is played in partnerships called Pirogues as well as by individual players called Anglers. Pirogues and Anglers compete in an intertwined, and sometimes entangled, opposition to win Game Trophies that count towards taking home the ultimate prize: The Trinidad & Tobago Tarpon Tournament Trophy!

name: Cargo for Victory
description:
From the rules: Each player tries to have his Cargo Ships safely deliver cargoes to certain ports, using his submarines both to protect his Cargo Ships and to sink enemy Ships and submarines.

Cargo ships are chosen randomly so their destinations change. Subs start on the S Marked on the map. Ships and subs move 1 space in any direction but cargo ships can gain distance by jumping friendly ships/subs and enemy cargo ships. When a sub jumps an enemy cargo or sub then it is considered sunk and taken for scoring purposes. Ships that make their destinations are set aside for scoring as well.

Play ends and scores are totaled when the last Cargo Ship makes it home port.

name: Rickenbacker Ace Game: Keep em Flying
description:
From the Rules: The Rickenbacker Ace Game is an exciting game that can be played by 2 to 4 players.

The board represents the sky. Each player uses 9 planes of the same color. One plane is place in each square of its own color in back of the crossline, which represents the players base.

The object of the game is for a player to complete a mission with as many planes as possible by reaching the colored squares beyond the crossline in front of his own OBJECTIVE diagonally across the board from his starting base.

Moving in a clockwise direction each player moves 1 plane or "Flies" 1 plane 1 square diagonally across the board. Planes may jump adjacent enemy planes (in any direction) and thus shoot it down. When all of the player's planes have been shot down or reached their objectives the game is over and players get 1 point for each surviving plane in the objective and 2 points for each shot down enemy plane.

High points wins. The winner of five games becomes an ace.

name: Sea Raid
description:
Each player takes a fleet (3 Battleships, 3 Cruisers and 8 Destroyers). Each player also takes 3 mines and 3 buoys. The fleets are placed in the harbors or capitals (not on the Jetty dots used for "moving out").

Movement is based on the roll of 2 dice. Units may be moved in any combination adding up to the total on the dice (for example a roll of 12 means 12 units can move 1 or 4 units can move 3, etc.)

Attacking an enemy happens when friendly units move onto a spot with enemy units (there is no limit to stacking on a dot). To fight, players add up the values of each fleet (Destroyers = 1, Cruisers = 2 & Battleships = 3 combat points). The fleet with the lowest value must lose its best unit. Additional factors include forts, obstacles (shoals & straits) and high speed stretches. Buoys and mines affect movement.

The game is won by the player who succeeds in penetrating into the opponent's capital with one or more ships. Occupying the capital requires superior forces.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Invasion
description:
From the Rules: Invasion is a game for two to four players, who have before them a board divided into 13 rows of 13 alternatively white and blue squares.

The board is marked to show the starting position of the various pieces within each player's territory. There are 15 total units in a player's force, 6 Soldiers, 2 Tanks, 2 Cannon, 2 Bombers, 2 Pursuit Planes, 1 Dictator. These units are all lead miniatures (flats). Each unit type has a different movement, for example the soldier can move 1 space in any direction, the tank can move 1 or 2 squares in any direction. A unit is captured by entering its square and in some cases (cannons) the unit capturing can jump over intervening friendly units.

The object of the game is to capture the opposing dictator or dictators at which time the captured dictator's entire army "surrenders" and is removed from the board. When four people are playing then two sides ally and both players on one side must be defeated.

name: Wiry Dan's Electric Baseball
description: Harett-Gilmar produced Wiry Dan's Electric Baseball in 1950. This game, and a similar Jim Prentice-branded offering in 1948, added electricity to the outguess-your-opponent mechanism. In this case, the pitching player secretly pushes a metal arrow down onto one of four metal pitch option circles. The batter touches the lead on a wire to one of four hit circles. If a light goes on, he uses a spinner to determine the kind of hit. If nothing lights up, the batter touches the ball and strike circles to determine the result of the pitch. Two more circles by the "Smiling Umpire" determine the results of attempted steals and bunts, foul pops, tagging up or double-play attempts.

name: Flying Fun Card Game
description: Nucraft Toys presented this card game in 1927. Cards show different flying maneuvers. Object was to complete a flight successfully.

name: Crazy Traveller
description: Parker brothers 1908 game Crazy Traveller features a wind up spinner, a wooden board, and 16 wooden 'pins'. The object of the game was to start the spinner in the center of the board and then have it knock down as many pins as possible. The more you knocked down the higher your score.

name: Patrimonia
description:
Free interpretation from the rules (originally in French)

Every player has to enrich his initial heritage by a smart combination of buying and selling, weighing the possibilities of higher rates and periodically revenues, without overstating the risks of every type of investment.

The winner has, at the end of the game, the patrimonium (=latin for heritage of the father) with the highest value.

A round plays (in short) like this :

Take a "bourse" card.
Play one of the five "bourse" cards holding in the hand.
Adjust the stock board.
Roll 3 dice and advance your pawn.
So you end your move on 3 possibilities :
On a negotiation , on the unexpected or on revenue.

The game comes with a gameboard (consisting of 30 cases and a stock board), 5 types of cards (Bourse, Immobilier, Fôret, Numismatique and Imprévu), 71 paper chips , 6 Patrimoniumboards, 6 pawns, 3 dice and 165 cheques.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Stock Holding

name: The 2000 Guineas
description: This is an all metal game made in 1947 by B.B. Products of London, England. The gameboard is a simple spinning wheel mounted with six 'horses' and a removable 'post' which marks the winning finish line. The box itself is held together with rivets and it has an orange spinner which is not removable. The game is played by betting on the number of the horse you think will win. Each horse has different odds attached to the possibility of that horse winning the race.

name: Skip Ball
description: This is a table top version of the old fashion "Coney Island" type arcade game SKIP BALL. The board itself is made of stained wood and the game uses ceramic marbles. One long side of the bottom of the box has a triangular wooden cross-piece instead of a cardboard side and on the other long side there are two pieces of wood with grooves to hold a piece of very heavy card on to which are stuck six 'cups' with different values if your ball lands in one of them. The instructions say "Give the ball as long a roll as possible before it runs up the slope of the box and you will find that it springs more readily."

name: American Idols Live Tour 2005: Road to Fame Game – Part One – The Auditions
description: A simple promo board game that uses card drawing instead of dice rolling to move your game piece. It uses a "Limited Edition" Pop-Tart Box for all its game pieces and board. It is expanded by Part Two: The Countdown.
categories: Card Game, Math, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Number

name: Dexterity
description:
Dexterity is a unique word game - colourful, classic and above all, skill-testing. The play is unlike any other word game. In Dexterity, your ability to form interesting, unique and provocative words and to play intelligently is highlighted.

A unique scoring system rewards your level of achievement each round. The more challenges you are able to meet each round, the higher your score. Try it and see if you've got what it takes to be top notch!

OBJECT OF PLAY

The main object is to score the most points by skillfully forming words which your opponent(s) cannot break (i.e. change into a new word) while at the same time, cleverly breaking words belonging to your opponent(s).

Words which cannot be broken, that is, changed into new words, are called Unbreakable Words. Although the concept of Unbreakable Word is new to word games, the rules are simple and easy to grasp.

name: Wer Sieht's Zuerst?
description: Wer Sieht's Zuerst is a game for children, to keep them occupied during those long road trips (or even short ones). The object is to mark off objects in a bingo-like arrangement, as you come across them. Four different layouts provide different things to look out for on the road, such as road signs, license plates, makes of car and everyday objects.

name: Das Nordwolle-Spiel (Expo 2000)
description:
A small promotional game - only 999 were produced as give-aways for Expo 2000 in Germany.

Both players have two pins each, which start in a small wooden board with 19 holes. By jumping over one or more pins, the player reaching the target hole with one of his pins first wins.

name: Called to Arms
description:
A path movement game based on the Boer War. Players move down the path on the way to becoming the Commander of Chief.

An early and simple game based on a military subject with a detailed and colorful map. Key landing spots include an Ambuscade and Victoria Cross. Recorded in National Archives of Australia as first registered and exhibited in 1900.

'Called to Arms' was a game that took players along a perilous route through battles and adventures during the Boer War. It was a simple game of chance rather than military strategy that clearly took the side of the British imperial forces against the Boers. As such there was an attempt to both excite players and instill with patriotic feelings. In this respect the game is material evidence of the relationship between popular culture and ideology.

Under Creative Commons License: Attribution Non-Commercial

name: Tallyho
description:
TALLYHO "The War Cry of the R.A.F." Fighters & Bombers

Tallyho is one of the deepest games to come out of the 1940s. The players compete for merits by completing orders. Each player chooses a fighter or bomber and an airfield. Using dice the player moves over the spaces on the board. Ending on specific spaces forces the player to draw cards and perform the actions.

The player is given a cockpit to track altitude and turns. Orders can require being at specific altitudes and specific places to complete the mission.

Designed by a WWI RAF veteran, its quite interesting and advanced for its day.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling

name: Sea Raider
description:
The Game is played with Ships representing an enemy Raider (Black) and the pursuing Cruisers.

The Raider's goal is to get to the home base on the map without being captured by the pursuers. The map has multiple paths that the Raider can choose and some (those with Black dots) are impassable to the Cruisers but the Raider can only stay on the black dots for 1 turn.

A very simple wargame.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: Sum Times
description:
A 3M edition of the " Edu - PLAY - tional " series.

Game is similar - if not better! - equipped as " Quinto " from the adult bookshelf series of the same company and plays nearly the same.

You can tell that this is the better "Quinto" as it was edited earlier than the Quinto using the number tiles which have to be drawn in the pre-game-phase and was obviously adapted later.

Accordingly this is not a game for younger children as you have to be fit in multiplying and addition up to the number of 9.

There were two editions with completely different box design, the second one from 1968.

name: Ready, Set, Listen
description:
"This game is designed to help parents and young people talk to each other about underage alcohol use, why it's not smart, and how to prevent it.

The game has these goals:

1. to increase the number of conversations about the harms of underage alcohol use that parents and caregivers have with children Ages 9 - 13

2. to increase the percentage of children 9- to 13-years-old and their parents/caregivers who see underage alcohol use as harmful."

Roll the dice, move around the board, and draw cards that encourage discussion: "Feelings", "Facts" and "Challenges".
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Roll / Spin and Move
publishers: U.S. Department of Health and Human Services

name: The PBX Game
description:
From the publishers homepage:

Background
It is almost a true story. The Mayor of Farum (city on the outskirts of Copenhagen) had ruled the city like a king for almost a decade. His party ruled the city board and no one dared to speak out against the Mayor. But as with Hamlet, something is rotten in the Kingdom. A Danish newspaper blew the story wide open. It turned out that the Mayor, among other things, had made some creative investments and given his friends loads of city business. To top that off, his expense account carried not only trips to Championship Football games, but also wine for more than 10,000 a bottle – Cheers…

Sales and PR
PBX was released in the beginning of November 2002, and were sold out before New Year – that made PBX: The fastest selling board game in Denmark ever. 12,000 copies sold from the shops in only 6 weeks – without a dime spent on marketing. Yet PBX was able to create heavy and very positive media coverage: The media also focused on the fact that PBX was the first of it's kind. Some articles even had politicians (the main characters in PBX) playing the game and reviewing it. National TV News gave it full coverage as Christmas Gift of the Year, including a review done by two Mayors. The second largest daily newspaper had "business" Cavling Winning (same as Pulitzer) journalists reviewing the game (BT).

Game play
As a Mayor of a Danish town, you are obsessed about making your city the best city in the country. To fulfil all the dreams you have for the city, the Game starts out with you taking an illegal loan of 250 million from the Government. Now your job as a Mayor is to drive around the game board in your Mayoral car and try to spend the money as fast as possible. On your way you pick cards with instructions on how much to spend on, for instance, "gifts " to business relations in return for favours, dinners you have to give to keep your fellow politicians on board and travels you need to make in order to do proper "research ". You have to be careful, because the people you mingle with can easily forget their obligations to you, even though the gifts you spent on them were expensive. Your political opponents (though still full from the "friendly " dinner you hosted) will try and expose you, or the Government might even call you in for a little chat that would force you on a leave of absence, where you have no chance at all of blowing your 250 million. The instruction cards, mixed with questions on luxury lifestyle, all evolve around issues that actually did take place, though blown totally out of proportion and with a humorous distance, making this the first Board Game ever to truly be appointed: A Satire Board Game.

name: Pay Off
description:
Game comes in a 14 1/2" x 14 1/2" x 5 1/4" box and requires assembly.

The plastic Pay Off contraption, once assembled, vaguely resembles a kind of lolly machine from the Wild West. Three catch-triggered compartments sit behind a transparent plastic window with a small target located centrally beneath each. In each compartment there are one or more marbles.

Players roll a single marble each turn at the three targets from a predetermined distance - six to eight feet is recommended in the rules. If any of these are hit, a catch is released and the marbles in the compartment above are released to the player. One marble must be replaced in the compartment once it is reset for the next player. A plastic ramp located behind the targets catches stray marbles which roll up the ramp and then enter one of the three compartments in the machine. Players must also place marbles from errant rolls (e.g. those which miss the machine completely or are not strong enough to reach it) in any compartment they choose (there is a small square hole above each for this purpose).

Players are eliminated when they are out of marbles. The last player left with one or more marbles is the winner.

N.B. This game should not be confused with the 1978 marble game called Pay Off (or Pay Off Machine - game ID# 9025) also released by IDEAL which looks like a canister with horizontal sections that rotate.

name: Polygone
description:
Game consists of 36 hexagonal tiles and two 6 sided coloured dice. The tiles have 6 different colors on edges and the colors are arranged on the tile randomly.

Points are awarded for constructing various polygons.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Pattern Building, Tile Placement

name: Universal War
description:
From the publisher:

"The Universe is locked in eternal war. Amidst the uncounted galaxies of space, a million races struggle to survive a conflict that has raged since the dawn of creation. The young race of Man, recently ascended from the primordial ooze of Earth, is just the latest to learn of his impending doom."

Have you ever watched a science fiction movie thick with dramatic battle scenes and wished that you could step in and control the action? Wished you could command your own termination machines, armored storm troopers, or slime covered aliens. If so, then behold, for the means to do so is here before you now, within the pages of this book. Welcome to Universal War, a 10MM-1/180th scale, mass-combat, science fiction, miniatures war game. It allows players to lead fantastical armies amidst the unlimited planetary war zones of the far future and compete with one another for supreme control over all the fictional worlds ever made popular by novels, comic books, toys, television, and the cinema. Universal War allows its players to build and battle any army they can dream up. There are no limitations and no forbidden ideas, so summon your chosen legions and let the battles begin.

name: CraZmates the Relationship Board Game for Teens & Young Adults
description:
CraZmates is the outrageously fun, party game that will keep players laughing & joking as they experience the ups and downs of relationships. It's so emotionally riveting that some forget it's just a game!

The challenge is to find a perfect mate (or at least a not-so-CraZ one). There's just one catch: Sometimes it's hard to figure out whether a new mate is "craZ about you" or "just plain craZ".

Select from dozens of mates, including your favorite celebrities & local hotties. But be on the look out for highly-competitive, so-called friends willing to do anything to win, including steal a perfect mate!

Players Experience real life situations - ranging from the slightly bizarre to the outrageous. They'll want to play it again an again, because each time is a new experience. Players never know what to expect from CraZmates!
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Role Playing, Roll / Spin and Move, Voting

name: Manah
description:
"In the Ancient World, thousands years before Lemuria, The Ruler, the grandfather of all gods, controls men´s destiny. The five kings try to garner your favor, raising temples to pray and hail the great god..."

From the Lost Chronicles of Lemuria...

Manah (Maná) each player is a ruler of a fantasy kingdom, and your main goal is conquer and build more temples to praise the gods. All players can buy divine artifacts for their kingdom and invoke celestial "arauts" for help against their enemies. This game is still in development and play testing
categories: Abstract Strategy, Fantasy, Mythology, Territory Building

name: Big Red Bus Game
description: The big red buses are at the station, can you be the first to fill your bus and leave? Use the spinner to collect your passengers from the queue, but make sure they fit correctly on the bus!

name: Funny Fits Friends Game
description: Eight fun characters, each separated into three pieces and mixed up together. Either race to find and piece them together correctly or simply have fun mixing them all up and making wacky new characters. A colourful classic.

name: Nature's Challenge
description:
An environmental themed roll-and-move game that features trivia, drawing and acting. "Natures Challenge offers you exciting, fun ways to learn more about animals, plants and the environment of North America." For Ages 11 and up.

To retain their progress from the dice roll, players must answer trivia about the category that corresponds to the spot they arrived on. Some spots instead require acting or drawing to get another player to guess the secret word. A few spaces give a player temporary special abilities.

Contents:
Game board
167 Question cards
167 Mime / drawing cads
6 Game pieces
1 Dice, pencil, pad
mechanics: Acting, Line Drawing, Memory, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Operaatio X
description:
In this game half of the players are cargo vessels shipping goods to ports. Other half are buccaneers trying to steal the goods. Whenever a cargo vessel successfully delivers goods player is awarded points to the value of the cargo. Buccaneers receive points when they successfully steal the shipment. When the shipment is delivered or lost, the cargo vessel player draws a new card that indicates destination and value of new shipment. Game is played until all the shipment cards have been used.

The map consists of two different kinds of routes, open water and shallow. Players can freely move which ever way they prefer, but if a ship ends its move on shallow water the player has to draw an action card. Most of these cards either make the player sit out next turn or allows them to take new turn right away.

name: Tarzan Card Game
description:
Object: collect the most matching pairs of cards

Contents: 1 playing board, 48 cards, 1 instruction booklet

Description: (from game box) A card game that's based on the Life and Legend of Lord Greystoke, Tarzan of the Apes. It's a matching game! You and your opponents try to collect the most matching pairs of cards by choosing cards from the board or from players' hands. Can you remember where Tantor the elephant is hiding on the board? Or Manu the monkey? Whose hand is Bara the antelope in? Find two of these-or any other colorful characters in the game-and you have a match! The player with the most pairs wins the game.

Strategy Hints:
try not to show the players the cards in your hand or on your side of the board. you know what these cards are, but other players may not. Unless another player chooses one of your cards, don't show them, choose one of their cards instead.
Mix up the cards in your hand as often as you'd like, but especially when other players have seen your cards. Don't make it easy for them to make a match with your cards.
categories: Card Game, Memory, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based

name: The Liberty Game
description:
The Liberty game was created at the end of WWI and what follows is based on examining the only part available, the game board.

Apparently the player moves along the path via a die roll, fighting against the color coded units the player lands on (possibly facing at least 3 levels of combat, each new challenge coming after winning a previous battle). Each victory earns points.

The assumption is that after all players have returned to the USA the player with the most points wins.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: Alfa-Lek
description:
A game in Kärnan´s line of wooden games for children.

This is an educational game to help children learn to read and write. The game features 56 wooden-puzzle tiles with letters. Players connect tiles to make the letters build words matching.

Ages 7 and up.

name: Benedicto
description:
Benedicto, also know as "Beat the Blitz". An odd little follow-the-path game created by the makers of Benedict Peas. The description says it is a thrilling race against air raids, and time bombs, road jams and tank traps, warnings and diversions.

Players start in the pea patch and must move through the factory as they head home. The most interesting parts of the game are the advertisements on the back.

name: Bomber Raid
description:
From the rules: The object of the game is to bomb enemy objectives and, at the same time, to spot and bring down attacking enemy bombers before they drop their bombs. Equipment includes the game board, two dice, 2 searchlight beams and 8 bombers.

Players place the searchlight on the board with the small end on the X about the searchlight crew and the large end pointing to the 1. Play is alternately done and is based on the roll of a die. The roll can be used to either move a plane or the searchlight. A roll of 6 means the player loses his turn. Planes may be moved in any direction but must be moved the full distance of the die roll in that same direction. The searchlight can be moved in one direction, up or down, based on the die roll. A plane is shot down when either it is on the same line as an enemy airplane at the end of the enemy's turn or it crosses the searchlight beam. A score is obtained if the plane can cross over the targets in enemy territory.

The winner is the player with the highest bombing total after all planes have been brought down.

name: Define It
description: The box describes this game as an "extraordinary new concept" and a "unique fun-filled word game fashioned for the family of the future". Develop your verbal abilities, comprehension, pronunciation, and vocabulary.

name: Strategy
description:
Strategy is played by two players. Each player has 12 units which are put into play from the black circles at opposite end s of the board called the "Front Line". The spinner controls the movement of the units.

Players spin alternately and if they land on a numeral they can move the number of units indicated diagonally one space per unit. Special spins (left and right gun) kill all enemy units along the appropriate gun line. Also the charged wire spin kills all units sitting on the wire. The fill spin allows you to bring in one of the replacement units. Players can also jump enemy units to capture them.

The winner is the first player to get a unit into the enemy "First Line".

name: Closing the Ring
description:
From the "Pledge" link on the Decision Games Website:

This mid-sized-monster game can be played as a two-player or three-player contest. It has three large-hex maps, with 560 half-inch counters, covering the ETO from D-Day to V-E Day at 20 miles per hex. The main fronts are covered, excluding only Scandinavia and Greece. Each game turn equals a third of a month. Units are divisions for the Western Allies and Germans, corps for the Soviets (but with a complete divisional artillery order of battle), and armies for the Yugoslav's and the various minor powers.

The system is an operational (rather than strategic) derivation of the one used in "Beyond the Urals" and "Operation Kremlin." No unit will have more than one step. All entry data, notes about reinforcement or special status, etc., can be printed on their reverse sides. Stacking is eight units per hex, with both sides having the move/fight or fight/move sequence option, along with the possibility for limited use of fight/fight.

The system will be simple, making for a game players can finish in one long weekend, but there will also be plenty of historic chrome, such as: V-weapons, the Warsaw Rebellion, liberation of the death camps, Führer-Mandated Offensives, FLAK divisions, the Upper Silesian industrial region, German economic collapse, National Socialist ardor, proletarian heroism, heavy bombers, naval gun support, fortified lines, etc.

Play begins with the Western Allied player (or the "Grand Alliance" player in a two-player match) launching the D-Day landing. He'll be free to choose just about any coastal hex from northern Germany to the Spanish border as his landing site. Or he might choose to come ashore that first time on the Mediterranean coast of France, the far north of Italy, or even somewhere along the Yugoslavian coast. He'll also have a second invasion available for use later that summer.

Victory is determined using a point system, primarily based on the German retention of cities according to a schedule derived from the historic Allied advance. There will be periodic victory checks to prevent the German player from adopting any kind of unhistorical strategy based on retreating into the Reich's heartland at the very start of play to try to form some kind of super defensive hedgehog. That ploy would have been impossible for the Germans to support economically in the real-world, and having to maintain a certain level of victory points in order to survive the period victory checks will work to the same effect in the game.

The combat results table will be of the unit-elimination type, with results of "D-elim," "D-back-2," "Exchange," etc. Thus replacements will be plentiful and the action along the fronts fast and furious. Typical German infantry division will have attack and defense factors of 1-1, 1-2 or 2-3, while panzer divisions will weigh in as 3-2s and 4-3s. In comparison, US infantry divisions will be 3-4s, while that nation's armor divisions will be 4-3s and 5-3s.

A boxed game to be designed by Ty Bomba. Est. Retail: $60 (Est. Pledge: $45)

name: The Big Battalions
description:
A Napoleonic Game suitable for several brigades on each side.

Can be played with 28mm down to 6mm figures. Infantry are based on 40mm squares for 25/8mm and 25mm squares for 15mm down to 6mm. Units are battalions, squadrons or batteries. Games are usually up to a Corps per side with two players.

Card driven with the numbers of cards and options available being dependent on the quality of the commander. Combat is abstracted in "DBx" style depending on the number of units involved and support rather than detailed firing and melee results.

Movement and range measurement is also very flexible being determined by "bands" of distance (around 6" in a 25mm game) rather than micro measurement.

National characteristics and morale rules cover all aspects of the Napoleonic period. Designed for rapid action and big decisions rather than micro management. And no casualty removal so all those lovely 28mm figures that you painted stay on display!
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling

name: Robots and Reptiles
description:
Robots and Reptiles is a war game played on a checker board or other grid based map. Players build their forces around miniatures they provide, which could be anything from plastic army men to Godzilla figurines. This was a Cheap Ass style game from the age of mimeographs, before photocopies were plentiful and cheap.

This stand alone product has sample units and rules for creating your own, and the rules book is small enough to fit in your pocket.

Many copies have incomplete or hard to read rules because they were all trimmed in bulk, by hand, so partial text clipping is common.
mechanics: Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Truth Tower
description: This game has solid wood playing pieces. It's very similar to Jenga. The difference is this game has a question printed on every block. The questions are like those that you ask in "truth or dare", although all of these are "truth" questions. Examples on the box are: describe yourself in three words, what is your biggest pet peeve, and who would play you in a movie of your life?

name: Buzz Off: The Electronic Bingo Game
description:
Buzz Off is Bingo with an electronic element. From the box cover: "You pick the winning number. Be careful! Trip the buzzer & you lose your turn."

Contents: six 5x5 bingo cards, one hundred chips (#1-25, four each), one bowl and base.

name: Wild West
description: There are two roads to Dodge City, one red and one black; you can chose one of these roads to go to your destination. On your way to Dodge City you will win or lose money, visit the saloons and get in fights with bandits. The Cowboy who reaches the Mayor in Dodge City with a gold bag and the most money will win the game.

name: Obol
description:
Obol is a stimulating board game combining entertainment with education. Obol, an exciting addition game in which tossing the dice determines your numerical points. Obol is a dice game that challenges your mathematical skills.
(From the box)
publishers: Go Anywhere Games, Ikron, R. D. Retort Enterprises

name: Fische und Schafe
description:
The game was included in "Das Buch der Spiele" (Book of Games), a cataloge printed for Spielefest, Wien's game festival held on 23.-25.11.2007.

Players are trying to place their fish right way, so they score victory points (fish), while they cannot place white and black sheep near each other.

name: Quid
description:
New trivia game containing 1500 questions from the Quid encyclopedia. Be the first to go from one end of the board to the other by answering questions about numbers, celebrities, hobbies, ...
Each card contains two questions, one for junior players and one for adult players, so that it can be played with all the family.

name: Sus-Pense
description:
Sus-Pense is not just the game of "Hangman" but can also be used to play "The Game of Merrio" - a "Cootie" like game.

Sus-Pense has a man made of out plastic parts that you hang on a metal trapeze.

"A game of Wits for the Entire Family"

name: Pohjoisen Pikajunan Arvoitus
description:
The board is map of Finland with not entirely accurate railway and bus network. One of the players is the mystery traveler who plans his/her route from on of three cities in southern Finland (Turku, Helsinki or Kouvola) to one of the three towns in northern Finland (Kolari, Rovaniemi or Keminjärvi) and back. He/she only reveals his/her whereabouts in every sixth city he/she visits.

If the mystery traveler can make his/her route, he/she is the winner. If any of the other players can get to the same city with the mystery traveler that player wins.

Players move by throwing dice and completing tasks in cities they visit. Mystery traveler doesn't throw dice.

This game is a promotional game from the Finnish transport company VR.

name: Seafood Palace
description:
Seafood Palace is a medium-weight resource management and auction game for three to five players aged 10 years and older. Games usually last from 60 to 90 minutes. The game features an innovative dice drafting mechanism for players to obtain resources used in bidding for cards which yield points. Each turn, players have a variety of actions available to them and tempo is an important consideration – it may be good to get a bid in first to win a card cheaply, but at the cost of taking a high value die instead.

In Seafood Palace, players take on the role of Chinese seafood restaurant owners in Singapore, seeking to gain fame points by bidding to satisfy public demand for tasty seafood dishes. The more resources you put into the dish, the more likely that people will identify that dish with your restaurant, and this recognition is represented by fame points.

Every player starts with stores of fish, prawn, crab, non-seafood resources (chicken and vegetable), beverages and coins. The resources are represented by counters on the player’s own board, which represents the player’s stores.

Each round, public demand is represented by dish cards that become available for auction. Players bid to satisfy the demand with the corresponding resources and the highest bid wins the card and the fame points on the card.

Each round, new resource dice and number dice are available for players to replenish stores. These dice are traded in as pairs (one of each kind) to get the specified number of the specified type of resource (e.g. a 5-number die and a crab resource die are traded in for 5 crab resources).

There are also bonus cards which could permit special actions to benefit the player - some of the bonus action cards include discounts on buying seafood resources, using MSG to get an advantage over your competitors (but with a penalty) or the abundant catch that helps you stock up on seafood. Bonus cards could also be set menus, which if fulfilled by the end of the game, will yield bonus points. A wedding banquet menu is valuable, and this game also caters to vegetarians with a vegetarian set menu. If you hire a master chef, your lowly 1-point dishes will increase in value.

The twist is that players have to choose which of several actions they want to take (take a die, bid on a dish, claim a dish, bid on a bonus card, claim a bonus card, or pass) and focusing on one action means sacrificing the tempo to carry out another action. If you decide to go for the high number die, someone else could take the resource die of the type you need badly, and yet another will get in a bid on a valuable card that you can’t outbid because you haven’t managed to obtain the right dice yet …

The game lasts enough rounds so that each player has the advantage of going first an equal number of times. At the end of the game, players score fame points for dish cards they have won, set menus they have fulfilled with their dishes, and recognition for having the best stocked cellar (player with the most beverages) and best seafood stocks (player whose least seafood resource is greater than other players’ least seafood resource). The player with the most famous restaurant wins.

Seafood Palace was accepted for play-testing in the 2008 Hippodice competition

name: Hoe overleef ik mezelf spel
description: A trivia cardgame around the books by Dutch author Francine Oomen in which the players learn a lot about themselves and each other. Some acting skills, a bit of courage and lots of humour are required to play the game.

name: Nordopoly
description: Nordopoly is yet another Monopoly clone. The game is a promotional item for Nordstrom department stores with squares and cards representing areas of the store such as Jewelry, Shoes, Sportswear, and Furnishings. The Jail Square is replaced with "Customer Service." Apparently, serving customers is equivalent to serving time.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: PFC: The Pro Football Chronology
description:
Features:
All professional teams from the year 1920-2006 are included. (APFB, AFL & NFL)
Teams are rated in overall offense, defensive and execution ("X" factor, which is based on win percentage.) Teams are also assigned a power (P) rating, which fine-tunes a squad's offensive strength.
Fast and accurate results: Play a complete game in 5 to 10 minutes.
As in the high school game, the game engine is self-driven. You may still call for the 2-point conversion, run out the clock, attempt a 4th down conversion, use the hurry-up offense, and attempt onside kicks.
100 pre-printed action cards included, or you may use your own 10-sided dice or pre-printed random number sheets. (#'s 1-100)
Keep score and track the time expired as you play. Tally each team's cumulative plays and total yardage, if you wish to accumulate stats.

name: Regional: The Game of Pro Bowling
description:
Features:
All bowlers who competed in at least 3 rounds during the 2006 season are included
Non-PBA member bowlers also included
Optional lane condition system - May affect a bowlers final or individual frame score
2 ways to play: Quick mode or Ball-by-Ball; simulate an entire tournament quickly or watch the action unfold as it happens
Run your own regional tournaments; bowler charts are grouped by his or her home state

name: Games of the Pilgrim's Progress, Going to Sunday School and Tower of Babel
description:
An integrated three game set produced by McLoughlin Brothers, in true bookcase style. The wooden playing board has a pair of book-like spines on one side and the illusion of book pages on the others, with an outer slip case to hold everything together. The set also contains a dual arrowed spinning indicator which its makers proclaimed as "A Complete and Unobjectional Substitute for, and Improvement on Dice, Teetotums, &c."

In the basic Pilgrim's Progress game, played on the outer board halves, a player must move both of his pieces (two pawns: a Pilgrim and a Staff) by the number of spaces indicated by the dual spinner until he reaches the Giant Despair space. He then moves his Pilgrim alone until it lands by exact count on the Golden Gate, and thence (if not displaced) to victory in the Celestial City. Rules for three other variants are also included. These use various combinations of board spaces and require differing numbers of pieces.

In Going to Sunday School, played in one of the inner board halves, players spin and move around the board. Essentially, the player that lands on the most picture spaces (10 special spaces, each illustrating a virtue or a vice) is the winner.

The Tower of Babel, played in the other inner board half, combines a race for the top of the tower with a race to the bottom. Different rules apply to each race within the game. The winners of each half have a spin-off to determine the overall winner.

Contents:

Rule booklet
12 round-headed (Pilgrim) wood pawns
6 pointed-headed (Staff) wood pawns
Dual arrowed spinner
Wooden game board
Slip case

name: Evel Knievel Stunt Game
description:
"Evel Knievel races around the Track. You perform 6 Daredevil stunts. Most skillful cyclist wins."

A battery operated board game based on the exploits of the motorcycle riding, car jumping daredevil. The stunt motorcycle moves around a circular track and a "brake" button on the center motor allows the players to start and stop the motorcycle once a stunt has been set up. The six daredevil stunts the players perform are: Big Wheel (dodge the rolling tire), Barrel Barricade (stop before hitting the barrels), Wheelie, Stop on Ramp, Loop, and Pit Stop.

Components: Box, instructions, Evel Knievel cycle with wire, power pack, 2 barrels, 1 wheel ramp, 1 jump ramp, 1 incline, 1 wheel, and trophies. One D battery required.

name: Top Me
description: Each player controls six cone-shaped "tops". During their turn, players roll two six-sided dice and move one of their tops around the board forward or backward. The object of the game is to capture all of your opponent's tops by landing on them before your opponents do. Before the captures are complete, you can unload your captors into your home space. The rules permit some areas on the board designated as safe zones and the option to trade captors with another player.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Safety First
description:
Safety First: The Fun and Factual Game for Kids and Parents

This is a safety game for kids about how to stay safe when they're alone or in a difficult situation. The figures move around the board reaching places that represent school, the bus, home, the mall and other places a child might be. Children are asked questions about hypothetical situations - some social, some life-threatening - and asked to tell what they would do. Adult cards ask parents to answer questions about their own childhoods. When children are empowered by correct responses and adult reinforcement, their lives will be safer. Discussing these issues can help a kid to act smart, not scared if they find themselves in certain circumstances.

name: Flix
description:
Flix was distributed as a single game containing three rule variants (Lucky Flix, Pay-Off Flix, and Tac-T-Flix). The basic goal is to get 4 taxpayer men in a row on a three dimensional gameboard. Specialized dice are used to limit the color and placement of pieces on the "Spaceboard". In Tac-T-Flix, Burocrats, a second type of game piece, are introduced.

Contents:
One rules sheet says:

54 flexible taxpayer men (in three colors for the different players
24 Burocrat[sic] Men (8 of each color)
3 special Flix dice
12 Numbered Tokens


So there are 18 "taxpayer men" and 8 "burocrat[sic] men" in eaach of the three colors. The men are made from looks to be a drinking straw. The top on both is cut off at about a 60 degree angle to give a very pointy appearance. Presumably this is the end that you'd stick in first through the board holes. The bottoms of the taxpayer men are cut off straight across, however the burocrat[sic] men are notched into a "V" and are longer.

The numbered tokens are a card sheet with 12 very thin strips that are meant to be cut off. The strips have a number on them. The set is six 10's, three 25's, two 50's, and one 100. The idea is that when the strip is folded in half that the number is hidden when stuffed inside a "straw piece." The numbered tokens are only used in the game Pay Off Flix by folding them in half and randomly splitting the 12 token between the two players.

Also see:
Qubic which is 4x4x4 tic-tac-toe
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Line Drawing, Pattern Building, Tile Placement

name: Town And Country
description:
Many stories can be told and many adventures await in this clever sequencing game for young children.

As card after card is placed in a row, story pictures are created to talk about and share. Players complete country or town scenes by matching the pictures, one after the other. "Here's a farm with lots of animals! There's a truck carrying a big load".
