description: Players reach into a bag to identify shapes and complete a puzzle card with the shapes they select.

name: Jogo Picolé
description:
From the publisher: "Jogo Picolé, the game of crosswords is now a boardgame to play with your friends!

On you turn, roll the dice and move your pawn. You may land on a space with a question that should be answered with a word of up to three letters or over four letters, or even a word that worth twice the points. The most important thing is to not leave it blank, after all the player who gets more points answering the questions will be the winner"

name: Game of Nationalities
description:
The primary game represents a struggle for supremacy, in which America and Europe are allied against Asia and Africa. Cards are dealt to each player, and the top card of the deck is turned up. The continent of this card, and its allied continent, are "crowned" and have higher value. Players play to a trick, following with the same continent, if possible. High card, taking into account value and whether the card is "crowned," takes the trick. When cards are exhausted, points are totaled, and high score wins the round and 1 point. 11 points wins the game.

Rules for 5 different games are included.

name: Confab
description:
Confab is a conversation-based blank-card game for any number of players; ideally two. It was idly invented for a prize in Round One of BlogNomic (http://blognomic.com), and has been polished slightly for more-than-two-player games since.

Get a load of blank cards; at least ten per person. Everyone then scribbles arbitrary conversational sentences ('Hello.' 'How are you?' 'Yes.' 'No.' 'You're very tall.') onto the cards, until they're all covered. Shuffle them all together, deal five to each person and leave a face-down draw pile.

Taking turns, players must either play a card from their hand that follows conversationally from the previous card (or opens the conversation, if they're the first to play), or - if they can't go - draw a new card from the draw pile.

It sounds a bit of a throwaway game, but there's a good level of strategy and humour to it; the 'offensiveness' and 'defensiveness' of particular sentences, the vagueness of wild cards, the general effect of cartoon characters communicating via pre-written signboards. Language is a game, after all.

Available at:
http://kevan.org/games/confab.html

name: Short Circuits
description:
Educational game designed to teach electrical circuit theory. Includes board, chips, and tiles showing electronic elements, such as diodes, capacitors and wires.

"A high tension game of building and blocking electrical circuits requiring skill, strategy, and a lot of luck."

Details of the game available in US Patent #4376538
mechanics: Network and Route Building, Tile Placement

name: Discover Columbus
description: From the cover: "DISCOVER COLUMBUS: A trivia game that tests and improves your knowledge of the Columbus, Ohio area."

name: Sky Sports
description:
A trivia game based on sports knowledge, heavily weighted to the European television network from which it draws its name.

Playable from 2 to 6 players and/or by team play.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Sports, Trivia

name: Alfa-Bild
description: Alfa-Bild (English, Alpha-Picture) is a Swedish children's game in which the object is to identify pictures and find the corresponding first letter.

name: Serving Time on the River
description: Serving Time on the River is a game created by a prison inmate and sold at prison craft sales. It is intended to simulate life in the Angola Louisiana State Prison. Players take on the roles of inmates from Angola prison with different sentences, and spin their way around the board, hoping for eventual parole when they obtain 1,000 points. They must endure "Unavoidable Circumstances," ranging from frame-ups by enemy inmates to extortion, and players may commit offenses as well, which could land them in the work camp or the "Dungeon," or simply lose you the game (e.g. suicide). Good behavior and informing on other inmates may help players to be freed. The game is made to convey the hopelessness of prison life, as some players may not win at all if their sentences are not commuted. The designer created the game to be played by youth offenders to encourage them to stay out of prison.

name: Sgame
description: The idea of the Sgame is to lay out your tiles to create a row of triangles of your color, as long as possible. And to prevent the rows of your opponent.

name: PACE: The Double Deck Card Racing  Game
description: A horse racing, trick taking game. It has a deck of 72 unique cards that go from 5-30 (by fives) and 1/5-4/5th. The cards, along with the numbers, has a distance (suit) on each card...quarter mile, half-mile, three-quarters mile, and mile.

name: Metamorfo
description: Metamorfo is an educational game, created by a French Canadian teacher, that teaches youngsters to play checkers and the concept of metamorphosis. The game helps develop concentration, strategy and dexterity in children.

name: Courtship and Marriage
description:
Simple roll-and-move game designed to educate children on the morals of courtship.
Now stands as a museum piece both in the National Library of Australia, where it is dated "c1905", and in the National Archives of Australia, where it is dated 1909 based a copyright registration record by the designer.
In the latter it is part of a National Archives display entitled The Games We Played, which features a dozen games form the same publisher and designer from around the early 20th century.
From the display notes: "...some of the favourite sports of the time - yachting, horse racing, cricket and tennis - were cleverly packaged for parlour play. Even more serious matters - such as not offending your prospective in-laws or getting through to the right number at the telephone exchange - could all be managed with the lucky toss of the dice.
"All these board games were designed by Christopher George King of the National Games Company, a man who obviously had a real creative bent.
"His moral sense is also evident in Snakes and Ladders where traits such as anger and avarice send you tumbling down the board while kindness and obedience are duly rewarded..."

name: Round Up
description:
Beware of the wolves as you gather the sheep!
Earn the most points in this strategic game... and win!

Round Up is a strategic tile-laying game for Ages 7 and up. Players take turns 'penning' sheep by laying tiles to complete fences around groups of sheep and score points based on the number of sheep enclosed. Wolves subtract from a player's score. Hunters may be used to neutralize wolves. Place a well in a pen and double your score!

name: My First Games: Match & Spell
description:
In Match & Spell, a child learns:

- to recognize the shapes and orientation of letters
- to apply recognition of basic colors
- to match words with pictures
- to make groups of similar items

The game is designed to work in different ways with different ages.

The cardboard components are decorated with the characters of Suzy's Zoo.

name: R&R's Crossword Challenge
description:
R&R’s Crossword Challenge The Board Game is made for crossword lovers by crossword lovers. This unique, fun game that challenges your friends and your mind is ideal for ages teen to adult.

Each puzzle slides into the clear plastic Puzzle Holder which can be rotated to give each player the proper viewing angle. The Wet Erase pens make it easy to fill in words on the puzzle and still allow mistakes to be erased and corrected. These pens will also be used on the reusable scorecard.

The answer cards are encoded and are readable only when viewed through the Revealer. Use of the Revealer during play ensures there are no mistakes made when completing each puzzle. The Revealer allows everyone to participate without assigning one person to check answers.

The Master Edition includes 48 reusable crossword puzzles with a medium level of difficulty and can be enjoyed by players aged teen to adult.

name: Let's Auto-Tour
description: A "travel game" in which up to four players travel on different routes from a joint starting point on the west coast of the United States to four different destinations on the east coast. The game features a 34x17" hinged mapboard showing the lower 48 United States, four stand-up automobile pawns, two spinners, and play money. The instructions are printed on the inside of the box cover.

name: Cheer Boys Cheer!
description:
Regimental level combat rules for use in the American Civil War.

In a departure from the usual modern wargame environment (like Shipwreck and Tank Wreck!), take a look at the bloody battlefields of the American Civil War.

Using a carefully developed rules system, CBC offers the realism and playability you've come to associate with Vandering Products.
CBC allows you to recreate both land and naval warfare in 1861-1865.
categories: American Civil War, Book, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Paper-and-Pencil, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: All of Me
description:
From the box: All of Me is a fun and healthful game for children Ages 4 - 8. Simple, yet stimulating, it promotes the positive values of life along with color and shape recognition, sequential reasoning, turn taking and even a healthy degree of frustration tolerance.

This one-f-a-kind game, developed by psychologist Dr. Paul R. Gorecki and New Day Enterprises, helps young children develop a healthy attitude about themselves, their emotions and life in general.

Rolling the die (a large foam cube), players move about the graphically interesting game board amid colorful children's activity scenes, following directions and gathering cards which clearly display the meaning of Love, Happiness, Sharing, Caring, Honesty and Friendship.

Players may be lucky enough to climb a tree to the "Nest Rest", glide down the "Water Slide", or go "Finish" space, all the while keeping an eye on their "ALL OF ME" goal and their playmates.

The first child to collect and assemble all six positive value cards on his or her self-character and move on to the "Finish" space wins. Yet, because of what the game teaches, and the active excitement and positive feelings it creates, there are no real "losers" ... only winners ... in "All OF ME"
publishers: Developmental Concepts Inc., New Day Enterprises

name: The Young Athlete
description: A simple children's "racetrack" style game where the goal is to be the first to reach the finish. The path portrays various sports and gymnastic exercises (such as a vaulting horse, wrestling, pole vaulting). After meandering through the center of the board, the game path finishes on a running track that circles the entire playing board. The pawns are moved according to spinners marked 1-6. The playing board is printed inside the box bottom.

name: Davy Crockett
description:
Spin-and-move...

Submit a better description and contact Admin Skelebone for a GeekGold reward.

name: Transaktiona
description: A game about share, shareholders and the building of great trusts. Motor are 2 dices with 12 faces.

name: Jubilee
description: A trick-taking game with red and blue numbered tiles.

name: Payout!
description:
Payout! is a chance-heavy board game that Jonathan Leistiko made up back in August of 2003 as an alternate use for the 1,000 Blank White Questions game board. Payout! is a “race to the end” board game. You start the game with 20 cents. There are 6 different types of spaces on the board. Each type corresponds to a vault. If you land on a vault with coins in it, you get the coins that are in the vault. If you land on a space without coins in it, you have to put coins in the vault. When you get to the end of the board, you get to sit in a vault and take all of the coins that go in it. If you have the most money at the end of the game, you win.

Payout! is a game for three to six players, although you can play it with two if you really want to. Payout! uses two dice, loose change, pawns, and a custom board. You can download the custom board and read the rules at http://www.invisible-city.com/play/477. A four-player game takes about 30 minutes to play. Payout! is appropriate for ages 7 and up, and is a great way to reinforce basic counting and money skills with younger children.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Dadama
description:
The base idea of the game is to cross the rules and the draughtboard [checkerboard] with the use of dice instead of pieces. In fact to play Dadama you need 12 dice per player and a 8 x 8 draughtboard. (Dadama is a synthesis of the Italian words “dado” = dice and “dama” = draughts/checkers – translator’s note.)

This game appeared in issue 17 of GiocAreA Online (http://www.davincigames.it/giocarea_eng/17/index.htm).

Available at:
http://www.davincigames.it/giocarea_eng/17/dagiocare.htm

name: Kunterbunt gewürfelt
description:
The idea:

All players try together to build a pyramid in the middle of the board with their color dices.
The game provides a team game for children and one for adults.

It is a cooperative game where everyone works together to finish the pyramid.

name: Tricom
description: The idea: Each player has to try to transport six "Tops" with the help of his "basic" pawns into the opposite goal.

name: Run
description: The idea is to bring your own unbeaten pawns through the round course to their destination. At the same time you must try to catch as many of the opposition stones as possible with your catch stones.

name: Benjamin
description: The idea of BENJAMIN is to entertain a group of people of different age. Each player is forced to contribute something for the entertainment of the players. The winner is the one who fulfills these tasks the best.The players have to move around a board with fields with different meanings. These different jobs have to be fulfilled.

name: Babylon Challenge
description: Babylon Challenge is a set of anagrams. One determines a number of letters then one starts to pile up the polygons in the center of the desk. Each one seeks to form a word with the letters compared to its position of play. The six players have including each one 6 different pullings. As soon as a player finds a word, it advances on its track of score from 1 to 3 boxes according to the length of the word to find. When it falls on a Babylon box, it must answer a question in the shape of play of the vat under penalty of moving back.

name: TANKS you're welcome
description: Simple roll, move and shoot game. Eliminate their tanks or capture their flag to win. Box says Ages 10 and up, but most 5 or 6 yr olds will be able to play. 29 x 29 square play field with obstacles the block movement and shots.

name: The Desert Game
description: This game published by the Sage Publishing Company in 1979 is a Trivia type Game where players are tested on their knowledge of the desert environment. Questions about Why a pit viper is called a pit viper (the pit vipers have developed special organs of heat reception that help them to sense warm-blooded animals, an ability that is especially useful at night, when many of them hunt. These organs consist of pits, for which the group is named) and What creature impales its prey on cactus thorns? (Loggerhead Shrikes (they are a bird) often impale reptiles and small mammals after the prey becomes tired from being chased.)

name: Voter's Choice Election Game
description: From Are You Game advertisement. Make your run for President of the United States! Win the primaries and the popular votes and you're on your way to Pennsylvania Ave! This exciting strategy game takes you through choosing a platform, beginning a state election, to buying a campaign headquarters, and entering a debate. You'll have fun while learning with this great game. Who knows maybe you'll find a budding politico in your midst!

name: Rain
description:
The goal of the game is to race your raindrops down the window. The player with the most raindrops moved off the end of the window at the end of the game wins.

A modular board is used, with an extension being added for three player and a further extension for four player. Cards are drawn that dictate the number of raindrops added to the board and the movement of the raindrops. To progress down the board larger raindrops are required at each row. Any raindrop moved off the end of the board is collected. At the end of the game the number of individual drops collected is totaled and the player with the highest number of drops wins.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Hand Management, Modular Board

name: The Amusing Game of Yes or No
description:
"Yes or No"

A Laughable game for six or less players


Players sit around a table and distribute the question cards without looking at them. The answer slips are scattered face up in the center of the table.


Players then pick answers of the right kind (yes/no or time period) for each of the question cards in order without knowing what the questions are.

Once all answers are drawn, players read the question cards in order and the answers that every other player has picked for this question.


Paraphrased from the game instruction sheet.

name: Island Hoppers
description: Using a map based on actual places, this game relies on a card-drawing mechanic for players to determine their end-game strategy. The object is to build terminals and gates at airports, purchase a fleet of various aircraft, and hopefully, overcome pirates and mother nature to fly your routes and collect fares. The player who manages to keep his fleet intact and successfully fly his routes will have the advantage...until a hurricane hits his home base.
mechanics: Hand Management, Network and Route Building, Open Drafting

name: Presidentinvaalipeli
description:
The goal of the game is to get your candidate to be the president of Finland. In the game there are three election rounds. The first round is a competition between the candidates of a election coalition, who gets to be the candidate for the next round. On the next round the two main candidates are chosen. On the third round it is determined who wins "the chair of the president"( Pressan pallin, in Finnish).

The game was produced on the election year of 1984 and lends a great deal of basic mechanics from Pacheesi.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Buy A Vacation
description: Here is where you try and earn enough to buy a vacation; doesn't sound that exciting and while it seems to have some inspiration from Monopoly - the theme at least makes it different. It does not have an ability to trade, so there will be less player interaction.

name: Escape from Lovecrypt's Tomb?
description: From the author, Escape from Lovecrypt's Tomb is a maze/treasure hunt game for one or two players. It requires a standard deck of cards (not provided), a couple of pieces to represent the player or players, and about 50 tokens (pennies, pente' stones, candy corn, petrified squirrel droppings, whatever...). The package contains rules and two variant game boards.

name: Space Shuttle Adventure
description:
Endorsed by the U.S. Space Academy:

Imagine the thrill of the countdown beginning - All systems are go. The Lift-Off begins and you're in orbit. - The adventure of going into space. The thrill now comes alive with space shuttle adventure....A game endorsed by the U.S. Space Academy that is not only an adventure but a learning experience for young and old.

Discover the adventure, the obstacles the astronauts must overcome...from the challenge of pre-launch and the thrill of lift-off to the uncertainties of orbit and the celebration of re-entry. You'll learn the terms and feel of the adventure as if you were a part of the great space program.

name: Chinese Jackstraws
description: Two players race to build a tower using chopsticks. Twelve wooden cylinders (that the game calls "suey") start in a bowl build into the box insert. Players race to pick up the cylinders with their chopsticks and stack them upon their own wooden base.

name: Mr. Pokerface
description:
Content:
45 cards, 2 dice

The funny-smart table tennis-card game
Whether you get a smash on you forehand or a topspin at your backhand, a proper "Mr. Pokerface knows an answer to the net balls and edge balls. That no one watches what good capacities are inside him he plays under cover sometimes, and no tremor in his face says if he speaks the truth.

name: 3/4Takt
description:
The game is packed in a can.
Content:
57 stones in different colors,
9 cards with 4 rings at it

In the basic game with 2 players one gets 18 red, the other 18 green stones.
The cards have to be laid in a square.

Alternately each player sets a stone onto a ring of one of the square cards. The valuation starts after 3 stones:
One point for 4 stones on one card, or 4 stones in 4 rings side by side, a.s.o

When all stones are laid, the game is over.

There are also 4 cooperative versions.

name: Tit Tat Toe: Marble Game
description:
This is a vintage Parker Brothers table game that combines pinball or pachinko with Tic Tac Toe. Judging by the art deco/American "streamline" design, the best guess would be that it dates from the mid-1930s to early 1940s.

The playing field consists of a Tic Tac Toe grid with holes in each square surrounded with wooden pegs inserted at various points to serve as bumpers. Players alternate hitting a metal lever to launch marbles up a chute and onto the playing field in an attempt to get their marbles to settle into the squares. As with Tic Tac Toe, the winner is the first to get 3 marbles settled in a row.

name: Safari Dice: Africa's Big Game
description:
A simple dice game similar to Yahtzee. The player rolls five dice, which depict 5 different animals (giraffe, buffalo, rhino, lion and elephant) and a poacher. There is a scoresheet where you attempt to collect various sets (e.g. 3 giraffes, or 5 different animals), you get a varying number of points based on the difficulty of the set you are trying to collect. The poacher causes a player to lose 5 points for each poacher revealed. If you roll 5 poachers all your animals are dead and you are out of the game!

The game is complete after 15 turns. The player with the highest point tally wins.

name: The Little Mermaid Happily Ever After Card Game
description: A card game where you must help Ariel kiss her Prince before sunset so she can become human and live happily ever after.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Fantasy, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based

name: V Invasión Extraterrestre
description:
Galaxy battle game, with a version based on the TV Series "V".

Board with 77 squares with different numbers written. The game brings 10 yellow cards and 10 green (each color represents one side). In the center of the board have 2 areas of "Red Dust" covering 6 squares each. In 2 of the 4 ends of the board have squares representing 4 cities or countries. Each placer must distribute each counter in the board, both sides are Visitor (no one represent the Resistance), and each card represents a weapon or vehicle with different powers.

The game is a mix of chess and chequers since the counters can be moved in a certain way. To destroy a counter, this has to be less than or equal power of the attacker. The game ends when one can infiltrate any of its ships within the area of cities or countries that it is protecting his opponent.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction

name: Arabian Nights Flying Carpet Game
description: A vintage game in which you have to rotate a clock to know where to go on a board, which looks like a snakes and ladders board. Actions that have to be taken, are related to the stories of 1001 Nights.

name: Postal Delivery Boys
description: A game in the style of The Game of District Messenger Boy. Players start off as postal delivery boys and race to be the first player to reach the center square and become president of the company. Spin and move - but try to avoid the penalty squares which will slow your progress.

name: Roll A Word
description:
Roll A Word is a small portable word game where seven game dice are set into a square plastic frame that allows them to rotate freely. The frame is rolled between the hands and then set down for play. The center die has a different category on each side, and the six other dice have various letters. Players race to come up with six words that suit the category starting with each of the six letters and write them on their score sheet. A point is scored for each word that has not been duplicated by another player.

The game includes two extra category dice for variety.

name: The Quadrasonic Defender
description: Roll and move type game with Safety Education theme. Players start at school and work their way getting home. There are 3 different levels of basic education questions, and then there are a series of safety questions, from "Do you know your area code and phone number?" to "If there is a pot in the kitchen why shouldn't you touch it?" Each question card comes with an answer, but the rules highly encourage customizing the game to meet your needs/situation. The game also comes with numerous blank cards to write your own questions/answer. According to the rules, if you don't like the question/answer to a card, either change it or discard it. Although the first one to make it "Home" is a winner, the rules specifically state the everyone is a winner since the knowledge and safety tips they've learned will be with them forever!

name: Black Water Navies
description:
From the Rulebook

BLACK WATER NAVIES.

Designed by a naval officer to cover all aspects of sailing into combat: various types of ships, 3D combat, ECM/ECCM, cloak units, fighters, landing on planets, etc.
816 different ship classes are included, each can be modified to suit the player’s personal taste. The size of the battle can range from one ship each to what ever the players can control.

Black Water Navies is designed to allow you to use figures from any old games.

Available as download.

name: The Chucklers Game
description: This game has a touch of Black Americana in it. The game was produced by the Rosebud Art Company, N.Y. The box has the same features as the game board -- clowns with their mouth's open. The game includes a spinning top that you twirl to send balls into the open mouths of the "chuckler's". The game came with a spinner, a board and eight wooden balls.

name: Peter Pan Viagem à Terra do Nunca
description: In this Peter Pan based game the players must travel through Neverland and take a picture of each site visited. After accomplishing that, the player should go back on the trail with their pictures. The first player to do so is the winner!

name: Promiseland
description:
In Promiseland players are a wandering tribal champion, exploring the land looking for a new homeland for their tribe. The game is played with a standard deck of cards, a marker for each tribal champion, a marker for each tribe, a bunch of territory markers and three six sided dice. A grid of face down cards are laid out before the players. The players roll for their number of allowed actions each turn, moving their champion on the cards, looking at face down cards and sometimes taking them into their hands. Cards may be used to duel other champions or collected to build a promiseland for the tribe. Face cards may also be used for special actions, like taking an action in the middle of another players turn. Once a player has collected enough cards for a promiseland, they must cross the board to get their tribe and bring them to the promiseland. The first to accomplish this wins.

Itesser Ink sells only a rulebook, all other pieces must be provided by the purchaser.

name: Golf Fore Juniors Game
description: From the rules: May be played by 1 to 4 players. Object of the game for one player is to score less than 72 and with more than one player the lowest score wins. Each player chooses a colored marker and places it at No. 1 tee. Shuffle cards well and place face down. In turn, Players turn over the top card and check with the proper sequence of their shot on the card, moving the amount of yardage indicated. With three or four players shuffle the cards after every hole and with one or two players shuffle after every second hole.
publishers: Tee Pee Toys, Jessup Paper Box Co.

name: Divine Nuke Wrath
description:
A quick co-op / competitive game of anarchy and destruction for 3 to 4 demigods.

You need:

* A Divine Nuke Wrath board. (provided on the website)
* A Heaven board. (provided on the website)
* A Limbo board (with two regions: Step 1, and Step 2). (provided on the website)
* An Underworld board (with two regions: Styx and Underworld) (provided on the website)
* A homogeneous pool of neutral people pawns (64). (provided on the website)
* 4 homogeneous pools of follower pawns (50) with one hero token each, each pool distinct from the other. (provided on the website)
* A deck of Divine Action cards for each player. (provided on the website)
* A Divine Wrath chart. (provided on the website)
* A Disaster chart. (provided on the website)
* A divine favor totem.
* A bowl or other opaque container.

The end of days draws near. The ruler of the Pantheon will be whomever has the most devout followers in Heaven. You’d like it to be you. Be careful, though! The God of the Underworld has always resented his (or her) position, and may try to subvert our followers to meet his own ends.

From the designer:

"I hosted the “Let’s Make a Game” panel at ProtoCon 9 (http://www.protocon.com/) for the second year in a row this year. Last year’s panel resulted in Cetacean Ascension Moonbase 8 (http://www.boardgamegeek.com/game/25952). This year’s brainstorming session started with the following premises:

"Screw other players over, co-operative play, religion theme, quick pace, explosions, diceless, guns, apocalypse.

"...and this is the game that came of it."

Available at:
http://www.invisible-city.com/play/465/divine-nuke-wrath

name: Juchajdo!
description:
From publishers website:

Low budget original board game for 2 – 8 players, packaged in the foil as a magazine. In role of the most well-known gentlemen rogue and very cheer and wanton ladies a player try to collect the points of their realized desires. The only strategy and erotic game all over the world.

Juchajdo! is a humorous Czech adult-themed game illustrated by one of best Czech illustrators Kaja Saudek. You'll need two sets to play with 8 players, one is enough for 4 of them.

Players draw cards with male and female characters and play them on a square grid. The deck also contains some special cards, that can be used when placing these characters or when doing various actions.

Once you have some character(s) in game, you can move them. All characters have some preferences, when it comes to "partnership" and you try to "pair" your characters with those, that are matching these preferences (getting them to the same square).

Once you "pair" one of your characters with one of opposite gender, the owners of both score points by the preferences of their character and "qualities" of the second one. Unless of them play some special card, both of them are removed from game thereafter.

Having a very nice price for such a game, it is a cheap print on waxed paper, cut-before-play, is full-colour, and especially if laminated can remain for a long time.

name: Defiance and Domain
description:
An abstract strategy game pitting the fiery Rebels against the ever present Imperium.

Player one takes on the role of the defiant Rebels, trying to set up a network of 'Cells' throughout the Imperial held territories, or sectors, and establish stable bases for future attacks.

Player two takes on the role of the Imperium. The established power. Defending it's domain against any threat, from within or without.

An entry into the About.com: 2002 Unequal Forces Game Design Competition

name: Fire Fighters
description: As described in a vintage Milton Bradley catalog: "This game board represents a burning building, and the players are firemen endeavoring to reach the child in an upper window, the first one doing so winning the game. The label [i.e. cover art] shows a modern steamer racing to a fire."

name: "Inside" Base Ball
description:
A tin lithograph board game displaying a baseball diamond with a large metal spinner in the center. The approximately 13x13" board is in the form of a tray, with the spectators and outfield fence (as well as the instructions) printed on the inside edges of the tray. The game includes 18 metal discs (3/4") naming players from the 1911 World Series teams, the New York Giants and Philadelphia Athletics. The discs are used to track the competitors at bat and on base.

The players play the game by following the general rules of baseball and spinning the four-armed spinner to generate results which are specified by results boxes of varying sizes arrayed in a circle around the spinner. According to the publisher, "the percentages of plays spaced on the board have been calculated from the actual number of balls pitched, hits, put-outs, etc., from hundreds of games played by these leagues."

The game board has six metal arrows mounted to it which are used to track the inning, outs, balls, strikes, and the score for each team.

name: Base Ball
description:
This boxed card game comes in a 5 3/8" x 3 7/8" box containing the rulebook and 94 cards. The game may have also included paper scoring sheets.

The card deck consists of 40 batter cards and 54 fielder cards. The batter cards describe results of each pitch, such as "Ball Batted to Left field", "Strike Called", "Foul Ball" , etc. The fielder cards describe the outcome of a play, with results such as "Fielder gets ball on fly in deep field. Batter is out. Base runners advance one base after ball is caught", "First Baseman makes a fine pickup of bad throw from shortstop. Batter out. Base runners advance one base", "Pitcher stops hard drive but loses sight of the ball a moment. Batter safe at first. No advance on bases", etc.

name: Downtown
description:
In Downtown, you and your opponent are real-estate tycoons bidding for property in the city’s bustling, prosperous business district. From a standard deck of cards, one player takes the red cards and the other the black cards. Most cards represent checks used to invest in intersections; when a city block is surrounded, whichever player has invested the most in the surrounding intersections claims ownership in it. Court cards have special effects.

At the end of the game bonuses are awarded for buildings adjacent to public buildings and the park, buildings in specific patterns, having multiple buildings from a set, and buildings adjacent to a bonus intersection determined during the game.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Pattern Building, Set Collection, Square Grid

name: Operation: just (be)cause
description: This is a small "envelope" game, that is obviously tongue-in-cheek. According to the back cover, the game is "a fun and exciting game for 2 players as the U.S. tries to capture Gen. Manuel Noriega, infamous drug dealer and dictator. Heck, even George is here to help!" This begs two questions. Which George (probably the first) and, can't we just go to a prison in Florida?

name: Executive Suite
description:
The object of the game is to build chains of companies and in doing that earn points for your Partnership. Multiple chains can be started for each partnership, and they can be "bankrupted" by opposing players.

Note: Two player games require only one deck, while four players require 3 decks.

name: Island Run: Put Your Feet in the Sand
description:
"Based on the idea of traveling in the Caribbean, this game is targeted to families who might be planning to visit the area, and to cruise ships, hotels, resorts and travel agents looking for a unique item for promotional giveaways. Dubbed 'The game that brings ‘em back!' Island Run is intended to entertain families and encourage first time or repeat visits to the Caribbean tropics."

"With colorful seashells serving as engaging game pieces, the board shows game spaces weaving among the islands of the Caribbean."

Contents include: playing cards, color-coded “sand dollar” money, instructions (printed on parchment with the feel of a treasure map) and a die for determining moves.

For more information about Ink Inc., visit www.planetink.com

name: Give & Take
description:
The designer's description:

Give & Take is designed for elementary-age students, grades 3 and higher, who are developing their sense of numbers. In the earlier grades, it can be used to teach operations and basic reasoning skills. In grades five and higher it can be used to reinforce quick recall of basic math facts and also to foster advanced reasoning skills.

The game is played on a 10x10 square grid. Each player has 50 colored chips. Three standard dice are required for play. The object of the game is to be the first to play all of one's 50 chips and to cover the four center squares of the gameboard.

http://eprentice.sdsu.edu/F03670/giveandtake/

name: Neutral
description:
From a copy of the rules put out by Gamesarchives.

Neutral by V.E. MORRILL CO, was produced in 1914. It is a game consistent with current history. The striking difference between Neutral and other games in which tricks and trumps figure a part of, consists of the suit of Neutral Cards representing the United States, played under certain restrictions as described in the rules which are supreme over trumps and all other cards.

The game comes with 48 cards divided into 8 suits. 40 cards represent the 5 principle warring countries; Great Britain, France, Germany, Russia and Austria. The cards of the warring nations are termed "Belligerents". Each set of Belligerent cards consist of The Ruler(value 8), General (7), Colonel (6), Major(5), Captain(4), Lieutenant(3), Sergent(2), and Corporal(1).

The United States represented by 8 cards plays the role of Neutral and Peacemaker to all of the warring nations.. Any trick won by the United States is neutralized and theoretically removed from the conflict.

The game is played like most other trump games with players bidding to be able to establish trumps and then win a certain number of tricks. The established trumps win tricks if played on tricks where you have none of the lead suit but Neutral Trumps beat established trumps if they are played.

If you succeed with your bid you score points, if you fail you score nothing. Each Neutral trick won scores 2 points + 1 point if the ruler card is included in the traick (The US ruler card is President Wilson). Ruler cards won in "Belligerent tricks scores nothing. Game consists of first to score 50 points wins.

name: Color Guard
description:
Color Guard is a tile placing game that is played on a 6x6 board. All 36 spaces are connected with lines of different values.

There are 42 tiles as playing pieces. They all have the same back, but the front shows one of 6 different colors.

Object of the game is to achieve the most points, which are collected from the connecting lines.
Each turn, a player can place up to 3 tiles on the board and refills his hand to 3 tiles again. The tile placement starts in the center of the board and develops to the edges, where the most points can be collected.

There are 4 tile placement rules, which make this game very playable. But what makes this game brilliant is the fact, that it includes 6 tiles more than needed (42 tiles for a 36 space board!). Thus, hoarding tiles of a single color to make secure points in the edges is not a good winning strategy.


Color Guard, Stronghold, Tower 6, and Where To? are 4 games designed by Ronald Corn in the 1980s that never found a publisher. They all had interesting mechanics and/or inventive victory conditions - but they had no theme! Since they were not pure abstract games (they used dice, cards, or tiles as random elements), this lack of a good theme could have been the main reason why they were never published.

name: Stronghold
description:
Stronghold is played on a board showing a network of 25 spaces. Each player has 8, 10, or 14 playing pieces, depending on if 2, 3, or 4 people are playing.

Object of the game is to be the first player to have all their playing pieces on the board.

When a playing piece is placed on the board, its strength is determined by the throw of a die, but the initial strength can well be increased during the game.

Attacks are quite normal in this game and the chances for success depend on the strength of the 2 opponents as well as on the distance between the 2. The playing pieces that loose a fight are returned to its owner, who must enter them on the board again to win the game.


Color Guard, Stronghold, Tower 6, and Where To? are 4 games designed by Ronald Corn in the 1980s that never found a publisher. They all had interesting mechanics and/or inventive victory conditions - but they had no theme! Since they were not pure abstract games (they used dice, cards, or tiles as random elements), this lack of a good theme could have been the main reason why they were never published.

name: Tower 6
description:
Tower 6 is played on a board showing 51 hexes. 24 of them are colored with 4 different colors and they constitute the four regions, where new playing pieces enter the board.

Equipment:
1 normal 6-sided die
1 colored die (4 sides with 4 different colors, 2 sides wild)
10-12 stackable playing pieces (depending on the number of players)

Object of the game is to be the first player, who can build a tower of 6 own pieces.

The game starts with an empty board. During a turn, a player can enter a playing piece on the board, move a piece that's already there or attack an opposing piece (or tower).

Entering the board is very critical in this game. The location, where a playing piece can enter, is determined by the throw of both dice, but that space should be empty - or you either loose one of your own pieces/towers or your turn.

Therefore moving away from such entering spaces is important, but entering lots of new pieces or attacking opposing pieces is what leads to victory!

Movement is determined by a die roll, but the die is only needed to fix the direction, where a piece can move.
And attacks are even handled without using any die: they are simply decided by the height of the 2 involved towers.


Color Guard, Stronghold, Tower 6, and Where To? are 4 games designed by Ronald Corn in the 1980s that never found a publisher. They all had interesting mechanics and/or inventive victory conditions - but they had no theme! Since they were not pure abstract games (they used dice, cards, or tiles as random elements), this lack of a good theme could have been the main reason why they were never published.

name: Where To?
description:
Where To? is played on a small board with only 29 spaces. On each side of the board is one circular space in one of 4 different colors.

Equipment:
1 playing piece (with arrow or face)
1 special die (showing 5x straight and 1x curved arrow)
40 cards in 4 colors

Object of the game:
The players attempt to score the most points with the cards that remain in their hands at the end of the game. The problem is, that only cards from a single color count, but this color is not known until the end of the game!

Each turn, a player rolls the die to determine if the single playing piece is moved in the direction, where it is pointing, or if it can be rotated.

The game ends, when the playing piece moves on one of the 4 colored circles. The players who earns the most points with the cards of that color wins the game.

These rules alone would lead to a very short game, because the playing piece could only be rotated in 1 of 6 dice rolls and it would reach a colored circle very fast.

Therefore, there is another possibility to rotate the playing piece: you can sacrifice some cards to do that.

Needless to say, that you mostly choose the cards of the wrong color to sacrifice...


Color Guard, Stronghold, Tower 6, and Where To? are 4 games designed by Ronald Corn in the 1980s that never found a publisher. They all had interesting mechanics and/or inventive victory conditions - but they had no theme! Since they were not pure abstract games (they used dice, cards, or tiles as random elements), this lack of a good theme could have been the main reason why they were never published.

name: Citrusopoly
description:
Citruspoly is a monopoly style game with a Citrus County, Florida travel theme. Features a colorful board showing historical views of the city. The cards represent various business locations and tourist attractions.

Sponsored by the Citrus County Historical Society

Pride Distributors -- First Edition (c)1997

name: Cootie House
description: This is basically a combination of Cootie and Candy Land. Up to 8 players spin a spinner to build up a cootie in their off-board "cootie nest". Once the cootie is complete, the players use the spinner to move around the board according to the color spun. After one lap around the board, they move toward the cootie house in the center. The first cootie there wins.

name: Iron Mountain Property Trading game
description:
Iron Mountain Property Trading game is a monopoly style game with an Upper Peninsula of Michigan theme. Features a colorful board with pictures of towns like Iron Mountain, Norway, and Kingsford. The cards represent various business locations and tourist attractions.

KATY Consultants

name: Bury Your Faults
description:
Bury Your Faults is a Christian board game. Players move around a cemetery game board picking up faults (impatience, foul language, selfishness, etc.) as they move. They must bury these faults in the appropriate location.

Includes the cemetery board, 84 tombstones, 4 saint markers, 2 dice, and instructions.

Gospel Games, Inc. (c)1981
mechanics: Pick-up and Deliver, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Sixe-Ace
description: The name R.C. Bell uses for an antique French game described in his book Board and Table Games from Many Civilizations. The game is played by two to five players using the pieces from a backgammon set. Each player places six checkers in the player's portion of the board, with the center of the board representing a "pool" area that is empty at the start. Pieces are captured from the groups of the other players, or moved to the central pool, or taken from the pool, based on the roll of two six-sided dice. To win, a player must clear all the checkers from his portion of the board and then roll a 6. Bell also reports on a drinking game variant.

name: Exaltation
description: Exaltation is an LDS trivia game in which players race on a board that represents various stages of life and death in order to reach exaltation the first. Players ask each other trivia questions in order to progress. Players move forward five spaces for answering a question correctly and move forward three spaces for stumping another player with a question s/he doesn't know the answer to.

name: Frankenstein
description:
From the publisher: Frankenstein is a Beginner Engle Matrix Game about Mary Shelly's classic tale. The board comes complete with art from the early 19th Century. The game plays in half an hour and is highly replayable. While it is based on the classic text players can take the game in whatever direction they like. Pick your favorite Frank movie and make it come alive!

The game is available in a hard copy laminated version and a PDF version.
categories: Fantasy, Horror, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based

name: All-tes-teg-enuk
description:
A game that was played by the Passamaquoddy Indians of the northeastern United States.

The components include a shallow wooden bowl (about 12 inches across and 2 inches deep), 6 plum stones (plain on one side and carved and colored on the other), forty-eight small sticks approximately 6 inches long, 4 longer sticks, and 1 longer stick which is notched.

The plum stones are placed in the dish which is banged on a blanket on the ground causing the stones to jump. The resulting combination of face up and face down stones controls how many sticks the player may take from the central pile or from the other player. The goal of the game is to win all of the sticks from the other player.

This game is similar to Hubbub.

name: The Mummy's Message
description:
From the publisher:

Besides exposing the players to interesting and fascinating facts about ancient Egyptian culture, the Mummy's Message classroom simulation game allows each of the players to experience the thrills, frustrations, and horrible dangers as they become archeologists traveling through the interior of a pyramid. The 50 Problem Cards and the possible impact that facing these dangers have on the expeditionary teams’ successful progress through the pyramid, took three years of research alone. As the players will discover, archeological expeditions into pyramids encountered many physical and emotional challenges as the result of the sadistic mind of the pyramid builder, who incorporated deadly traps in order to frustrate and confuse grave robbers.

Three groups are created, each with two competing archeological teams (approximately five players per team). The teams progress through the pyramid by correctly answering Question Cards, selecting a Passage Progress Card and collecting Hieroglyphic Cards, each with a hieroglyphic symbol and the translation of that symbol. Although most of the symbols were created to resemble actual hieroglyphics, the simulated experiences encountered as the players collect, piece together, and correctly translate a real message from a hieroglyphic tablet, is authentic.

The goal of the two competing archeological teams is to travel to each of the three chambers; the Pharaoh’s Burial Chamber, the Queen’s Burial Chamber and the Great Hall. As each chamber is entered, a piece or several pieces of a Hieroglyphic Tablet is/are discovered. Using the Hieroglyphic Cards accumulated, the team that can correctly piece together and translate the Mummy's Message wins the simulation game.

name: Ram
description:
The object of the game is to build and complete herds of sheep, thus gaining points for you partnership (or individuals if playing so). The point values are determined by the composition of the herds. While points are earned for all herds, completed herds earn more points than non-completed herds.
There are also rules for two players.

name: Alice in Wonderland: A Card Game
description:
This game is based on Alice in Wonderland, containing the following cards:

3 Caterpillar, 4 Duchess, 4 White Rabbit, 4 Executioner, 4 Gardener, 5 Knave of Hearts, 4 Cheshire cat, 5 Alice, 4 Queen of Hearts, 6 Mad Hatter, 4 King of Hearts, and 5 March Hares

name: Bomb Tokyo!
description:
This is a unique combination of dexterity and wargame. You drop clay 'bombs' through holes in the provided airplanes and hope they stick to the target locations on the board. Earn points for completing the bombing missions during World War II.

Poph-Itt TOASTED WHIFFS cereal premium introduced the game "Bomb Tokyo" which was made by the Broughton Specialty Co. in Minneapolis, Minnesota in 1942. It was named "Game of the Year" in 1942. The game was distributed by the Poph-Itt Cereal Company of Minneapolis as a mail-away premium. It was shipped rolled in a solid cardboard tube. The playing field measures about 16" by 22" with a full-color artwork layout of city of Tokyo and its harbor. The board illustrates factories, the emperor's palace, residential areas, and ships.

The object of the game is to drop round bombs made from modeling clay (which was not included) on different areas of Tokyo and the ships in the harbor to score various points. Game includes 4 thin card stock airplanes that come apart (fuselage and wings), each with a "sighting hole" and place to drop your clay bombs. It includes paper playing pieces marked "destroyed" that are placed on the areas that have been destroyed by your bombs.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Wargame, World War II

name: Wyntre Golf
description: This golf game comes in a blue box. There is a wheel and a green table in the center of the board and several tracks go up the side of the table, around the wheel, and then back down the other side of the table. Graphics of golfers surround the functional parts of the board.

name: The Green Acres Game
description: This is a Green Acres themed roll-and-move game, with the track going around the outside of the board like Monopoly. The object of the game is to be the first player to buy enough equipment to start running your farm.
categories: Economic, Farming, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Pentana
description:
This game works like Tic-Tac-Toe combined with playing pieces that look like checkers, but move like a king in chess. It is played on a 4x4 grid, with each player setting up their pieces in a row on opposite sides. On each turn, a player moves their piece one space orthogonally or diagonally. The object is to get 4 in a row orthogonally or diagonally on any row other than your starting row OR to get all your pieces placed in each corner.

The game has some really attractive bakelight pieces.

name: Golden Eagle Anagrams
description: This old McLoughlin game features an eagle on the cover holding a large medallion. The contents are basically cardboard scrabble tiles (minus the numbers), used to work out anagrams.

name: All-Time Hockey
description: A tactical hockey simulation featuring some of the best teams in the history of the NHL - the 1967 Toronto Maple Leafs, the 1976 Montreal Canadiens, the 1985 Edmonton Oilers, and the 1989 Calgary Flames.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Simulation

name: Feast of Warring States Period
description:
'Feast of Warring States Period' is a battle class game of "Battle of Sekigahara(Keityo5/A.D.1600)" that
might be the most famous fight in the history of Japan.

The game includes 1Map(4 A3 size),460 uncut counters.

20 turn all,It corresponds 1 turn : at 25 minutes.
1 hex : 150 - 200m

The Feast of Warring States Period is dipicted with a different system with the current civil wars battle class game.

The correction to the combat value changes by length of the fire range of the combat unit. The morale rule　plays an important role in the attack and the defense.The Command Power Movement rule reproduces the variable of the movement.

"Betrayal" is an important element of Sekigahara.In this game, victory or defeat is not decided by "Betrayal" check once.In a word, the victory condition is changed depending on the number colored to the ally and the number of turns.

name: B-B Ball Players Baseball Game
description:
This is a dice game, with a baseball theme, from the 1950s, which uses two special dice.

From the card that comes with the game:
"B-B Ball Players Baseball Game - Everything Real but the Umpire. 9 innings - 9 minutes. Anywhere. Anytime. 2 to 18 players. Nu-process Parlor Dice Game."

The rules are stated in a few lines:
"Same as baseball.
Batters cast dice in turn until a play is made.
A pair (2 of a kind) is a play.
No pair is a strike.
Double play when 3 OUTS are shown."

name: Straights
description:
The players try to get 100 points by playing Straights.

A Straight can be open (vulnerable to special cards but more valuable) or closed (immune to specials cards but only worth the half of an open Straight).

Cards can be used to building Straight or for special actions (there is reminder text on the cards). There is a lot of interaction between the players because you have a lot of possibilities to mess with the other players and their Straights.

Components
2-4 Players need 2 Sets of Cards (110 cards) and every player needs a die as action buffer.

If you want to play with more than 4 players you need additional sets of cards.
mechanics: Action Points, Hand Management, Set Collection

name: The Heights
description:
This is a 3-D pyramid game where you move pieces up and down the pyramid. It actually ships with three games in the rules that utilize the common movement mechanism of moving around the pyramid (and/or jumping like checkers).

Kaptor - capture all of your opponents pieces

The Crown - have 5 of your pieces fill the top five holes at the top of the pyramid

The Voyage - fill the six bottom slots on the opposite side of the board where your opponent started

name: Dr. Arnvie's Grand Rounds
description:
Dr. Arnvie's[tm] Grand Rounds[tm] is a medical-themed trivia game produced by The Vincent Company, Inc. [Gledale, WI].

While the game follows the basic "Trivial Pursuit" approach to game play, every element is based on a medical theme. Even the rule sheet is presented as a "Prescription Form," which notes Refill: PRN (As needed for fun).

Per the rules: "Each player acts as a resident physician. (A resident physician is a doctor who is undergoing specialty training following medical school.)

At the start of the game, each player is given 10 patient cards [which] represent the patients that the player must try to discharge during the course of the game. One patient is discharged each time a question is answered correctly."

The first player to discharge all his/her patients wins.

As per the Trivial Pursuit model, there are color-coded spaces on the board that correspond to question categories. The 4 categories are:
Green-History and Personalities
Yellow-General Medicine
Red-Anatomy & Surgery; Public Health; Preventative Medicine
Blue-Nutrition & Exercise.

In addition, other spaces offer exceptions to the color code system and present players with alternative Bonus and Risk cards that can modify their position on the board or choice of question categories.

The rules conclude with a directive [keeping with the prescription pad theme] for "NO GENERIC SUBSTITUTIONS" and "Keep within reach of inquisitive teenagers & adults."

This is followed with a fairly substantial disclaimer that though this game is based on reputable sources, one should turn to Dr. Arnvie for advice on medical treatment or conditions but should, instead, consult your regular medical provider.

name: Owzthat! Cricket: The Classic Cricket Game.
description:
Roll the classic " Owzthat " dice to bat. Roll for runs and answer questions to score. More runs mean harder questions.
Roll an " Owzthat " and your opponent has the chance to get you out. Keep tally on the score board provided.
This game has all the fun and excitement of the classic " Owzthat " game with the added ingredient of questions.

name: Battlefinder!
description:
Battlefinder! is a campaign generation supplement for use with the various miniatures rules released by The Perfect Captain. It is also suitable for use as a campaign generator for other gaming systems set in Western Europe, for the period 1000 to 1700 A.D.

"It is in essence a modular campaign board that can be used in thousands of configurations. You can use this in conjunction with our miniature rules sets (Ironbow, Spanish Fury, Actions! and Spanish Fury, Battle! or Pistolado!) or with any other set you might own (for those of you who dare to touch a non-Perfect Captain product…you know who you are!). This set can be used in a variety of ways, some of which I’m sure you’ll develop yourselves - and if you do develop something, don’t forget to write it up for our Yahoo group, and share it with us all."

"The cards included with this campaign generator can be used to simulate most areas of Western Europe from the Pyrenees to the edge of the Eurasian Steppes, and from the Alps to Scandanavia."

The Battlefinder! components include a rulebook, a mapsheet, terrain cards and a set of counters.

Like all games from The Perfect Captain, Battlefinder is available for free download to print and play. (See Web Links.)
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Medieval, Miniatures, Renaissance, Wargame

name: Cast for a Bite
description:
Contents

390 Fish Cards
130 Bait Cards
60 Snag Cards
2 Spot Dice
1 Fish Size Dice
Electronic Count Down Timer (Batteries supplied)
6 Coloured Playing Pieces
Board
Rules


From the back of the box:

"Cast for a Bite combines all the anticipation, skill and luck of competitive fishing, allowing players to experience the excitement and sense of achievement when a big fish is caught.

Players travel around the river and lake on the board collecting beautifully illustrated fish and bait cards, whilst keeping an eye on the clock and trying to avoid the snag cards, never knowing if the next catch will help win the game or the next snag will set them back."

name: Larkspur
description: Larkspur is an educational card game which aims to teach children how to identify and name flowers and flower families. It comprises a pack of 60 cards, organized into 12 sets of 5 cards, with the first card in each set depicting a garden flower and the other 4 cards depicting related field flowers. The rulebook contains instructions on how to play three different games with the cards, all of which involve the collection of complete sets of cards via a number of routes.

name: My Alphabet Card Game
description:
A game for children to help them learn their letters and words. Per the back of the box...

"There are lots of games to play with these colorful alphabet cards. You can play a competitive matching game, where the winner finds the most sets of cards or a cooperative Memory game.

You can also:
*Identify the letters and name the objects in the pictures
*Match the lower and upper case letters
*Put the cards in alphabetical order
*Spell simple words
*There are lots of possibilities!

All the while, children learn the alphabet and build their vocabulary.

Great to take with you wherever you go, the games play quickly, are easy to learn and fun to share!"
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Word Game

name: Big Apple
description:
In this game, players manage stores in New York City. Stores are established in spaces on the apple-shaped board, and players manage their inventory by holding onto cards representing goods. These cards are purchased from warehouse spaces and frequently change hands since a player is obliged to purchase a card whenever he or she lands on an opponent's store. The maximum price which may be charged for an item depends on the number of floors in a store, so players are constantly expanding their outlets.

The game deals with more than just cash -- every player gets a balance sheet used for tracking bank loans and credit with other players. Credit limits are determined at the start of the game and affect the length of the game -- a $300 limit is recommended for an hour-long game, while $500 can last two hours or more. As players reach their credit limits and are unable to pay back their creditors, they go bankrupt and drop out of the game.

In addition to the normal flow of buying and selling, the game features board spaces and cards that spice up gameplay with random events. There are also some special transportation spaces (taxis and subways) which allow players a little more control over their movement to add variety to the normal rolling and moving.

Big Apple obviously draws a lot of inspiration from Monopoly, but it's not just a retheming -- there are enough differences to make it distinct from its more famous predecessor.

name: Gnemo
description: Gnemo is a card game based on (and featuring) the illustration work of artist Tom Kidd. The thematic material for the game is from the imaginary world developed in Kidd's Gnemo series of paintings.
categories: Card Game, Exploration, Fantasy, Science Fiction

name: Cinquo
description: An abstract strategy game played on a 7x7 grid. The object of the game is to be the first to visit each corner and the center space, ending on the player's starting corner. However, players must play a hand of cards to determine which player gets to move. Players are dealt three cards and have to win a trick to move one of their pieces. The cards are marked like dominoes, with 1 to 6 spots, and each number comes in three different colors - red, black, and white.

name: Economy
description:
"By moving to the right locations you get inventions, factories and shops. With these properties you can collect points and become winner with the most points! A shop is worth 1 point, a factory 2 points and an invention 3 points (most for the invention, because without a new invention there are no new factories and shops!) You get most if you have an invention, factory and shop of the same sector. But be careful - there is keen competition!"

Components: 8x8 game board, 36 location cards, 36 property cards, 6 pieces, die.

http://www.printgames.net/english/detail_e/economy.htm

name: High Noon
description:
The object of the game is to eliminate all opposing pieces.

Each player has six movement points to divide among a set of four pieces. Two pieces from each set move clockwise and the other two move counter clockwise.

Pieces landing on the same square duel. In order to win the duel, the player challenged to a duel must correctly guess whether an odd or even number of fingers will be simultaneously held up by both players.

http://www.printgames.net/english/detail_e/high.htm

name: Checkpoints
description: The players race across a 6x6 grid seeking to be the first to visit all four corners, with the caveat that a player's starting corner cannot be the first corner visited by the player. The spaces on the board are covered by numbered cards. Dice are rolled for movement. The player can only move onto squares showing the same number as was rolled on a die.

name: Right-Left
description:
An abstract strategy game played on a 7x7 grid. Four starting spaces are marked in the four player colors. The object of the game is to visit each of the four colored spaces on the board, ending with the space of your own color. Movement is controlled by a pair of dice, one dictating which direction the piece must turn during the move, and the other setting the distance of the move.

http://www.printgames.net/english/detail_e/rile.htm

name: Witches and Wizards
description:
Players take turns laying down cards marked with different animals, seeking to "enchant" a previously played card. The winner of each round is the player who was last able to enchant a card. There are scoring and victory conditions for party games, easy games, and "professional" games. The game consists of 32 animal cards, 2 bacillus cards, and a magic formula card.

http://www.printgames.net/english/detail_e/witch.htm accessibility
categories: Animals, Card Game, Fantasy, Print & Play

name: State Fair: Ferris Wheel KnockOut
description:
This game is a sort of shooting gallery for at home in a ferris wheel theme. Your target is to shoot sensors with a sort of laser-gun. When you hit the sensor with the laser a balloon pops. This game can be played alone as well as with several players (using time targets for example).

It came in a lot of different variants, all in the State Fair style (see other names). Also a lot of other target shooting games exists nothing to do with those of this brand, but they may be listed here as well.

name: Ike-A-Doo Crazy Ikes Game
description:
Object: To assemble, piece by piece, one of the figures on the spinner board. Each figure has twelve parts which are to be chosen by shape and not necessarily by color. First player who completes h is figure and calls, "Ike-A-Doo" is the winner.

Colorful, nostaligic game of putting together legs, heads, arms, feet and torsos into robotic-like figures called, among many others, Cap'n Ike, Ike-A-Roo, Dopey-Ike and Lazy-Ike.
mechanics: Pattern Building, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Hund und ...?
description:
The content.
36 cards
Each card contains 3 items:
a dog and...
2 displays from the following list:
tree-car-ship-hat-moon-ball-girl-boy

The basic idea of "Hund und...?" is to develop the capability of recognizing differently displayed symbols as similar.

There are two game ideas included. The more challenging one is the second one, where the players have to notice whether any of the other items (besides the dog) appears on two cards in a row. Whoever recognizes this first, gets the cards. This variant is suitable for kids about six and up.
categories: Animals, Card Game, Children's Game, Memory

name: Wimbledon
description:
Content:
4 pawns, 4 score markers, 1 ball, 2 dice, 23 tennis cards, 1 board

Both players try to decide the mathch for themselves. The match is decided by skill, dices and tennis cards.

name: Kerlett
description:
Content:
1 board, 1 dice cup, 5 dice, 1 block, 36 chips

At the beginning each player gets a set of chips in one color. The dice are thrown. All players play at the same time and try to place their chips a tdifferent places of the board.
You may not place a second one in a field.
Besides real number fields which show the sum of all dice there is one field each for even and odd sums, for pairs, triplets, quadruplet, quintruplet and small and big street.
If noone wants to put down any chips, points are given for the combinations.

name: Check-Point
description:
Content:
1 board,
49 tiles,
72 chips

Each player has an closed deck of tile in front of him.
All players try at the same time, to place their own tiles at the right location on the board.
At the placed card a chip of the own color is put.
As soon as a player has laid down all of his cards, the game is over.
For each correct Karte the player gets a point. Wrong cards are good for minus points.

name: 6mal6
description:
1 board, 1 deck of cards with 72 cards of the numbers 1-9, 12 big and 90 small chips

The destination of the game is to lay higher card values onto the 6 fields of the own horizontal row than the other players to avoid to give away own chips. The winner is the player who stll has chips at the end.

name: Schubs + Remmidemmi
description:
Two games in one box. Both games were the contest winners of Ravenburgers "Spielesammlung zum Ausprobieren" (Nr. 12023, ca. 1965). Out of 7 games, they were the 2 games with the most votings to get published on their own with new designed game boards.

1. Schubs:

1 board, 5 pawns in 4 colors, 1 die

The pawns of the players have to be moved through a landscape, but each pawns needs the help of a second pawn. The cannot succeed on their own. That forces cooperation, which noone can deny.

2. Remmidemmi

1 board (the back side of the board above), 5 pawns in 4 colors, 1 die
In this turbulent game to bring your pawns to their destination, on ways, which directions xou cannot decide allways for yourself. Own skillfulnuess ist as important as dice luck.

name: 247 "two.four.seven"
description:
Content: board with 247 fields (13 x 19), 1 stone, a team of 5 "actives" each, 1 die

247 is a die-game for 2 players.

In the game they overtake the "stone" with the help of an "active" in order to throw it tawards the opposite "out line" and finally into "out" there.
Winner is the player whose team succeeds to get the most "outs" after a certain playing time.

name: That's Donald Pokerface
description:
Content:1 board, 4 Donald-pawns, 4 pawn holders, 32 playing cards with the different values

The fields on the game plan are numbered in sequenc from 1 to 71 and also show numbers on ther borders. These numbers tell the players which card they must play in order to leave each respective field.
The active player calls out a number and plays a card face down. The other players now have the task: believe that number or don't believe.Ifthactive player was right but his card was doubted, then he can move by twice that number.The doubter has to go back the same amount. The opposite way it goes when the doubter is right.
The game is over as soon as a player reaches the finishing field.
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: El Joc del Cava
description:
El Joc del Cava is a game that simulates the manufacture of sparkling wine in Catalonia, called cava (Protected Designation of Origin).

Components:

Board game
Deck of 108 cards
24 counter
Rules.

name: Hessen Reise
description:
The players travel through the federal state of Hesse, Germany.
They receive one town card which becomes their "home card".
They get 11 more cards which they have to organize for their travel from town to town.
The destination is the capital Wiesbaden.
The die lets the pawns move. A "free time" card is taken when a 6 is rolled. It contains events that either have to be fulfilled immediately or it can be kept to fulfill later. "Free time" cards disrupt the normal trip through Hesse.
The first player to reach Wiesbaden and get rid of all their cards, wins.

name: Fighting Fantasy collectible card game
description:
From the web site:

The Fighting Fantasy™ collectible card game (CCG) is a collectable card game based on the Fighting Fantasy™ series of interactive gamebooks published by Wizard Books. In the Fighting Fantasy™ CCG, each player assumes the role of a character card as they attempt to destroy the other player and take control of Allansia. During the course of play, this character will discover secret artifacts, learn new spells and gather monsters to their fold.

The web site was last updated in 2005: http://www.fightingfantasygamebooks.com/tradingcards.htm

Buy Microbadge

name: Memo-Maus
description: Mice are building themselves a racetrack with a start and a finish line. In the middle there is a "cheese-tunnel" out of swiss cheese which the ate 3 tracks inside. Through these tracks they push differently colored cheese pieces. By the pieces which come out on the other side thay know how many fields they can move forward on the racetrack.

name: Tauchbasis X-1
description:
Several scuba divers start from the under water platform for treasure huntingbecause the wreck of an pretty old ship is found. Unmeasurably much money was said to be there.
Each player commands three scuba divers who try to get as much money as possible from the depth.
The winner is the player with the biggest treasure at the end.

name: Tausendsassa
description: the group of the plyers tries to get more points than their opponent, the goblin "Tausendsassa". If thes succeed to get more points by skill and luck she has earned the title "Tausendsassa".

name: Wortwurm
description: A category is chosen. The clock is running. The turn player writes fitting words into the Wortwurm on the board. Who has the best ideas and writes the most words, gets the most points.

name: Ätsch!
description:
Where is the small plate hidden?
It has to be somewhere!

Turn by turn the players stab with a small stick into the opponent's lump of modeling clay, always on the lookout for a hidden plate.
As long as it isn't found the player on his turn throws a die and moves his pawn forward on the board. The better the plate is hidden the further a player may push his pawn.

name: Karlchen
description: Each player has a track for his pawn. On each field of the track there are barrier stones with the picture of Karlchen. Each player has to bring his pawn over the barrier stones as fast as possible to the finish field.

name: Awithlaknakwe
description:
An American Indian game attributed to the Zuni tribe of the Southwestern U.S.

A game for two or four players played on a board made up of 168 squares each intersected by diagonal lines. The board is composed of a 12x12 grid with a line of six starting/home squares parallel to and centered along each edge of the board. The players place their six pieces in these squares at the start of the game. In addition, each player has a seventh piece, which is slightly larger, known as the Priest of the Bow.

The object is to cross the board and occupy the opposing home spaces, capturing as many men as possible on the way. Moves are made one square at a time along diagonal lines, with the pieces being placed at intersecting points. The pieces may not be moved backward.

When two pieces surround an opposing piece, it is captured and removed from the board. The first captured piece is replaced by the capturing player's Priest of the Bow, which has the ability to move either on the diagonal lines as normal, or at right angles.

name: Igel, Frosch und Maus...
description:
Each player tries to get as many animal cards as possible. Important is to achieves getting all four of cards of a specific animal. This gets more points and because the cards are secure when you have all 4 of them, they cannot be taken over by other players.
The winner is the player who has won more quartets of cards after a certain time.

name: Alle meine Tiere
description: Each player cares for eight animals of one species. On the board they lie all scattered around. The player who manages first to see all of his animals at the same time on the board has almost won. He has to answer a question and wins.

name: Fischer's Fritz fischt große Fische
description: The idea is to catch as many fish and as a big a fish as possible, but also there are many items that lie in the water, but do not belong there. The winner is the player with the highest card value at the end.

name: Daumenlutscher
description: Sucking thumb is a dreadful habit. Every child knows this. It is hard to get rid of this habit. This game provides 15 situations that you can come into such an embarrassing situation. Each time when your pawn puts a thumb into his mouth you are punished by slowing down your forward progess. Who will be first to the finishing field without sucking their thumb?

name: Siege
description:
From publisher's press release:

Based on the classic chess, Siege is played with a standard set of chess pieces, a circular 120-space Siege board, and new objectives.

With its debut at the 2008 Canadian Toy & Hobby Fair on January 26-28 in Toronto, Siege Games is poised to unleash this innovative new game on Canadian chess players.

"If you can play chess, you can play Siege", says Frank Elstub, President of Siege Games. "Where chess represents two opposing armies facing off across a field of battle, Siege moves the conflict to the siege of a castle. The pieces move basically the same as in chess, so it's easy to get started, but there are more spaces and new perspectives, so standard chess strategies are out the window."

name: Double Vision
description: A reflector-box is put in the middle of the table. All plates are arranged in any order on the 20 spots of the board edge. The turn player pushes two of the plates in the middle of the box to see the down side. If he sees 6 symbols at the upper and the mirror side he can take this plate.

name: Denkste
description: The window board is placed between the players. The turn player throws the symbol die, takes a marker and throws in into a slit with the same symbol. From now on the turn player has to memorize first how many markers are in every slit. Is his answer correct, He may throw the die once more. Is it wrong. His turn is over. The winner is the player who wins 4 rounds.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Pattern Recognition

name: Ei der Kuckuck
description: Each player moves the eggs of his color over the colored field of the board - towards a strange nest. Destination is to lay your own egg as a "kuckoo egg" into the nest of another player as fast as possible. Who manages this first wins the game.

name: Arctic
description: Each player slips into the role of an ice bear who jumps from floe to floe. In the meantime the ice bears made a game out of it. They count the floes which they reach without falling into the water. The players take the floes which they leave and add the points of them. When no one can make any move the game is over.
