The Army Deck consists of units (Infantry Company, Cavalry Platoon, or Artillery Battery), each of which is rated for Attack Damage and Defense. The Battle Deck consists of Attack Cards, Opportunity Attack Cards, Defense Cards, Event Cards, Leader Cards, and Terrain Cards. Each player starts with a random draw of five Army Cards and five Battle Cards. Variant rules are included for a quick start, balanced starting forces, and alternate victory conditions.

name: Greek Games
description:
“Card game for 2-4 players. Ancient Greek Olympics Theme. Players try to win the most Events. Victory: The player with the most Victory Points at the end of the game wins.”

The game is played using two decks. The Ability Deck contains sixty cards. The Event Deck specifies the twelve events in which the players will compete, which include Discus, Javelin, Horse Racing, and Boxing.

The Ability cards played by the players determine who will be awarded the Gold, Silver, and Bronze medals in each event.

name: Grecos
description:
“Wargame for 2 or more players. Mythological Greek theme. Victory: Occupy all 6 City States on the Board.”

“Tiles are used to make the Map. Chits are used to represent Units. Cards are used for Events. Counters are stacked with units to record damage. Tile, chit, counter, and card sets are common to all players. Six sided dice are needed to play.”

The map is generated by randomly distributing the Terrain Tiles on a chess board or 8x8 grid. The Tiles come in two water varieties (Sea, Abyss) and five land varieties (Coastal, City State, Forest, Mountains, Ruins.)

Each player starts the game with one Hero unit located on a City State space. The players must recruit various heroes, men, and monsters to aid them in their conquest of Greece. The players will face random events reflecting the blessings of the Greek Gods or disasters and dangers.

name: Gods & Demons
description:
“Card game for 2 players. Based on Hindu Mythology. One player is the Good Blue Skinned Rama. The other is the Evil 10-headed, 40-Armed Demon King Ravana. Victory: Kill the opposing Leader.”

Each player has a unique deck containing, in addition to one Leader card, eight basic card types: Heroes, Troops, Weapons, Armor, Modifiers, Strikes, Defenses, and Events.

Players can hold a hand of up to eight cards. The players alternate being the attacker, at which time they have the option of choosing to attack with some, all, or no units. The defender chooses which units will block attacking units. All unblocked units attack the opposing leader. Damage markers are used to record combat results.

name: Goblin Commander Tactics
description:
“Card game for 2 players. Based on the video game of the same name. Victory: Destroy all of your opponent’s units.”

Each player portrays one of five Clans. Each Clan has an individual deck of Clan Units. The players share a common Magic Deck and Tactics Deck. The players deploy Clan Card units onto the battlefield by playing them on the table. Each Clan Card is allowed to make one attack each turn.

name: GeneRally
description:
Based on the PC auto racing game of the same name.

“A cardgame for 2 to 6 players. It tries to recreate some of the twists of the original PC game, but incorporates more than that: card management, timing of card play, bluff.”

“The game is played on four regular rounds and a great Final Lap round. The regular rounds are the main moves of the race, where the players will struggle to better their positions on the race. The Final Lap round will be the outcome of all the tactics and choices made during the race . . . The winner of the race is the player which car has moved furthest on the track.”

The rules are in English, Italian, and French.

name: Garden Grow
description:
“Players compete to see who can grow the best garden. Victory: At the end of the game, the player who scores the highest in the most plant categories is the winner. Game End: The game ends when at the end of a players turn, there are no cards left in the deck.”

The game uses a custom deck composed of ten categories of cards: eight Plant Categories, the Nurture Category, and the Blight Category.

name: Game of Lists
description:
“Trivia game for 1 or more players. Winning: The first player to score 35 points is the winner.”

The game consists of a custom deck of cards. Each card describes a category. A card is drawn and the players are given a set amount of time to write a list of items that come within the category. Once the time limit has expired, the players reveal their lists. Each correct answer scores one point, but a player may not score more than ten points in a single turn.

Categories on the cards include: Names of Physicists, Names of Cuts of Beef, Names of Computer Programming Languages, Names of Antibiotics, Names of Bad Guys in Star Wars and The First 10 Elements on the Periodic Table.

name: Galactic Civilizations
description:
A game of alien conquest played on a 10x10 grid, with each square representing a sector of space.

Eight major alien civilizations inhabit the galaxy. Each player represents four Client alien races as determined by random card draw at the start of the game. At the start of the game, each alien race controls one randomly selected sector. Each race has special abilities/limitations that affect the general rules of play, as well as special victory conditions which establish additional criteria by which the players may earn extra Victory Points.

The player with the most victory points at the end of 2d10 turns wins the game. Victory points are scored for each sector controlled by a player’s Client alien races.

name: Freudian Slip
description: “Players immerse themselves in a mass psychosis directed by the cards and their own subconscious desires.” Players are dealt seven cards, each displaying one word. “The player with the most psychological baggage goes first.” The players take turns describing a dream, incorporating a word from one of their cards. The game ends when two players pass their turns. The player who is voted the winner in the most categories “is declared the most in need of Psychoanalysis.”

name: French Indian Wars
description:
“Card Game for 2 Players. French Indian War Theme circa 1753-1763.”

One player takes on the role of the British forces, the other player is the French. The game is played with a custom deck of cards. The cards include leaders, troops, Indians, and defenses.

The object of the game is to win all of the forts, represented by Fort Tokens. At the start of the game each player has five Fort Tokens. The Tokens are won when the Attacking player is able to play the winning cards in the Expedition and Siege phases of a turn. Solitaire and optional rules are included.

name: Asimov's Foundation and Empire War Game
description:
“This is a four player war game set during Asimov's Foundation and Empire Novel. Each player controls a quadrant of the Milky Way Galaxy: (Listed from Terminus, going Spinward) The Foundation, The Imperium, The Union Of Worlds (The Mule) and Tazenda.”

The first player to occupy thirteen Sectors with Major Systems wins the game. Solitaire rules are also included. The game portrays combat between interstellar fleets using a diceless combat resolution system.

name: Fish Food
description:
Two groups of fish battle for supremacy.

Each player starts with a set of sixteen fish (two each of eight different kinds) which square off on an 8x8 grid or chess board. Each turn a player rolls two dice and moves up to two fish the distance shown on a die.

The fish are rated with Force values ranging from 0 to 7. A fish with a higher Force value can eat a fish with a lower Force value by landing on it. However, two weaker fish can be positioned to eliminate a stronger fish when their combined Force totals are equal to or greater than that of the larger fish.

The three weakest fish have special abilities – the Flying Fish can jump over other fish, the Minnow can use both die rolls in one turn, and the Puffer cannot be eaten.

The winner is the player who eliminates all opposing edible fish or who occupies all four center spaces of the board at the end of the opponent’s turn.

name: Firestorm
description:
“When two forest fires collide... a ferocious storm unleashes its fury. You must stop the flames at all costs. Do you have what it takes to fight the biggest wildfire of this century? Or are you too busy cowering beneath your computer desk?”

“Solo card game. Also designed for 2 or more players to compete against each other for best score. Each player is in command of an Army of wildfire fighters & equipment. Protect structures from fire damage to accumulate points.”

The game uses two decks of cards. The Battle Card deck is a custom deck consisting of Fighter Cards (different kinds of firefighting crews and equipment), Aid Cards, Challenge Cards, and Leader Cards. The Flame Deck represents the fire and structures or victims using a standard deck of playing cards (including jokers.) The object of the game is to have the most structures once there are no more Flame Cards in the deck or all flames are extinguished.

name: Fighting Front
description:
A World War II themed game played using cards placed on a 5x6 grid. The players portray one of five nationalities: German, Russian, American, or Japanese. At the start of the game, each player controls one half of the board.

The cards in the deck represent combat units, leaders, locations, and events. The types of combat units represented in the game include air, armor, and infantry forces of various types. While both sides play from a common deck, there are six types of cards in the deck that provide a various nationality specific unit or effect.

The first player to have units occupying two or more spaces in the opposing player’s back row wins the game.

name: Fading Suns Emperor Wars
description:
“Card game for 5 players. Based on the 1995 SF PC Game Emperor of the Fading Suns.”

In this detailed game of interplanetary struggle and conquest, each player is the leader of a Noble House who is seeking to become the Emperor. Each player starts with control of a Noble House, five random planets, five Scepters, and a War Fleet. Each Noble House has a unique bonus.

The object of the game is to hold the position of Regent for four consecutive turns. The first player to do so is declared Emperor. The Regent is selected by vote of the players, with each Scepter they hold being worth one vote. In addition, a player with the favor of the Church or Guilds may vote with Scepters controlled by those groups. In the case of a tie vote, no player serves as Regent that turn. Scepters can be obtained from other players by making successful attacks.
categories: Card Game, Print & Play, Science Fiction

name: Eskimo
description:
“Card, Board, & Dice game for 2-4+ players. Each player is an Eskimo (Inuit) Hunter.”

The game is played on a circular track of 16 spaces. There are three types of spaces on the board: shelter, hunting grounds, and ice. Two decks of cards are used, the Animal Deck and the Hunter Deck. The Animal Deck is composed of the animals that may be captured by the players. The Hunter Deck is composed of weapons, means of transportation, and special cards.

“Winning: At the end of the game, the player with the most Food Points wins. Food points are gained by collecting (hunting) Animal cards. The game ends when all Animal cards have been collected. Get 1 Food Point for each Special card in your hand at the end of the game.”

name: Eskimo: Expansion
description:
“These solo rules are based on an essentially romantic view of the eskimo and hopefully compliment the multi player Eskimo card and board game by Lloyd Krassner. Why solo??? - No one to play with, thats why.”

In addition to splitting the board into the real world and underworld halves, this solitaire variant also adds Fate Cards, Skills and Seasons to the game.

“The solo rules are 1 year in the life of your eskimo. One year is 16 steps of the season track.”

“The upper world (realworld) is bad luck, accident, misadventure and occasionally good luck. To survive you need to manage your resources, your personal strengths, acquire skills and deal with misfortune.”

“The other world is taboo, transgression, animal guides and recovering your balance in your world.”

“You need both to survive. You will need to travel in both worlds and maintain balance.”

name: Enclave
description:
“Players lead post-holocaust armies in a battle for survival.” The object of the game is to occupy your opponent’s Enclave.

The game is played on a 6x6 grid with each player occupying an Enclave at a corner of the board (at opposite corners if there are only two players). The nature of the territory in every other space is unknown until revealed by exploration. The different types of territory chits bestow various bonuses. The game features Road Warrior type gangs and vehicles, including cycle gangs and a gyrocopter.

name: Emporex
description:
“Players take the roles of rival Noble Houses in a war to control a neutral space sector.” The object of the game is to be the first player to control every planet on the map.

The game is played on a 10x10 hex grid, with the Homeworlds located in the corners. The other 20 planets are randomly distributed by rolling 10 sided dice to determine coordinates. All of the planets and Homeworlds are named and rated for type, income produced, and combat units available on the planet. Each player begins with identical forces, including randomly determined allies. The allies represent galactic powers that provide certain bonuses, units, or special capabilities.

name: Elemental Chess
description:
An abstract strategy game with an “Earth, Air, Water, Fire Theme.” The game is played using 24 pieces on a standard 8x8 chess board.

Each piece is associated with one of the four elements. A piece cannot capture pieces of its own element, only those of different elements. For example, Air pieces can only capture Water and Fire pieces; Water pieces can only capture Fire and Earth pieces; Fire pieces can only capture Earth and Air pieces; and Earth pieces can only capture Air & Water pieces.

You win if you capture all six of your opponent’s pieces of any one element.

name: Eagles of Glory
description:
“Two player Card game depicting Napoleonic era warfare. The first player to be routed from 3 of his 5 forward positions loses.”

The game is played using three custom card decks: the Battalion Deck, Tactics Deck, Commander Deck. Cards are played on the table in opposing lines representing positions on the center, left and right center, and left and right flanks of the battlefield. The game includes scenarios for Maida (4-7-1806), Bussaco (27-9-1810), and Quatre Bras (16-06-1815).

name: Bellum Astralis
description:
“Space empires against each other and the bug threat.”

The map is randomly constructed, drawn on a piece of paper. Each player selects a starting world for his empire. A random number of worlds (1-6) are infected by Bug units, which reproduce and spread to other worlds. The players each start with one frigate, one freighter, ten troops, six food units, and six machinery units. Agricultural worlds provide one food unit per turn. Industrial worlds convert one food unit to one machinery unit each turn.

The winner is the player who has the most victory points after ten turns. Victory points are awarded at the end of each turn based on the types of worlds controlled, for each cruiser owned, and for having the longest trade route.

name: Cannonade
description:
“Napoleonic era tactical combat simulation. Watch out for grapeshot.”

Each player is given 100 points to construct a force from the following types of units: Infantry (1 point), Cavalry (1.5 points), Cannon (10 points), Officer (3 points), and Baggage (supply wagons, 2 points). Each player also receives a Flag unit “for games of capture the Flag.” The players must also construct their own map of the battlefieldt using four abstracted terrain types: Clear, Covered, Fortified, and Impassable.

The object of the game is to obtain the most Victory Points, which are awarded in varying amounts for killing or capturing units.

name: Celtic Saga
description:
“Players take the role of Celtic Warrior Heroes in ancient Ireland. Players compete to make their Hero the most famous of all. The winner will be sung about by bards for generations and his exploits will be written of in the Book of Kells.”

The game comes in two versions, Ulster and Fionn. A separate deck of custom cards is used for each version.

The players accumulate cards to score points in four categories: Blessings, Fortune, Victory, and Prophecy. The player who has accumulated the most points in the most categories after seven turns wins the game.

name: Chinese Warlords
description:
“These battles take place in China in the 1920's. Anarchy and Lawlessness reign. Now is the time for enterprising individuals to gain power.” The object of the game is to kill the opposing Warlord or capture his stronghold.

Each player begins with one stronghold, one warlord, three peasants, two thugs, and one bodyguard. The players collect income from their stronghold and villages. Income is used to recruit additional men, weapons, and vehicles. Units which may be recruited include Trusted Lieutenants, Machine Guns, Artillery Pieces, Armored Vehicles, and armed Boats.

name: Classic Space Opera
description:
“Explore intergalactic space and fight the Slish (enemy aliens), and pay off your ship!”

A simple card based space adventure game inspired by White Buffalo’s Starfaring. Each player starts with a Scoutship with nine crewmembers and a captain. The players travel through space, battling aliens and facing hazards, seeking to discover planets. Send down a landing party to make contact with aliens and battle them. Encounters and events are generated by the card decks. The Imperial Scout Service pays the players for various discoveries and for destroying Slish spacecraft.
categories: Adventure, Card Game, Science Fiction, Space Exploration

name: Corps of Discovery
description:
“Thomas Jefferson bought (bargain-price) Louisiana from the French in 1803. This purchase more than doubled the size of the United States. Meriwether Lewis & William Clarke were chosen by Jefferson to Explore this vast, unknown region. They assembled a group of Soldiers, hunters, boatmen, and slaves (40-50 men) known as the Corps of Discovery. They set off from St Louis in 1804. They Traveled as far as the Pacific. The Expedition lasted two and a half years. They returned safely after mapping large areas, finding new plants and Animals and meeting many new Indian Tribes.”

The players compete to acquire the most discovery cards by making sets of four and seven cards. Solo victory conditions are also included.

name: Dark Sun Adventures
description: A boardgame set in the AD&D Dark Sun campaign setting. Each player controls a party of six adventurers attempting to acquire and return with the Rod of Divining. The map is a 40 space track. The first party to reach the end of the track obtains the Rod of Divining. That party must then return the Rod to the start space to win. However, if an opposing party is able to defeat the party carrying the Rod, then the victorious party obtains the Rod and may return it to the start space to win the game.

name: Dogma the Board Game
description: A game based on the Kevin Smith movie Dogma. The object of the game is to be the first player to get your pawn to the Church Gates (the end space on the board.) One player takes the role of the Last Scion, the other player takes the role of the fallen angels Loki and Bartleby. The board is fifty spaces long. Each space relates to people or incidents from the movie. The spaces are marked as one of the following types: Joke Space, Good Space, Evil Space, Test Space, Distraction Space, Help Spaces, and Bad Spaces. Each type of space has a different effect.

name: Doubloons & Dragoons
description:
“Players take the role of Merchant Princes in control of their own city state. Thru conquest and trade they try to outdo their opponents in the quest for Gold & Glory. Object: Conquer all Cities on the map.”

The game is played on a hex map with 25 cities, some landlocked and some on the ocean. The game includes rules for the Black Plague, favor of the church, trading, taxation, production or military and trade units, spy missions, and diplomacy.

name: Dracula's Castle
description:
“One side is Dracula and his minions. The other side is the Vampire Hunter and his assistants. Action takes place inside Castle Dracula. Victory: Completely eliminate all of your opponent’s pawns.”

The Vampire player starts with Dracula and three lesser vampires. The Vampire Hunters are a team consisting of the lead vampire hunter and four assistants. Movement is simultaneous based on secret written orders. Each side has a custom deck of cards that are used to extend movement and for attack and defense.
categories: Card Game, Horror, Novel-based, Print & Play

name: Dredd
description:
“Based on the comic series Judge Dredd. Players share 3 common decks: Judge Deck, Criminal Deck, Event Deck. Each deck has its own discard. A player will keep cards from all 3 decks in his hand. Victory: Be the first player to accumulate 100 Prestige Points. Prestige Points are gained by apprehending Criminals.”

“Teams: Each player controls a team of up to 4 Characters. Most characters will be Judges. Stats: Each Character will have 2 Stats: Fight & Investigate. A Stat will usually have a value between 0 and 4. Characters will also have one or more Traits such as: Judge, Psychic, Alien, etc.”
categories: Card Game, Comic Book / Strip, Science Fiction

name: Dungeon Keeper
description:
“Based on the Computer Game of the same name. Each player controls their own Dungeon, which they try to build up, in spite of a continuing onslaught of Heroes.”

Using a Room Deck and Spell Deck, amass a collection of Rooms, Creatures, Gold, Mana, and dead Heroes – but don’t allow your Dungeon Keeper to be killed or your Heart Room to be captured, as these lead to instant defeat.

name: Dungeon Master
description:
“Dungeon Crawl Card game. One Player is the Dungeon Master. The other player is the Party Player. Each player has his own unique deck. The Party Player must create an adventuring party. A party starts with 6 members (Heroes). Pick 10 cards from the Character Deck. Discard 4 and keep 6.”

The Dungeon Master wins the game if all of the Heroes are killed. The Party Player wins the game if the party gains Treasures worth 50 points or more.
categories: Adventure, Card Game, Fantasy, Print & Play

name: Earth Defense Force
description:
“Takes place in the Star Blazers Universe. Pick your Fleet: Earth Defense Force, Gamillon Empire, White Comet Empire. Abstract skirmish level Ship combat. Each figure represents a single Ship (unit). Victory: You win if you Destroy the opposing Flagship.”

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the ships. Each fleet has five types of ships. A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw their hands from a common deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction

name: Exorcist
description: “Card Game for 2 players. One player is the Exorcist. The other player is the Demon. The Demon has taken possession of a young Innocent. The Exorcist is trying to purge the Demon. Each player has a unique deck. Each player gets 50 Soul Tokens. Victory: The first player to win all the Soul Tokens is the winner.”

name: Fabulous Thunderbirds
description:
A game based on the Thunderbirds television show.

The players travel from their Secret Bases to respond to various emergencies determined by card draw. Each emergency requires a certain assortment of vehicles to resolve. All players have an identical assortment of vehicles to work with: "Thunderbird 1" through "Thunderbird 5", and "FAB 1."

The object of the game is to make more rescues that your opponents.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction

name: Fairy Circle Ring
description:
“It is Spring Equinox in the Sylvan woods. The little people, also referred to as Fairies, or Fey have gathered to celebrate. After feasting, storytelling, gossiping, and singing they gather around the Fairy circle ring to play a game they call the Dance of Eights. The fairies dance in groups until they finally form a perfect circle of eight dancers. The winners get laurel leaves and an extra helping of Pixie dust on their elderberries.”

The winner is the first player to build a “ring”, or hand of eight cards, composed of a specified mix of dancers according to their gender, size, alignment, and Earth element.

name: Farmers of Ur
description: “Players each control a settlement in ancient Mesopotamia. Players are trying to be the first to develop their village into a full-fledged city. This Honor belongs to the first player to build a Ziggurat. Tokens represent the manpower and materials needed to build the Ziggurats. Victory: The first player to accumulate 60 Tokens is the winner. If two players both go over 60 in the same turn, the player with the highest total number of Tokens wins.”

name: America's History: Multicultural Contributions to America – Modern Age to Contemporary Period
description: This is primarily a trivia game. Players move around the board answering questions. The player with the most correctly answered questions wins. A set time period is used to determine when a particular game is completed.

name: The Pickle Game
description: Ever wonder just how many kinds of pickles there are? Of course you haven't! But we did… Here players strategically change the ingredients in jars of pickle brine, each trying to achieve the correct ratio of ingredients to complete different pickle recipes.

name: Mad Scientist: Frankenbuilder
description: Play a Mad Scientist student, racing to animate your first monster! Send your unreliable assistants (Agor, Egor, Igor, Ogor, Ugor, or Ygor) to collect diverse body-parts from different graveyards, with the hope that you can cobble something together from the mis-matched parts.
mechanics: Pick-up and Deliver, Point to Point Movement, Secret Unit Deployment, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Mad Scientist: Lab Rats
description: Players are Mad Scientist students chasing escaped, mutated lab rats throughout the Mad Scientist university. Each rat has developed different powers while being a lab rat (psychic rats, genius rats, giant rats, mutant rats, etc.), and they can put up one heck of a fight!

name: Mad Scientist: Final Exam
description: As Mad Scientist students, players collect, trade, and assemble hands of cards as they go through their crazy final exams. Hand ranks change during the round, causing players to bet on the winning hand and change strategies mid-game at the whim of capricious teachers.

name: Operation Phantom Fury
description:
“Lead US Marines in the assault on Fallujah.”

This solo card game uses two decks of card, the American deck and the Insurgency deck. The American card types include Tactics, Infantry, Armor, Support, Recon, and Disarm. The Insurgency card types include Tactics, Insurgents, Positions, Explosives, and Objectives.

As the game is played, seven piles of cards are formed. Three piles represent the "Front Line", Insurgent positions 1, 2 and 3. There is also one pile for captured insurgents and objectives, one pile for American casualties, and two discard piles (one for each side.)

The game Ends when there are no cards left in the Insurgent Deck and the Front Line piles.

The player’s score is based on the total value of the cards in the captured pile less the total value of the cards in the casualty pile.
categories: Card Game, Modern Warfare, Print & Play

name: Kilts & Claymores
description:
"Board & card game for 2 players. Skirmish between two feuding Scottish Highland Clans. Abstract skirmish level combat. Each figure represents a single man (unit). Victory: You win if you kill 6 or more opposing units."

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the units. Each side starts with sixteen units: a Chieftain, five Champions, and ten Clansmen. A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw hands of cards from the shared deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.

name: Phasers
description:
"Board & card game for 2 players. Battle between two Star Trek Fleets. Abstract skirmish level combat. Each figure represents a single Ship (unit). Victory: You win if you Destroy the opposing Dreadnaught."

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the ships. The players choose to play as the Federation, Klingons, or Romulans. Each side has eight ships: three Destroyers, two Scouts, two Cruiers, and one Dreadnaught. The only distinction between the types of ships is the number of hits they can take.

A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw hands of cards from the shared deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.
categories: Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction

name: Star Command
description:
"Board & card game for 2 players. Battle between Buzz Lightyear and Evil Emperor Zurg. Takes place in the Buzz Lightyear Universe. Each figure represents a main character or group of lesser characters. Victory: Capture the opposing Leader."

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the forces. Each side has sixteen units. The units are rated for hit points, movement, attack range, and special ability.

A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw hands of cards from the shared deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.
categories: Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction

name: Martian Cloudships
description:
"Board & card game for 2 players. Battle between a Band of Martian Cloudships and a British (Victorian) Expeditionary Force."

"Alternate Fantasy Universe circa late 1800’s. Abstract skirmish level aerial combat. Each figure represents a single Ship (unit). Note: Vessels achieve weightlessness by carrying quantities of distilled Essence of Ether. Victory: You win if you Destroy the opposing Flagship."

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the ships. Each player has eight ships and a unique deck of cards. The cards are central to the play of the game as card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.
categories: Card Game, Fighting, Print & Play, Science Fiction

name: He-Man Skirmish
description:
"Board & card game for 2 players. Choose your side: He-Man or Skeletor. Takes place in the Masters of the Universe setting. Each figure represents one Fighter. Victory: Destroy your opponents Leader."

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Action figures, miniatures or counters are used to represent fighters and vehicles. Each side has sixteen units plus vehicles.

Each player has a custom deck of cards. Card play is central to the game as it is used to determine when units may move, attack, and defend.
categories: Comic Book / Strip, Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: X-Men Skirmish
description:
"Board & card game for 2 players. Battle between Mutants & Sentinel Robots. Takes place in the X-Men Universe. Each figure (unit) represents a Mutant or Robot. Victory: Destroy all opposing Units."

The X-Men get eight Mutants with a maximum Hit point total of 16. The Sentinel Robots and eighteen named Mutants are described by hit points, abilities, and three special powers.

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the combatants. A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw hands of cards from the shared deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.
categories: Comic Book / Strip, Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction

name: Narnia Skirmish
description:
"Board and Card Game. Battle between Aslan and the Kingdom of Narnia against the White Witch and her minions. Abstract skirmish level combat. Each figure represents 1 creature (1:1 scale). Victory: The Narnian forces win if they either defeat the White Witch or her entire army. The White Witch wins if she defeats Aslan or the Army of Narnia."

The Forces of the Kingdom of Narnia include Aslan, the King of Narnia, a Duke, an Earl, four Archers, and eight Infantry. The Forces of the White Witch include fifteen assorted monsters in addition to the Witch herself.

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the units. A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw hands of cards from the shared deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.

name: Musketeer Skirmish
description:
"Board & card game for 2 players. Melee between the 3 musketeers and a handful of the Cardinal's bodyguards. Abstract skirmish level combat. Each figure (unit) represents a single man. Victory: Eliminate your opponents completely."

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the combatants. Athos, Porthos and Aramis face off against a Captaion of the Cardinal's Guard and seven Guards. A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw hands of cards from the shared deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.

An optional scenario provides for adding D'Artagnan as a fourth musketeer and three additional Cardinal's Guards.

name: Rockets & Rayguns Skirmish
description:
"Will Flash rescue Dale or will they go down in flames aboard the Imperial Flagship. Find out in next weeks cliff hanger. Strap on your jetpack and get ready for some high flying adventure."

The Rebels are attacking the Imperial War Rocket Ajax where Heroine Dale is held prisoner. Aided by Chieftan Voltan of the Hawkmen and Forest Chieftan Baron, Human Hero Flash leads the Rebel force in its assault to board the Rocket and get to the brig to free Dale.

Victory is determined by which player scores the most Victory Points. The Rebels gain points for rescuing Dale and destroying the Rocket, and lose points for each Hero killed. The Imperials gain Victory Points for each Rebel Hero killed and for keeping Dale prisoner. The Imperials lose points if the Rocket is destroyed.
categories: Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction

name: Playground Skirmish
description:
"Board & card game for 2 players. Fight between two groups of kids on the playground. Victory: Drive the opposing gang off the playground."

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Eight to ten spaces are marked with obstacles such as Jungle Gyms, Monkey Bars, Teeter Tooters, Swings, Slides, etc.

Miniatures or counters are used to represent the kids. Each side has eight kids - two are on skateboards, two are on bikes, and 2 have skates.

A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw hands of cards from the shared deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.

name: Stickin it to the Man
description:
"Card game for 2+ players. Based on the Blacksploitation films of the early 70’s. Winning: The player accumulates the most Cool Points (CP) at the end of 5 hands wins."

The game is played with a custom deck containing seven suits of cards: Character, Cool, Fighting, Accessories, Bad Guys, Musician, and Actor. Each card is valued at 1 to 10 Cool Points.

Each turn the players play melds containing up to one card from each suit. The meld with the highest total Cool Point value wins the hand and the value of the hand is added to the player's Cool Point score.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: The Guardian
description:
A U.S. Coat Guard themed game inspired by the movie of the same name.

"Mayday!!! Mayday!!! Two teams of U.S. Coastguard helicopter pilots, spotters, and rescue swimmers are racing against time as a large storm wreaks havoc across the high seas. Each team is attempting to rescue as many victims as possible. Victory: The team with the most rescues after 52 turns wins."

The components include an 8×8 board (the sea), one 8-sided die, one 6-sided die, two standard decks of cards (representing the ”search & rescue” and “operations” decks), twenty-five Coast Guard event cards, two Coast Guard team tokens, and six Disaster tokens (numbered 1-6.)

name: Huscarl
description:
"Board & card game for 2 players. Battle between two Norse Tribes. Abstract skirmish level combat. Each figure represents a single man (unit). Victory: You win if you kill the opposing Chieftain."

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the combatants. Each player has sixteen units: a Chieftain, three Huscarls, two Berserkers, eight Warriorss, and two Pathfinders.

A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

name: Methuselah
description:
"Board & card game for 2 players. One side is Dracula and his minions. The other side is the Vampire Hunter and his assistants. Action takes place inside Castle Dracula. Victory: You win if you kill your opponent’s Leader."

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the combatants. The Vampire player has five Lesser Vampires, two Elder Vampires, and Methuselah. The Hunter player has a Lead Hunter, two Companions, and five Assistants.

Each player has a custom deck of cards. Card play is central to the game, as it determines when units may move, attack, or defend.
categories: Card Game, Fighting, Horror, Print & Play

name: Operation Blitzkrieg
description:
"Board & card game for 2 players. World War II theme. Abstract platoon level combat. Each figure represents a company or unit of men. Victory: You rout the enemy if you destroy 9+ of his units."

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the combatants. Each player starts with eight Infantry, four Tanks, and four Artillery.

A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

An Air War rules variant replaces two to four Infantry units with Air units. Additional attack, move, and defense cards are added to the deck for the Air units.

name: Monster Brawl
description:
"Board & card game for 2 players. Two Rival Gangs of Giant Japanese Monsters Face-off. Each figure represents a single Monster. Victory: Kill all opposing Monsters."

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Action figures, toys, miniatures, or counters are used to represent the monsters.

The players each have forty points to spend on monsters. The game describes thirty giant monsters who are rated for cost, hit points, flight capability, and special abilities.

A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw hands of cards from the shared deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.
categories: Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction

name: Old Course Golf & Country Club St. Andrews Golf Game
description:
From the Box:The Old Course, St. Andrews

No one knows who the first golfer was but everyone knows where he played: The Old Course, St. Andrews, Scotland.

The first mention of the game was in 1457 and ever since then a succession of great champions have wrestled to master The Old Course. Now, the latest in a long line of champions, Seve Ballesteros, winner of the 1984 Open, here at St. Andrews, plays The Old Course as Touring Professional of The Old course Golf and Country Club.

The Old course Hotel, as it then was, was acquired by a major British public company in 1982 and a multi-million pound refurbishment programme was completed in April 1983 creating 150 luxury five star rooms, a health spa, restaurants and many other luxury amenities for the exclusive use of members of The Old Course Golf and Country Club.

The club offers a unique membership which gives members a passport to unparalleled golf facilities the world over and which includes many of the finest resorts both in europe and in the U.S.A., with luxurious, complimentary accomodation.

Jack Nicklaus, Bernhard Langer and Sean Connery are but a few of the well known members of this, the most prestigious club in the world-

The Old Course Golf and Country Club, St. Andrews.

Game: Played on full colour scale drawings of The Old Course.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: Les Belligérants
description:
The Belligerents (A vivid game of Modern Combat) is one of the few pre-WWII wargames from France. Featuring a board on heavy card stock with various terrain features and a superimposed grid for movement of units. The game is driven by dice rolling and has units representing air, artillery, tank, ambulance, spy, guard, patrol and infantry. Each unit has a value on the bottom to represent the impact of capture.

The rules have not been translated at this point but an update will follow.

name: Klar Zum Gefecht
description:
Klar zum Gefecht! Das packende Flottenspiel

Ready for the Fight! The Fleet Game

The map represents an ocean with 6 islands and contains a grid for movement, set up area for the red and blue fleet. The fleets consist of battleships, cruisers, destroyers, u-boats, etc. Each unit is a lead flat which is rare to find.

An update of the game flow and rules will follow but its primarily a die roll, move and attack game.

name: Palaces of Minos
description:
"Card game for 2-4+ players. Minoan Civilization Theme. Each player is a King on the island of Crete circa 2000 BC." Each player chooses to play one palace: Knossos, Phaistos, Malia, or Kato Zakros.

Two custom decks are shared by the players, a Trade Deck and a Build Deck. For each meld played with the Trade Cards, a player receives 1 to 16 Luxury Points (based on the type of meld played) and draws one card from the Build Deck. The Build Cards come in two types, Events (disasters) and Resources (bonuses).

The first player to accumulate 100 Luxury Points is the winner.

name: Quest for the Princess Bride
description:
"Card game for 2 players. Based on the Princess Bride Story. One player takes the role of Westly. The other player takes the role of Prince Humperdink."

The Humperdink player starts with control over Princess Buttercup. Both sides attempt to recruit allies as Character Cards are drawn. A fight may break out, randomly determined to be a battle of wits, strength, or sword. Card play determines the winning side. The winner of a fight gains or maintains control of the Princess.

"Victory: Any player able to control the Buttercup token for 4+ consecutive turns wins. Any player who loses his Main Character (Westly or Humperdink) in a fight automatically loses. If the deck runs out, the player in control of the Buttercup Token wins."
categories: Adventure, Fantasy, Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based, Pirates

name: The Great Game
description:
"Card game for 2 Players. Depicts the 19th Century Rivalry between England and Russia in Central Asia. One Player is the Russian Empire. The other Player is the British Empire.

"Players share a common deck. There are 8 types of Cards: Intelligence, Politics, Military, Motivation, Obstacles, Difficulties, Events, Ally."

"Territory Points represent territory that has come under your sphere of Influence. Use pen and paper to keep track of Territory Points. Players may have negative Territory Points."

"Victory: The first player to accumulate 100 Territory Points is the winner."

name: U-one.
description: U-one. Submarine versus Merchantman. Consists of a heavy card stock full color four fold board showing the Western Approaches (South West England, the French Coast, and the Channel Islands with a superimposed playing grid. The game is played by two players (1 controls a submarine, the other a merchant ship). Each lead ship occupies 3 squares and must move forward the number rolled on the die. Players must avoid the red squares (minefields) and the object of the game is for the merchant ship to safely enter either Southhampton or Havre. The submarine must have the merchant ship directly to its bow and must roll a number equal to or greater than the distance between the ships to sink the merchant and win the game.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: America Rises
description: This is primarily a trivia game. Players move around the board answering questions. The player with the most correctly answered questions wins. A set time period is used to determine when a particular game is completed.

name: Chapter 11
description:
The wheeling-Dealing game of empire building in the world of business..Free enterprise at its best...and worst!

Now you can move up to the executive suite in this action-filled game of strategy!

Conglomerates, mergers, recessions, proxy fights, strikes and bankruptcies...It's all here in this exciting battle for success in the business world.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Hand Management, Paper-and-Pencil, Set Collection, Team-Based Game

name: Zombified
description:
"Card game for 2+ players. Zombie Theme."

The game uses a custom card deck made up of five types of cards: Survivors, Zombies, Weapons, Locations, Events. Send zombies against the survivors of the other players.
"Game End: The game ends when there are no cards left in the deck and and every player has had a turn in which there were no cards left to draw. Victory: The Player with the most survivors at the end of the game wins."

name: Second American Civil War
description:
"The beginning of the second decade of the 21st Century is a time of great turmoil for the United States. Political Factions tear the otherwise stable American political system into two deeply divided camps."

"The President (Eagle Faction) under the Homeland Defense Amendment has moved to the Cheyenne Mountain complex in Colorado just outside of Denver, in order to counter what he called the growing internal threats to the American way of Life. He is isolationist and seeks to remain beyond a second term. He is supported by the Air Force."

"The Congress (Flag Faction) wants to control what they see as the unchecked power of a Demagogue determined to seize total control. They are supporting greater State autonomy but are international in their economic interest. They are supported by the Navy. Eventually, the thunderclouds of civil war once again threaten to appear over the skies over America."

The game is played on an area movement map of the continental United States. There are 22 areas and 19 cities marked on the mapsheet. "The First player to gain control of THIRTEEN cities (two of which must be Denver and D.C.) and FIFTEEN areas is declared the winner."

A Political Alignment Index (PAI) is used to determine which side has control of these spaces on the mapsheet. The side with an advantage on the PAI has an easier time establishing political control over areas and cities, while the other side has an easier time gaining military support.

name: X-ploits
description:
"XXX rated card game. Players score points for sexual exploits they create through card combinations."

The game uses a custom deck of over 100 cards which are named for Partners, Places, Positions, Pluses, and Spoilers.

The players draw and discard from a hand of seven cards attempting to play a combination of as many cards as possible. Each combination must have one Partner, one Place, one or more Positions, and one or more Plus cards. However, one opponent may play a Spoiler card to reduce the value of a combination.

The game ends once the deck runs out. The player with the most points wins.

name: Thunderbolt
description:
"Each player controls an A-10 Thunderbolt II (The Warthog) on Close Air Support Duty."

The game is played with a custom deck of cards shared by all players. The deck includes Mission Cards, Munitions Cards, Enemy Cards, and Event Cards.

Mission Cards are ground targets of various Mission Point values. A player who successfully attacks the target wins the Mission Card and adds the Mission Points to his score. Enemy Cards, representing a variety of Soviet air and ground threats, are played against opposing players. Munitions Cars represent bombs, missiles, or other payload items which aid in attack or defense. Event Cards offer a variety of bonuses and can be played at various times as specified on the particular card.

There are also six named Pilot Cards that are not a part of the main deck. At the start of the game each player randomly selects one Pilot Card. Each pilot has a special advantage.

Fuel and ammo counters are used to track each plane's status. The aircraft are required to return to base to refuel and rearm. Damage can also force a plane to return to base where the damage is repaired.

The object is to have the most Mission Points at the end of the game.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Card Game, Modern Warfare

name: Sopwith
description:
"Dice game for 2 players. WWI theme. Ariel Dogfight. One player is a British Sopwith Camel. The other is a German Fokker Triplane. Victory: Shoot your opponent out of the skies."

Each player has five dice: a 20-sided die representing Visibility (from the aircraft), a 12-sided die representing Speed, a 10-sided die representing Maneuverability, an 8-sided die representing Firepower, and a 6-sided die representing Defense.

The Sopwith receives positive die roll modifiers for Visibility and Speed and the Fokker receives positive modifiers for Maneuverability and Defense. Neither aircraft has a bonus in Firepower.

The players roll all their dice each turn and compare them to determine a result. If the result of the dice places one of the aircraft in firing position with a higher Firepower score, the target must roll on the Damage table for a result. This ranges from destruction of the aircraft to damage which reduces the value of certain dice for that aircraft.

The game also includes rules for stalling (when a 1 is rolled on the maneuver die) and Ace Pilot skills.

name: Jedi Warp Duel
description:
"Card game for 2+ players. Each player controls a Jedi with a light saber. Takes place in the Star Wars Universe. Each figure represents a Jedi knight."

The game is played on a 5x5 grid. Miniatures or chits are used to represent the combatants. A custom card deck is used by both players. The appropriate cards must be played to allow units to move or attack.

Statistics for ten Jedi from the Star Wars movies are included. Each is described by Rank (Apprentice, Jedi, or Master), Jedi Ability, and Heroic Ability.

To win the game you must reduce your opponent to zero Force Points by making successful attacks.
categories: Card Game, Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction

name: Kill Rasputin
description:
The players compete to see who can kill Rasputin.

The game uses a custom deck of 52 cards. There are five types of cards: Method, Conspiracy, Location, Save, and Fate.

The players attempt to play melds of cards of the same type. Once you have three melds in play (one each for Method, Conspiracy, and Location), you may make an Assassination Attempt die roll to see if you kill Rasputin. If the roll is not successful, you lose some or all of your melds and the game continues.

A player who is unable to play a meld on a turn must roll on the Event table and take the specified action.

name: Mad Scientists
description:
"Board game for 2+ players. Science Fiction theme. Players are Rival Mad Scientists bent on World Domination. Victory: Destroy all Enemy Bases."

The game is played on a chess board or any other 8x8 grid. There are four types of counters in the game - Units, Bases, Modifiers, and Specials.

The players each receive one base at the start of the game. Every turn the players receive two counters, drawn randomly from a pile. Some counters add to the player's offensive capabilities, while others represent new bases and improvements for bases.

name: Snackin' Safari
description:
The slap-happy "feed-the-hungry-animals" action game!

Snackin' Safari is an action game that helps preschool adventurers with their coordination, counting and motor skills. This small table top game has 4 animals on the sides and a safari man in the center. All of the players tap their animals to get Safari Sam to spin. When Safari Sam spins, the snack disks in his "hands" fly off. The player who catches the most snacks wins.

Components:
FPT11101 - Green base with 4 animals on the sides: orange tiger head, green alligator head, yellow lion head, and grey elephant head. There is a safari man in the center that holds the accessory snack disks.
16 round plastic snack disks
categories: Action / Dexterity, Animals, Children's Game, Number

name: Stitch-opoly
description:
This is a variation on Monopoly, produced by the DMC Corporation, who makes embroidery floss. This version is thread and needlecrafting themed. Instead of properties, players collect stitching techniques.

According to the website at http://www.dmc-usa.com/majic/pageServer/1l0100028r/en_US/Sti...
, all property cards also feature a stitch diagram for the design on the card.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Modern Warfare
description:
Developed and published in 1940, Modern Warfare looks to be a self-published game as no publisher is listed and the game is copyrighted by the designers. The rules boast 3 games in one, the main game is Modern Warfare, a "game that fills up a long standing demand for a war game and introduces you to our latest mechanical inventions and the rapid development of their uses as weapons of destruction in the present day war operations". Additionally there is a wargame, called "Trench Warfare", based on the old styles of warfare and finally a simple "Hit and Miss" game.

Modern Warfare uses large (1.25 inch) lead Soldiers, Aircraft, Tanks and Artillery as units in the game and they are initially placed in one of four lines (3 main lines and the reserve).

The main game begins with the firing of a single artillery piece on each side for 4 turns (a spinner is spun for combat results and movement) followed by an artillery barrage (both artillery pieces fire on each side) until one side loses both their guns. Then the winning side gets 3 more shots and moves and attacks with his air and tank units in the first line. The other side then moves all air and tank units in the first rank. This alternates until one side has lost all their units.

The winning side retires their remaining air and tanks to the reserve and the infantry then fights alone... Terrain can be destroyed on the map (indicated by placing a red square on the destroyed item).

Fascinating instructions with detailed play throughs and fairly complicated rules depending on the unit type and position (line) the unit occupies.

name: High Roller Skinstakes Casino Game
description:
High Roller is a game which contains two card games:
High Roller Casinos and High Roller Superskins.
Superskins has the focus of betting on the card play between the dealer and one player. The betting is on the outcome, Dealer to win, Player to Win or Stand Off.
Casinos is a betting game with continuous involvement and fast moving action.
In both games two players play the cards and the other plays bet on the outcome of the game, and rounds can be played so that everyone has a turn at being a dealer, player and a better.
Game components:
One Plastic coated pack of 72 High Roller Casino Cards
Eight suites of players betting cards
Rules for both games playable
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Mature / Adult, Party Game

name: Fraperdeck Fraction/Decimal/Percent
description:
Fraperdeck Original is designed to encourage students to learn the relationship between fractions, decimals and percents. Fraperdeck has added a clever educational twist to commonly played games such as “War”, “Crazy 8” and more. This unique instructional format offers a FUN alternative to other methods.

Conversion charts and instructions for 4 different games are included.

Ages 7 and up, 2 or more players
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: In the Land of Egypt
description:
"Full" title: In the Land of Egypt... You'll find 8 great games about ancient times.

A small collection of games in a single box... Includes 30 Pyramid Cards, 30 Mummy Cards, 15 Rhyme Cards, 2 Egyptian Dice, and a rule booklet

From the box: In the Land of Egypt bring the dark secrets of ancient Egypt to light while reinforcing the educational curriculum. Children will see ho ancient engineers used science and math to build pyramids. Through storytelling and rhyme, they will learn about Egyptian life and mythology. Probability and problems solving will help them master exotic dice games.
categories: Ancient, Card Game, Educational, Math, Memory, Mythology, Number
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Memory, Pattern Recognition, Storytelling

name: Ghost Wiry Dan's Electronic Word Game
description:
Ghost Wiry Dans's Electric Word Game consists of two interconnected word tracks. The word tiles are placed face up, so you can choose to spell any word, but the electronics in the game vary the turn order, so your opponent may be able to spell their word first, even if it's longer.

The cover shows two small children, one of which has been possessed by a smiling ghost. It also shows a robotic figure, which I can only assume is "Wiry Dan."
categories: Educational, Electronic, Horror, Math, Word Game

name: Shortcut! Computer Basics
description: Computer Basics is a game to teach people basic computer skills. You roll a die, put a place holder on a square, and then answer questions from different categories (Hardware, Software, Internet, Navigation, General). If you answer the question correctly you move forward by putting your pawn where the place holder is. If you answer incorrectly it is the next player's turn. The first one to the finish wins.

name: Stifle
description:
In Stifle players move pieces along the grid lines based on adjacency; a piece must move exactly as many spaces as the number of pieces adjacent to it, regardless of owner. A piece may move in any direction but may not move into or over other pieces.

The winner is the last player able to make a move.

For tournament play it is suggested to play four games, alternating first move, with a simple scoring system.

name: Beyond Hex
description:
This is a set of three games based on Hex; they all have the same objective as the parent game (connecting two opposite sides of the board).


Link: in this game after placing a stone a player may move any number of their stones which form a connected line, in of the directions of that line, up to as many spaces as the size of the group. Opposing stones in smaller groups may be pushed, but cannot be pushed off the board.



Tack: in this game a group of two or three stones in an adjacent line are captured if the other player places a stone to bracket the line on both ends. The captured stones are replaced by the capturing player's stones.



Fan: in this game after placement an optional capturing move is made by moving a piece one space so as to end up adjacent to an opposing stone, or to end up one space away from an opposing stone it started adjacent to, or both. Captured stones are replaced.

name: The Fisherman's Knot Tying Game
description:
A game which efforts to educate and improve knot tying skills which are specific to fishing.

The opponents attempt to tie the knot on the card drawn quicker than one another, without errors, using the materials provided in the game. Whoever does so claims the points on the card.

A vast array of multiple use knots for leader tying, snelling hooks, tying smaller leader line onto fly fishing line, along with standard knots for tying baits or hooks onto monofilament or braided line are included on the card.

It's educational, and handy to keep in one's tackle box for that matter, in case of a specific knot for a specific situation is needed. Or, simply in case the fishing stinks...
categories: Action / Dexterity, Card Game, Educational, Real-time

name: Strip-Tease
description:
Strip – Tease The Game is just what you need to add some zing to a night of fun with your friends. As the name suggests, play Strip-Tease an you risk losing your shirt, and a great deal more... Because if another player plays a card you can not follow, you’ll have to remove the piece of clothing shown on the card... The pack also includes surprise cards and jokers that add even more spice to the game. Naturally, you can agree how far you want to go (The ‘Full Monty’ or not...) before you start.

Strip - Tease is a striptease version of UNO. But you'll lose your clothes on the way.

name: Green Alligators: Zoo & Farm Animals
description:
The Giggly-Silly bilingual descriptive word game! No reading required!

Pictures are identified to encourage early readers of both English and Spanish!Green Alligators is that wonderful little "I'm thinking of" kind of card game, but this one has pictures so you can't change your mind part way through the game! Play with your little one while doing other things around the house, just take a look at your card and start giving clues. Your little one will delight in trying to guess what your card is. Then it is the child's turn to give clues.

It is a non- competitive activity for 2 players, or it becomes competive when the "big kids" try to out guess the others!
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Educational, Word Game

name: Troll Treasures
description:
"A band of Elven adventurers have got it into their heads to have a competition, to see who is the most talented Treasure Hunter of the lot. To this end, they decide to infiltrate the nearby troll caves, known for the ample treasures within, and filch the treasures."

"Completely unaware of the competition, the trolls are obviously surprised by the band of elven intruders swanning about in their caves, and understandably they are a little miffed."

"It is a race against time to amass enough treasure and get out before the trolls clobber you into oblivion!"

The object is to be the first player to find five treasures and get out of the troll caves.

Components: game board, a playing piece and stat card for each elf, a playing piece and stat card for each troll, an eight-sided die, 49 wound tokens, 24 arrow tokens, 24 mana tokens, 6 wall pieces, 2 magic door pieces, 3 sorcerer markers, 3 quiver of arrows marker, 3 magic potion markers, and the Search Deck.

name: Mek Leader
description:
"Solo or Multiplayer card game. Each player is a mercenary commander leading a Squad of Meks. Meks = Giant robotic war machines with a human pilot."

"Decks: There are 4 separate common decks (each with its own discard): Mission Deck, Foe Deck, Event Deck, Build Deck. Players keep a Hand of Event cards."

"The Build deck has 4 card types: Pilots, Meks, Weapons, Equipment. Weapons and Equipment are referred to as Attachments. Weapons may be further classified as:
Energy, Ballistic, Hand-to-Hand, or Missile."

A player's Squad can consist of up to a maximum of four Meks and four Pilots. In addition, a Squad cannot have more attachments than the Meks can carry.

Each player starts with 100 Mega credits and a hand of 4 Event cards. Megacredits are earned by completing missions, with the amount depending on the Mission Threat Level.

"Victory: Be the first player to accumulate 500 Megacredits (MC)."

Based, in part, on the Mekatac game setting.
categories: Card Game, Fighting, Print & Play, Science Fiction

name: Tales From the Mountains, The Kit Carson Card Game
description:
"A strategic solo card game in the life & times of the legendary Kit Carson."

The player must maintains a traveling force of mountain men, trappers, prospectors and soldiers exploring the American wilderness. Resources relied on by the expedition and tracked in the game include firearms and ammunition, horses and mules, and food and water.

"Victory: I. Live long enough to own 25 beaver pelts, II. or, Play for high score (fewest turns to victory.) Pelts cached, traded, stolen, or lost do not count towards your victory total."

Required components include two standard decks of playing cards (for the Frontier Expansion Deck and Frontier Adventure Deck), a roll of pennies (or tokens), six nickels, two dimes, a pawn, player sheet, turn sheet, and two six-sided dice (preferably red & white.)

The game also includes rules for a multi-player version.
categories: American West, Card Game, Print & Play

name: Key Konquest!
description:
"Another boring day at the Heroes Guildhall. There's only so much pointless killing, looting and drinking one can do before it becomes boring. What's the solution? Find a reason to kill, loot and debauch! So you have decided to quest for the legendary Keys of Fate which will open the Door of Fate in the Tower of Fate (are we sensing a theme here?), which holds the wondrous Scepter of... you guessed it, FATE! With this Scepter you will be able to rule the kingdom, which will stave off the boredom for a while at least. Unfortunately, some of your "workmates" have had the same idea (talk about coincidence), so it is a race against each other to find the keys and rule your own destiny... or at least kill a few hours in the most violent ways possible."

"Winning: There are six magical keys in the artifact deck. In order to win the game, a player must find at least four out of the six keys and are on the Tower of Fate space at the beginning of the turn. If they achieve this, they have unlocked the power of the tower and win the game.

Components: Hex map of the continent, 2 six-sided dice, 20 card Hero Deck, 28 card Spell Deck, 25 card Artifact Deck, 44 card Dungeon Deck, 50 card Equipment Deck, 15 card Villain Deck, 12 card Quest Deck, 114 card Adventure Deck, 60 Hit tokens, 60 Experience tokens, 60 Gold tokens, 20 Muscle tokens, 20 Whack tokens, 20 Magic tokens, 20 Guts tokens, 20 Sneak tokens, 20 Luck tokens, and a playing piece for each player.
categories: Adventure, Card Game, Fantasy, Fighting, Print & Play

name: Pizza Pie Maker
description:
A pizza making card game for children which uses a print-and-play card deck. The cards name parts and ingredients used to make a pizza.

Points are scored by playing card combos which make a complete pizza. The basic combo, worth three points, consists of a crust card, sauce card, and cheese card. Each additional topping adds one point, and some ingredients give bonus points. In addition, there are three named combinations which score bonus points: Everything Pizza, Meatsa Pizza, and Veggie Pizza.

The game ends when a player goes to draw a card and there are none left. The player with the most points wins.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Print & Play

name: Steam & Iron
description:
"Victorian Steampunk Strategic Combat."

The players control rival forces attempting to gain control of all of the cities on the map. The game includes units and rules for aerial and naval combat forces in addition to ground forces.

The players must control resources in order to be successful. The military forces depend largely on coal. Non-infantry units use coal reserves to move. In addition, metal resources are required to build units. Coal and metal are obtained by controlling mines. The players must also control agricultural areas to provide food for the cities they control.

name: Warp Hammer
description:
"Two player Card Game based on the Games Workshop Warhammer Fantasy Universe."

The players each assemble a custom forty card play deck with a total value of 100 points or less. Each player chooses a different army from which to build a deck. There are sets of cards for the following armies, among others: Dwarf, Wood Elf, Skaven, Ork, Goblin, Lizardman, High Elf, Chaos Dwarf, and Dark Elf. Each card is rated for cost, force, and type. Some cards are also designated as Unique (one per army) or Rare (two per army).

Each play deck must include a Command Group consisting of a Hero, with a Force rating of four or more, and a Wizard. A play deck may have a maximum of twenty Item, Spell, Tactic, Mark, and Virtue cards, and a maximum of ten Wizard and Hero cards.

The are numerous card types in the game, grouped under two main classes: Units and Enhancements. Unit cards include the following types: Hero, Magic, Wizard, Archer, War Machine, Signal, Berserker, Ambush, Scout, Monster, Beast, Cavalry, Infantry, and Spear. Enhancement cards include: Item, Spell, Tactic, Mark, and Virtue.

"Victory: The first player to win 5 hands is the winner."

name: Kings of Hyboria
description:
"Live and fight as a King of Hyboria!"

A strategic scale game of fantasy conquest based on the setting of the Conan novels.

There are eight unit types that make up a player's forces: Army, Elite, Hero, Wizard, Monster, Ships, King, Fortifications. Each unit type is rated for movement, initiative, and attack. Additional units in the game include neutral armies, gold, divinations, storms, curses, and relics.

Gold is gained by capturing and plundering territories. New units may be recruited from captured territories. Random events are generated each turn for Heroes and Wizards by rolling on the Heroic Actions and Wizard Magic Tables. There are also special tables for Heroic Battle Actions and Wizard Battle Spells that add flavor to the game.

name: Kung Fusion
description:
A card game of martial arts combat. The game uses a custom deck containing fifty-six cards, with eight cards for each of seven different types: Punch, Kick, Block, Grab, Move, Zen, and Combo.

The players must roll fighter characters before play. Each fighter has ten hit points and rolls ten times on a series of Maneuver Tables. This results in a list of "moves" the fighter knows and some die roll results can add hit points. Each Maneuver is rated for a cost in cards that must be played to use the move and for damage caused by the move (Attack Maneuvers) or damage negated (Defense Maneuvers).

The object of the game is to reduce your opponent to zero hit points.
categories: Card Game, Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Naval Engagement
description:
"Card game for 2 players. Simplistic WWII era Pacific sea battle simulation."

The game is played with a custom deck of sixty cards. There are fifteen different cards, with four copies of each in the deck. Cards are Units, Attack, Defense, or Special. Unit and Attack cards are combined to make attacks to reduce Fleet Points, while Defense cards can negate attacks.

Each player begins with ten Fleet Points. The object of the game is to reduce your opponent to zero Fleet Points.
categories: Card Game, Nautical, Print & Play, World War II

name: Ready Aim Fire
description:
"Two player Card game depicting Napoleonic era warfare."

The game used three types of cards - Battalion, Commander, and Tactics. The Tactics deck is composed of maneuvers, formations, weapons, incidents, and terrain types. There is a different composition of Battalion and Commander cards given for each of the five nations represented in the game: France, Britain, Austria, Prussia, and Russia. Each player forms a Battalion Deck and selects Commander cards based on the country played.

Cards are played on the table in battlefield positions representing the Left Flank, Left Center, Center, Right Center, and Right Flank positions. The first player to be routed from three of the five forward positions loses. A player may also lose based on morale considerations.
categories: Card Game, Fighting, Napoleonic, Print & Play

name: Magic Knight Rayearth
description:
A card game based on the manga cartoon series of the same name.

The game uses a custom set of sixty cards reflecting heroines, allies, and villains from the series. Heroines include Fuu Hououji, Hikaru Shidou, and Umi Ryuuzaki. For each heroine there are Heroine cards and Team Up cards.

The allies are Clef and Ferio. Villains include Alcione, Ascot, Caldina, Innova, Lafarga, Mokona, Presea, Princess Emeraude, Zagato. There are Plot and Villain cards for each villain.

The playing area is divided into two sides, one for each player, each consisting of a 3x3 card playing grid. Defending cards are played face down on this grid. The object of the game is to have a card reach one of your opponent's third rows at the same time that you have a card in any position on one of the opponent's other columns.
categories: Card Game, Comic Book / Strip, Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Print & Play

name: Harry Potters First Year Adventure
description:
"Board game for 2-4 players. Help Harry recover the Sorcerers Stone."

Each player portrays a wizard who has several attributes, skills, and abilities which must be tracked during the course of the game: House Affiliation, Magic skill, Flying skill, Study skill, Chess skill, House Points, Clues, Wealth, Wand Type, Familiar Type, Chocolate Frogs, All Flavor Beans, and Other Possessions.

The playing board is broken into three segments - a straight track representing Dagon Alley, a loop representing Hogwarts, and a second straight track representing the Dungeon. Players move one space per turn on the straight segments and roll a die for movement on the center loop. Each space has a special table or tables that must be rolled on when a player enters the space.

"Victory: The player with the most house points at the end of the game wins. The game ends when someone defeats Voldemort in the last space of the dungeon."
categories: Children's Game, Fantasy, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based

name: Master & Commander
description:
"A strategic 2-player simulatiion of naval combat in the Napoleanic era."

The game is played on an 8x8 grid. A chess board may be used. Each player has a set of eight Ship tiles. Ships are divided into four classes, numbered 1 to 4. Ship Class determines attack range, hull strength, and number of masts. Each ship is also rated for six skill types, described as follows in the rules: Seamanship, Gunnery, Command Authority/Discipline, Morale/Courage/Health/Stamina, Marksmanship/Snipers/Muskets, and Boarding/Swashbuckling/Hand-to-Hand Combat/Marines/Crew Size.

"Victory: The player with the most captured ships at the end of the game wins. If tied the player who sunk the most ships wins. The game ends when there are no ships left to capture or sink."

name: Quest for the Pirate Chest
description:
Choose to play one of nineteen famous, or infamous, captains - ranging from Sinbad the Sailor to Admiral Horatio to Blackbeard to Jack Sparrow. Each captain has a named ship, crew type, starting port, and special ability that provides an advantage in the game.

The game is played on a circular track divided into twenty-four spaces. Every third space is a port or other special space. All other spaces are open sea.

The object of the game is to find the hidden Pirate Chest and return it to your starting port. To find the Chest you must first gain possession of the Hidden Map and Hidden Key.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Space Swarm
description:
"2-4+ player board & card wargame. Each player controls an Advanced Spacefaring Alien Civilization."

Each Alien Race sends its fleets out to conquer the galaxy. Each Race has six attributes which can change throughout the game: Attack, Defense, Movement, Production, Strategic, and Initiative.

The players share a custom card deck containing two types of cards: Technology and Event. Technology cards give a Race a new ability or an attribute bonus that last for the duration of the game. Event cards represent temporary bonuses and effects.

The game is played on a hex map of space filled with ten "terrain" types: Alien Ruins, Star Cluster, Nebula, Super Nova, Black Hole, Dark Matter, Quasar, Worm Hole, Asteroid Field, and Deep Space. Each type of space has a special effect, except for Deep Space which has no effect.

There are two ways to win the game. Either control all the Star Cluster spaces in play or occupy the most spaces when the deck runs out.

name: Mobile Infantry
description:
"Individual Soldier Combat in the world of Ogre/G.E.V."

"Mobile Infantry Soldiers fight as cohesive, Battle suit wearing squads. They combine firepower and area defense measures making them the most effective combat formation in mankinds' long history of warfare. The six-man squad is the norm: 1 Paladin-suit for command and control, 1 Commando-suit for targeting enemy forces and spoofing the enemy’s sensors, and 4 Marauder-suits are the basis of the squad’s firepower."

name: Tron, The Card Game
description:
"Card game for 2 players. The action takes place in the world of Virtual World of Tron."

One player represents Tron and the other plays as the Master Control Program or MCP. Each player uses a separate custom deck of cards.

The Tron deck is made up of six types of cards: Programs (Characters), Skill (used to defeat Games and Security), Escape (used to go Rogue), Activation (used to become Activated), Transport (used to reach the Mesa), and Sub-Routines (various effects).

The MCP deck has four types of cards: Control (required to win the game), Games (used to destroy Programs on the Game Grid), Security (used to destroy Programs off the Game Grid), and Sub-Routines (various effects).

The MCP player wins when all ten Control cards have been downloaded (put into play). Tron wins by Derezzing (destroying) the MCP in Program Delete Phase.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction

name: Rockets & Rayguns Strategic
description:
A game of full scale war on the planet Mongo. Set in the Flash Gordon universe.

One side controls the forces of Human Hero Flash and his allies, Hawkman Chieftain Voltan and Forest Chieftain Baron. The other player controls the forces of Evil Emperor Ming. Each unit is rated for the following statistics: type, move, initiative, attack, defense, cost, and area of recruitment.

The game is played on a map depicting a major continent on the planet Mongo. There are five regions in the continent. At the start of the game, the Central and Southern regions are under Ming's control while the North, East, and West regions are controlled by the forces of Flash. The regions are further divided into territories, some of which represent Major Cities and some of which are impassable mountains.

The Flash player wins if Ming is killed. Ming wins by killing all of the Rebel Leaders.
categories: Comic Book / Strip, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Rockets & Rayguns Operational
description:
"Rebel troops are attacking Ming’s Palace. Who will carry the day?"

The Rebel forces under the leadership of "Human Hero Flash" are closing in on the palace of the Evil Emperor Ming, ruler of the planet Mongo.
