A set of forty-eight playing cards are marked with the results of an at bat, such as "single", "hit by batted ball", "wild pitch", "double play", "stolen base", "out on steal", "out on foul", etc.

The components consist of a cardboard box, instructions, wooden board, score card, and (per the instructions) forty-eight cards. In addition, this particular example of the game is marked on the box cover as the "pocket edition" compliments of Longman & Martinez Paint Makers, New York City.

name: The Victor
description: A simple children's "spin and move" race game where the players seek to move their pieces from their start spaces to the end space, moving up the opposite sides of the board. The components include a game board and rules (both printed inside the bottom half of the box), a spinner, and a set of discs for each player.
mechanics: Race, Roll / Spin and Move, Track Movement

name: Life Savers Game
description:
A game for two, four, or six players. The object of the game is for the players to use their life boats to rescue sailors from a wrecked ship and bring them to the beach. Avoid the hazardous "reef of rocks"!

The components consist of one "dial" (spinner), six differently colored counters (representing life boats), six differently colored discs (representing sailors.)

name: Humpty Dumpty Sat On A Wall
description:
A vintage, early twentieth century dexterity game. Each player has a small Humpty Dumpty figure which hangs from a suspended string. The players compete to maneuver their Humpty Dumpty onto a wall. Points are scored based on the facing and positioning of the Humpty Dumpty figure. For example, 20 points are scored for seating Humpty facing the player with both legs hanging over the side of the wall; but if only one leg is over the wall, the player scores 15 points. The winner is the first player to reach a predetermined number of points. An alternate race game is included where the players race to be the first to get their Humpty properly seated on the wall and detached from the string.

The components include the box, an instruction sheet, three Humpty Dumpty figures with string, three walls, and three clips used to attach the lines of string to the game table. The box and instructions state "British Manufacture. Made in England." No publisher is specified.

name: SanQi
description:
Players take turns to either add one of three colors of stone to the board or change the color of an existing stone to match its neighbors.

One player's goal is to create either a circle or a triangle of six stones of the same color. The other's is to create either a straight line or a triangle of six stones of the same color.

name: Boolean Rithmomachia
description:
This game was inspired by the medieval game Rithmomachy. But whereas in traditional Rithmomachy the pieces are labeled with natural numbers and captures are based on arithmetic progressions and geometric ratios, in Boolean Rithmomachy the pieces have binary nybbles 0000, 0001, ..., 1111 and captures are based on the logical operations AND, OR, XOR, NOT.

For good measure, the board has also been updated from two dimensions to three.

name: The Dance Game
description: From the instructions: The object of the game is to dance your way around the game board to receive a standing ovation. The first two sides of the board relate to dance class, side three is the dress rehearsal experience and the fourth side actually has you on the stage performing.

name: The Outdoorsman Game
description: Background from the instructions: The OUTDOORSMAN GAME was created by avid sportsman in a sparsely populated, wildlife rich area of Eastern Oregon. When he discovered that many of his junior high math students shared his enthusiasm for outdoor activities, he came up with a way to make statistics and probability more interesting to them. Drawing on his own experiences afield and information from fish and game departments, he developed a game that would involve fishing and hunting while teaching certain mathematical concepts. When people kept insisting that the game was too much fun to confine to the classroom, the idea was born of developing an activity that would challenge and entertain sportsmen when time, weather, or resources prohibited an excursion afield. The OUTDOORSMAN GAME is the result of those efforts. In the game, the species of fish, fowl, and big game, and the seasons and areas in which they are pursued, closely follow the actual events as they occur in Eastern Oregon. We trust you will find the OUTDOORSMAN GAME to an enjoyable and entertaining activity.
categories: Animals, Dice, Economic, Educational, Math, Sports

name: The Masquerade Game
description:
"This new and pleasing game is composed of thirty-two cards, each representing a character in masquerade attire, and the whole forging such a collection as may be seen at the carnivals yearly held in Rome or Venice."

The winner is the first player to score thirty-two points. Publication date is approximate.

name: The Reward of Merit
description:
"The Reward of Merit; a new, moral, and entertaining game"

A race game in the spirit of Game of Goose. The game board has 37 illustrated spaces, each of which is marked with a rhyming moral. Examples include: "A Gardener; Plant what is good, root out what's bad; Then You'll become a charming Lad", "a Dunce; Return great Dunce, with marks of Shame; Unto the Place from whence you came", and "a Puppy; You're pert to all, yet nothing know; Therefore pay one, sweet-scented Beau."

At least one version of this game came in the form of a jigsaw puzzle, with the lithograph mounted on wooden pieces about 0.2 inches thick. The board was made up of 51 puzzle pieces, most of them representing a single space on the board, but with some pieces just filling in numbers on corners and others making up the centerpiece with the rules and final space. The completed puzzle board measured 18.25 inches by 15 inches.

name: The Game of Kings
description: An antique card game consisting of a deck of 38 cards, a sixteen page instruction booklet, and a red slipcase bearing a picture of King William II. The game is described as comprising "a brief history of the English monarchs, from the Conquest to the present time, with an engraved figure of each." The instruction booklet summarizes each monarch's reign.

name: History of Philadelphia
description: This antique card game contains sixty cards "with labels of five different shapes and four different colors." Each card gives information about a place in Philadelphia or person related to Philadelphia. Game play involved matching cards of the same place or person. This is a revised version of the game, following the first edition published in 1831.

name: Running the Blockade
description:
"Two or more players provide themselves with Wooden Pins. The object in view is to run between the lines of the blockading squadron and to reach Wilmington, N.C."

The game that appears to have been produced in the Civil War period. The game board is a maze that leads to a number of illustrated spaces on the board. Some of the spaces depict Civil War ships. These spaces require a player arriving on that space to pay stakes. Other spaces represent hazards such as a Shark, Torpedo, or Reef, which require the payment of a fine. The first player to reach Wilmington collects all the stakes and fines paid during the game.

name: Commandments and Beatitudes
description: An educational trivia card game from the twenties or thirties. Each card has two questions on it referencing a specific Commandment or Beatitude. Each card is also marked with a value in credits. There are four different play and study variations given. Depending on the game variation selected, the object is to either acquire the most cards or cards worth the most total credits.

name: Toy Parade
description:
"Toy Parade is a colorful, exciting game for pre-school kiddies, who need have no knowledge of numbers and counting; and an interesting game for older kiddies too."

A vintage "spin and move" children's game for 2, 3 or 4 young children. The spinner depicts toys that are also shown on the squares of the game board. After spinning the spinner, a player moves to the next square showing the toy that the spinner selected. There are also colored squares on the board which have special effects, such as causing backwards movement or the loss of a turn.

The winner is the first player to get all the way through the Toy Parade.

name: Cleaver the Pit
description:
Cleaver the Pit, Version 1.0 is a Miniatures Game sold as a limited run of saddle stitched 12 page book.

Players create characters that fight in an arena. The characters are represented by a series of stats from which to extrapolate combat. The stats are generated randomly. Combat is conducted through a series of dice rolls and counter rolls to determine if one character hits another. Armor, weapons and skills can effect the outcome of each dice roll. Once a hit is scored, damage is determined. Once a character has exhausted his life points, the character is dead. The player creates a character. The character enters the arena. The character fights until dead.

name: Osiron
description:
Osiron is a game inspired by the graphic, the "Flower of Life". Each turn, players swap colored triangles in order to fill in a full circle on the board. The Designer, David Huffman, creates earthenware Osiron sets.

The gameboard is comprised of seven perfectly interlocked circles. Through this interlocking, twenty four concave triangle playing spaces emerge. Each of the seven interlocked circles contains six of these playing spaces.
There are twenty four playing pieces that correspond to the gameboard’s twenty four playing spaces. Twelve playing pieces are light colored for one player and twelve being dark for the other.

One player chooses the players’ colors, the other chooses who will move first. Players alternate taking turns exchanging playing pieces on the gameboard with one
another until the object of the game is achieved.

With six of their twelve playing pieces, the first player to fully occupy one of the gameboard’s seven circles before their opponent does is the winner.

name: Historical Loto
description:
"A Highly Amusing and Instructive Round Game."

Historical Loto is a Bingo type game where the Loto cards have historical dates marked on them. Each date lists an associated event and reigning monarch. A set of numbered Tickets matching the dates and numbers on the cards are drawn from a bag by a Teller. A player holding a Loto card with a square having a matching date calls it out.

Each player receives a pool of 36 counters at the start of the game. Six counters are paid into a pool for each Loto card played. A player must pay two more counters to the pool any time an improper claim is made on a Ticket. The first player to fill up six squares on any one card claims the pool.

Jaques also published a version of the game with dates from French history.

name: Panda Pile
description: A stacking game consisting of twelve wooden pieces. Players take turns adding a piece to the growing column: slanted tubes of bamboo, leaves that stick out to the side, and one worried panda that needs to be placed safely on top of them all at the end. Although a simple stacking game intended for children, the unusual shapes allow anyone to press the limits of balance.

name: Bingo Dice
description:
This is a dice game in the Onsworld Jackpot Dice series (the other's being Black Jack, Crossword, Liar Poker and Lucky Fortune Dice).

Players are dealt a card which shows six 2-digit numbers. They put counters into a pot which they are vying for. The only digits which appear on the cards are 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 and 9. On their turn, the player rolls two six-sided dice and with the two numbers rolled, forms a 2-digit number. For this purpose, the 6 can also be used as a nine. So, rolling a 1 and a 6, the player can form 16, 19, 61 or 91. All players check their card and if they have the 2-digit number, they can cover it with a counter. The player who first covers all the six numbers on his card wins the pot.

name: Yonkersopoly
description: Another game from the MONOPOLY family, this time featuring the streets and locations from YONKERS NY. The game was a limited edition.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: L'Entre Deux Verres
description:
Step into the world of French wines: Constitute your cellar while learning interesting facts about vintages, grapes, regions etc.
Show your knowledge and collect more wine-cards than your opponents.

name: The Stock Market
description:
This is a dice-driven stock speculation game with an unusual scoring mechanism. There are three decks of cards: red Bear cards, blue Bull cards and white Speculation cards. All three piles are placed face down on the board, along with a pile of stock certificates, each bearing the name of a different major company and a $1,000 face value. Each player puts $100 to start in the Broker space.

On their turn, players roll 2D6. On a 3-6, they draw a Bear card. On a 7-11, they draw a Bull card. Either variety may offer an opportunity to take a Speculation card. On a 2 or 12, they collect all cash and stock in the Broker space, and each player then pays another $100 into the space.

While some cards call for cash or stock to be paid to or from the Broker or other players, most provide a market up or down number. This does not affect the value of any stock, however. Each player has a scorecard with a metal clip that starts at zero and can move from -20 to +20. Each time the player's market hits +13 on the way up and +20, he draws a free stock certificate. He loses the same at -13 and -20. The winner of the game is the first to accumulate $7,500 in cash and stock value.

This Depression-era game has a clear upward bias: players draw Bear cards only 39% of the time, with the remaining rolls being positive; and 60% of the Speculation cards are positive. As the slogan on the game's rules puts it: "Big Winners, Big Losses, but Losses are Quickly Regained".

—user summary

name: Wall Street: The Game of Speculation
description:
From the instructions:

To those who enjoy a stirring game of chance, which may be controlled, to some extent, by smart judgment, this game of Wall Street will prove a fascinating diversion . . . Just as in the "Street" itself the time to buy and sell is fraught with uncertainty, so in this game it is puzzling to determine whether to take a trick with a 1-point boost to score and be "sure" -- or hold your best card for a 2- or 3-point "Win" -- perhaps to be forced, as often happens, to take a loss of 2 or 3 points because you held a "good card" too long.

Parts =

Cards in Blue, Red, Green and Violet
12 Counting Cards with "Win" or "Lose" and one "Mystery" card.
Cardboard chips in yellow, green, blue and red.

name: Bulls 'N' Bears
description:
Object of game - to accumulate money and stock.

Parts:
Money in $10, $50, $100, $500, $1,000, $5,000 and $10,000
Two wooden rectangle dice with Bulls and Bears on it
Stock Certificates for Autos, Bonds, Funds, Oils & Steels
"Chance" cards
Playing Cards

name: The Game of Bank
description:
Object of Game is to roll marbles into slots. The slots represent $1, $3, $5, $15 and $25.

Playing board is wood and highly lithographed showing a birds-eye view of a metropolitan street with cars, people, a department store, playhouse, drug store, hotel, wharf with ship and the center of it all the "Metropolitan Savings Bank".

name: Associate!
description:
Associate! is a racy team game suitable for parties and similar environments. It's simple to learn and great fun to play. Here's how it works:

Divide into teams and race against the clock to find the missing link between words - the more your team guesses in thirty seconds, the further round the board you go. It's a non-stop beat-the-clock battle of wits!

One member of your team reads out some of the pre-written clues, it might sound something like this: "Control", "Missile" and "Liner". Your team shouts out guesses as to what the missing word is that links those words. In this case it's "Cruise" which is linked by the phrases "cruise control", "cruise missile" and "cruise liner". You're racing against the clock to solve as many different links as you can before time runs out and your turn ends.
categories: Party Game, Print & Play, Word Game

name: Mumble Jumble
description:
Everyone's looking at sheet with five anagrams from a certain category and racing to be the first to solve three of them. Here's an example of what one of the sheets included in the game:

Category: "Things you might find in a fast food restaurant"

These are the five anagrams of things within that category:

(1) A GERM BRUSH

(2) PALE PEPSI

(3) SINK PAN

(4) WARTS

(5) CHEF ‘n FERRIS

Could you be the first person to solve three of these anagrams ?

Pick up points by solving the anagrams first or simply by letting somebody else make a mistake - the winner is the person with the most points at the end of the game.

And the answers are: (1) Hamburgers (2) Apples Pies (3) Napkins (4) Straw (5) French Fries

http://www.amherstlodge.com/dirtycheats/fbg/downloads/games/...
categories: Party Game, Print & Play, Word Game

name: Bid
description: Everybody plays at once. One person reads out a category name and ten items within that category (this is all provided in the file). Some of the items genuinely fall within the category whilst others don't. You have to decide how many of the correct answers you think you can correctly identify and then bid. But here's the dilemma: If you bid too high, you risk getting it wrong but if you bid too low, you might well be outbid. You've got to combine your knowledge of trivia with a little guesswork and a lot of guts to win !

name: Porky Pies
description:
With something like 500 questions included, Porky Pies is a game that comes with enough material to keep you going for quite some time although you only need to print off a few pages each time you play.

How the game works: You get given an old or unusual phrase (many originate from the UK in the 16th to 19th century) and have to decide which of the three explanations provided is correct. Everybody plays at once and the person who picks the most correct explanations during the course of the game is the winner.

http://www.amherstlodge.com/dirtycheats/fbg/downloads/games/...
categories: Party Game, Print & Play, Word Game

name: The Question Box Game
description: The Frederick H. Beech company put out this game The Question Box in 1939. The game was a trivia type game where you conducted and answered what the game called a Radio Question Bee. Questions about trivia from Radio Shows of that time were featured. You drew from a large number of card questions with different degrees of difficulty and asked another game player who tried to answer the question correctly. He/she then scored points based on getting those questions correct.

name: Frontier Fort Rescue Game
description: Frontier Fort Rescue Game is a simple roll and move game similar to many others of the times. There is a compass included in the game which helped determine in which direction you get to move.

name: Jingle Dingle's Weather Game
description: The Lowell Toy Manufacturing Corporation put out this game Jingle Dingel's Weather Game in 1953. The game is based on the weather puppet Jingle Dingel who was on American Television in the early 1950's. The game itself revolved around adding weather fronts to a map. (more info is forthcoming soon)

name: 18IA: Building Iowa's Railroads
description:
18IA:Building Iowa's Railroads is a single-state 18xx game set in Iowa, designed to play out in 4 hours or fewer.

Corporations:
Chicago & North Western Railway
Chicago Great Western Railway
Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul, and Pacific Railroad
Chicago, Rock Island, and Pacific Railroad
Chicago, Burlington, and Quincy Railroad
Fort Dodge, Des Moines and Southern Railroad

Private Companies:
Mississippi and Missouri Railroad Company
Farmers' Co-operative Contracts
Iowa State University
University of Iowa
Cedar Rapids & Missouri Railroad
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Network and Route Building, Stock Holding, Tile Placement

name: Mediums
description:
Based on different esoteric skills as Tarot, Runes Astral Cards, etc.

With it you will emulate the great mediums, discovering your past, present and and future.

Learn to decipher the signs and the way of the love, the fortune and the luck.

Move around the universe represented in the board, and in a trip across the four seasons (summer, fall, winter and spring) gather the cards that guard the message for you. The cards set will be adapting the game in order to assimilate an esoteric session.

Will you be the medium? Will you be the consultant? The destiny will decide it and only at the end of the game you will discover it.

You don't need esoteric knowledges to use it.

Enter to the fantastic world of the occultism and discover your past, present and future.

Content:

- 1 board
- 4 player pieces
- 1 symbolic dice
- numeric dice
- 48 environment cards
- 48 spring cards
- 48 summer cards
- 48 fall cards
- 48 winter cards
- 1 instructions

name: Cats and Dogs
description:
Players move celluloid cats and dogs around the board by spinning a spinner. The first one to the finish is the winner.

Parts:
2 celluloid Cats
2 celluloid Dogs
1 spinner with a cat on it
1 game board

name: Futballkártya "2000"
description: In this soccer card game the cards represent which player controls the ball and black arrows show where he can pass or shoot. The same cards also can be used for defense as red arrows show which players can tackle the ball controlling player.

name: Pirate Treasure
description:
Board has a turning disk under it to place the treasure chest in 1 of 16 holes on board, each covered with a gold coin.

Players are pirates looking to be the first to collect 25 coins. Movement is by rolling two six sided dice. Rolling doubles gives you the option to add another of your playing pieces to the board.

When you reach a hole on the board, collect the coin and check to see what's under it. The treasure chest is worth 10 coins, you can also find nothing, or be captured by another player and sent to their hideout. To be released takes one coin and a roll of doubles, or two coins without the roll.

First player with 25 coin wins.

name: Rouletta
description: This is a game similar to Roulette, but uses more than one ball, and one of those is worth 'double' of wherever it lands. It's pure luck of course, but despite its simplicity, becomes quite addictive and is a lot of fun to play!

name: Try it Again
description: Played by two and up to six people, each using a numbered disc to be found in the upper left hand corner. Any player can start this game. Each advances his disc the number of squares indicated on the spinner. Should the disc be advanced to a square with a double number (red and black), he/she is forced to move to the square indicated by the red number. If the disc falls into a square marked TRY IT AGAIN, player is allowed another spin. The player who is the first to reach the red square marked 92 or 93 is the winner.

name: La Riga
description:
From instructions:

"The Magnetic Game of Toggle Pins"

A game of skill and action wherein the player tries to pull his own color Toggle Pins into his "fenced-in" area by skillful manipulation of a magnet.

The bottom portion of the box is used as the playing platform and is first assembled into a raised platform by attaching 4 plastic legs. Each player sits at one side of the platform next to his or her "GOAL". Each player selects 20 Toggle Pins of the same color has their "GOAL" and places them in the center of the board. Each player then takes a magnet.

Magnets are rubbed under the playing surface to break up the pile of pins and guide them into their home goal. Each time a player draws a wrong colored pin into their own Goal, they must pick up that pin and one of their own and return both to the center enclosure.

name: Neptune Ruler of the Sea
description: Neptune uses 1-2 decks of regular playing cards. You also need a trident (search for a 3-tined fork) and the crown included. The Starting player plays some cards from his hand which must be all the same kind, but any number of them. The other players then in turn lay down cards which try to beat his. The winner takes all the cards. The Crown and the Trident are gained in special ways and have special powers for use during the game.

name: Open Numbers Game
description: The Open Numbers Game is a collection of several games based around the idea of moving numbered pieces on a board. Two different sets of numbered pieces are provided, the "large game" (numbered 0 up to 99, for use with a 10x10 board) and the "small game" (numbered 0 up to 31 twice over, for use with an 8x8 board).

name: Open Word Game
description:
The Open Word Game consists of several different games based around the idea of moving lettered pieces on an 8x8 board to form rules.

There are 64 pieces in the set: two copies of each consonant and four of each vowel (including Y). (Since the Russian alphabet has 33 letters, in the original Russian version there are two of each letter except Ъ and Ь of which there are one each.) In addition each piece has a numeric score depending on the rarity of its letter, and a suit (red, yellow, green or blue).

name: La pulce matta
description:
Fast and funny game for kids.
Chose one tokens from the table, and collect the similar object. Don't pick up the tokens "PULCE"! You may discard all the tokens you collect!

From the collection MINIGAME of Editrice Giochi.

name: Let's Furnish A House
description:
1947 board game by Parker Brothers.

Object of Game: The object of the game is to become the first person to buy a house, furnish it and secure $1,000 additional for a savings account.

Game Parts:

A circular board with a spinning dial
2 dice
Bank containing road cash counters
4 receipt books and receipts
4 moving pieces
4 house cards
4 sets of house furnishings

name: Market Maneuvers
description:
Stock trading game.

Game has a wooden game board with stocks circling in a square on the top. Stocks are NYCRR, UPRR, SPRR, Grand Union, A and P, Woolworth, Pure, Shell, Socony, American Sugar, American Wool, American Tobacco, National Steel, Bethlehem Steel, US Steel, Sears Roebuck, Montgomery Ward, Chrysler, Ford, Packard, US Rubber, Firestone, Goodyear, Western Union, Postal, Swift, Armour, Wilson, Aviation and Curtis Wright.

The board has four corners which are: Market News, Today's Market, Market Quotations, Market at a Glance.

There is a spinner in the middle of the board and the board has holes the fit the wooden peg playing pieces.

name: On the Board
description:
Game Parts:

On the Board Chance Cards include options to buy stocks, lucky breaks, John Law, obstacles, Santa Claus, happy days.

Stock certificates for Bell, Dupont, Goldfield Mining, Hecla Mining, Montana Mining, Atlantic Oil, Standard Oil, Shell Oil, Erie Canal, White Star, General Motors, Chrysler, Studebaker, China Clipper, Yellow Cab, Greyhound.

Money in dollar amounts of $500, $1,000, $5,000, $10,000, $50,000 and $100,000 and a loans log.

Object of Game: At the end of play, which may be for a specified period of time, each player cashes in his Stock and Bond Certificates at their then listed current values, and the player who has made the greatest gain over the original amount of money with which play was begun will be declared the winner.

To parallel actual Stock activity 6% has been designed with fluctuations of Stock as one of its prime features.

Game Parts:
Game board with squares denoted stocks, bonds and other stock exchange terms
Bull, Bear and Revenue cards
Pair of dice
Current Value stock board
Stock and Bond Certificates
Paper money in $100, $1,000, $5,000 and $10,000
Plastic 6$ symbols
Margin and sell short chips

name: Game of Success
description:
Object of Game: To see which of 4 errand boys can meet with the greatest success.

Players spin the spinner and move around the board landing on squares that direct them to success or failure. The winner is the first person to reach the "44" square.

Parts - 4 wooden pegs and one spinner. Instructions on back of box top. Brightly colored and lithographed board.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move
publishers: (Unknown), J. Ottmann Lithography Company, McLoughlin Brothers

name: Decisions
description: Roll-and-move stock trading game. The rules suggest that players should be cutthroat.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Roll / Spin and Move, Stock Holding

name: Dial & Learn
description:
Dial & Learn is an educational trivia game which uses a mechanical dialer to verify answers to common educational trivia questions. Categories include "The World of Science", "Lands and Seas", etc.

Recommended Ages 7 - 12

Contents:
Magic Dialer
Scorecards
Special marking pencil
Question cards
Rule Book

name: The Game of Africa
description:
"New, Fascinating, Instructive. The Game of Africa, or Contest of the Search Expeditions."

"Three games in one. Any number can play. Amuses. Educates without study. Contains Expeditions, Playing-Board, Map, 64 Cards, comprising authentic biographies, history, geography. Sold by booksellers, etc., or sent, post paid, on receipt of price, $1.00."

name: Googlepoly
description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

In this version of Monopoly the goal is to organize the world
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Singing, Trading

name: Cube Anagrams
description: An antique word game played using five wooden cubes (dice) marked with letters. The other components include two wooden dice cups and a rules sheet. The game came in a colorful 7.5 x 4 x 2 inch box marked: "Fun for old and young. Exciting new letter game." And the instructions tout: "The most popular of all Letter Games."

name: Jack and Jill Target Game
description: This is a simple shoot and hit the target type of game from Cadaco Ellis that was produced in 1948.

name: Which Is It?
description:
"The New Game of Which Is It? Bird, Beast, or Fish? Speak Quick or Pay."

An antique card game consisting of a deck of 52 cards colorfully depicting a variety of birds, fish, and other animals. Each card is marked with a number (5, 10, 15, or 20, and one 50.) The 50 point card is "Mr. Crowley", described in the rules as the famous Chimpanzee who for many years delighted children at the New Your City Zoo in Central Park.

There are two game variations. The game play revolves around playing a card when its name as read from a story in the rulebook. Points are scored according to the numbers on the cards.

Card manifest: 18 bird cards, 16 fish cards, 18 cards with other animals. The game also included a box and a rules booklet.

name: Little Red Bushy Tail
description:
This game is essentially a roll-and-move race game for 2 to 4 players, but instead of using dice, a series of tiles with movement numbers are drawn from a face-down pile. The board illustrates events in the story of Little Red Bushy Tail, a popular children;s story of the time.

Contents:

Board
Draw Tiles
4 player pieces
Instruction Booklet

name: Game of Radio
description:
"As Interesting as Radio Itself. Rules For The Three Great New Cards Games Broadcasting, Radio, Radio Junior (For Children.) Easy to Learn. A Riot of Clean, Fascinating Fun. The Best Family Game in Years. For Adults, For Children, For Parties. Everybody Likes Them."

A custom card game consisting of a sleeved card box, a 16 page rules booklet, and 48 cards. The cards are marked with the call signs and frequencies of vintage radio stations for twelve cities: WDAF in Kansas City, WCCO in St Paul-Minneapolis, KDKA in East Pittsburgh, WEAF in New York, WFAA in Dallas, WGY in Schnectady, KFI in Los Angeles, KFOA in Seattle, WOO in Philadelphia, KYW in Davenport, Iowa, and KYW in Chicago. Three games are included; Broadcasting (which is an Old Maid variant), RADIO (which is a rummy variant), and Radio Junior (also a rummy variant).

name: Cyber Tactics
description: Cyber Tactics is a Trading Card Game for 2 or more players. Each player is known as a Navigator and they possess decks called the Hard Drive. Navigators draw Data Cards from their Hard Drives and Downloads them into the computerized world of Virtua to engage in combat. The objective is to destroy your opponent's Memory Core before he destroys your own.
categories: Card Game, Collectible Components, Fantasy, Fighting, Science Fiction

name: Squelch!
description:
Squelch! is two games in one. They are:

Rain forest adventure board game: Roll the dice and move your counter around the game board, following directions to move yourself and others forward and back.

Treasure hunt: Hunt for specific animals and plants on the board and answer questions about them.

name: Tools Of The Trade
description:
The Tools of the Trade game introduces children to 32 different occupations and the tools they use as the kids sort pictures into the correct trays.

Includes 4 category boards, 56 colorful tiles, and a red plastic tray.

Smethport Model No. 8301

Designed to be enjoyed by 1 or 2 players Ages 4 - 8.

name: Zwort's Nature Report Animal Adventure
description:
Players explore the arctic, desert, forest, jungle, ocean, and safari habitats with Zwork, a curious reporter from outer space. As children play the game they improve their vocabulary, thinking skills, and listening skills.

Includes a colorful board, tokens, cards, and question booklet.

(c)1991 Thinking Well

ISBN 1-55999-203-4

name: Trusts and Busts or Frenzied Finance
description:
This game is a vivid representation of stock speculation as carried on by the general public through the brokers' offices of Wall Street. The uncertainties of the game and the anxiety of the players to be on the right side of the "Market," together with the possible occurrence of a "Boom" or a "Slump" give to the game the power to call up every emotion that sways the real speculator in stocks.

Parts:

86 cards with the following values -
60 cards representing "value" cards (6 sets of 10 cards with numbers on them)
13 "Trust" cards
16 small "Market" cards the represent the different occurrences

name: Game of Buy and Sell
description:
Game of store or buying merchandise with with money. The object of the game is to buy as much merchandise as you can before all the cards are gone.

Money is 1 cent up to $20.

Merchandise includes flour, mackerel, corn meal, umbrella, envelopes, pineapple, beef, tea, stove, pickles, sugar, skates, apple, whistle, cheese, chickens, gum, eggs, coal, Lion coffee, hat, honey, tennis rackets and other items.

name: Wild Animals of North America
description: This game sponsored by the National Wildlife Federation in Washington was edited by famed naturalist Roger Tory Peterson. The box says that it was illustrated by America's foremost Nature Artists. It is a trivia type game with questions and information about many wild animals including; Grizzlie Bears, Raccoons, Otters, Sheep, Buffalo and even Chipmunks.

name: Elementaire
description:
"An instructive game teaching the rudiments of music."

The components include a box, rules folder, musical note cards, and 96 numbered squares (blue and pink).

name: Game of By Mail, Express, or Accommodation Train; or Interstate Commerce
description:
Each players has a locomotive which journeys to destinations across the United States seeking to buy the most valuable commodities. The game ends when ten trips have been completed by one of the players. The winner is the player who obtained commodities having the highest total value.

The game components include the box, a game board depicting an "accurate, up-to-date" map of the United States and its chief railway lines, a set of four wooden discs representing locomotives, two "indicators" (spinners) marked 1-12, and a set of cards bearing the names of states, cities, commodities and their prices.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: The News Boy Game
description:
An antique 'spin and move' style children's racetrack game where the players race to be the first newspaper boy to travel 79 spaces to reach the Large Store end space. Special spaces along the way can cause a player's pawn to advance or go backwards.

The game components include the box, a spinner, and four wooden pawns. The illustrated game board is printed on the inside of the box bottom. The concise rules (five sentences long) are printed around the outside edge of the game board.
publishers: Parker Brothers, R. Bliss Manufacturing Company

name: Bag of Fun
description: This is a vintage game from 1932. The object of the game is for players to pull a number out of a bag and then match the number with numbers in a game book which lists different actions that must then be accomplished in order to score points. (some of the tasks that might be chosen are to "Sing a song and then have the rest of the players join in with the chorus" or "Have your eyes blindfolded and kiss the one you are with.")

name: Lou Gehrig Plaball
description:
The game comes with an 18" X 18" square baseball field. There is a metal spot located at the batters box which will expel your ball bearing or marble ball into the playing field. The ball will land in some position which will result in the determination of what happens on the particular at bat. (thanks to berniethepicker at Ebay)

The wording at the batter's box on the board is:
"Lou Gehrig"
Official
by arrangement with Christy Walsh
PLABALL

name: Fame and Fortune Game
description:
"Fame & Fortune: Win Fame while you gather a Fortune!" In this Whitman game, players use a spinner to move along a convoluted track that includes gender-specific career tracks [for girls, nurse, actress, stewardess, secretary, housewife and teacher; for boys: star athlete, jet pilot, cowboy, fireman, explorer, and scientist) and a "luck track" to collect "lucky gold coins." Whomever reaches the end of the track ["the pot of gold"] with the most gold wins [yet another life-lesson for kids].

Though the game is undated, based on the logo style, it would appear the game dates to the early 1960s.

name: Crayola "Draw What?"
description: Players form two teams. A member of the active team receives a noun, a verb and an adjective (eg BANANA LAUGHING BIG) and using crayons, has one minute to draw a scene incorporating all three words. Acting (without words or sound effects) can be used if the verb is too difficult to draw. If the other members of the team can guess all three words, they receive a point. The first team to five points wins.

name: Bigtopolis
description:
"Circus owners compete for the best cities and touring acts in their quest to conquer the big top." Inspired by Monopoly.

Components: game board, rules folder, play tips sheet, play money, city license cards, railroad operator cards, fortune cards, touring act cards, ticket price calculator, pawns, and dice.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Our National Ball Game
description:
An antique baseball game played on a wooden board which depicts a baseball field. The rules and a die rolling chart are also printed on the board. The board is approximately 20x20 inches. The other components include a pair of dice and a set of markers used to represent base runners.

The game is played using a chart which determines the results of each pitch by rolling two six-sided dice. The chart lists each pair of numbers that could be thrown and gives a result for each pairing. The results include a base hit, a "two base hit", "three base hit", getting on base by error, getting on base by balls, one strike, foul out, out at first, fly out, double play, triple play, and home run.

name: UFO Red Alert
description:
"Commander Straker has just about the toughest job on this planet - defending Earth for our safety. Now here's your chance to match your skill against the menacing UFO'S. The game can be played by two to seven people. One person takes the role of Straker and defends the Earth by shooting down the UFO's while the other one to six players divide the UFO's between them and try to land on Earth."

The game included a 29 x 19 inch tri-fold game board, an instruction sheet, six UFO pieces, five earth defense ships, and a die. The game came in a black soft plastic folder rather than a box.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction

name: When My Ship Comes In
description: "A simple game for young people." This antique game comes in a small box with a colorful picture of a sailing ship on the cover. Components consist of a sheet of rules and four sets of different colored paper slips (referred to as "cards" in the rules.) The players play a set of three types of cards (Wishes, Whence Expected, and When Expected) and the dealer plays a Consequences card on each set.

name: Shirtsleeves to Shirtsleeves
description:
Shirtsleeves to Shirtsleeves is an educational boardgame developed by GenSpring Family Offices, a wealth management firm. Its purpose is to encourage intergenerational discussions of wealth management within families. The game name comes from the saying, "From shirtsleeves to shirtsleeves in three generations," meaning that a family fortune earned in one generation can easily be lost by another.

This game was featured on the news radio program "Marketplace" and a version of the story can be found online here: http://marketplace.publicradio.org/display/web/2008/06/25/sh...

A summary of gameplay, excerpted from the "Marketplace" report:

"Every player starts with $25 million in play money and from there the game is kind of a cross between Monopoly and the game Life. You roll the die and move your piece along a snaky row of squares in the shape of a dollar sign...every turn, you have to draw a card...Everyone starts in generation one and after a few turns...You enter generation two and then three and there's a separate deck of cards for each."

According to the report, GenSpring is coming out with an advanced version of Shirtsleeves to Shirtsleeves that will let players control the outcome of the game.

name: Funda
description:
From the box "FUNDA™, a game of chance in which you travel into the exciting history of Black America, earning your way through the University of Black Studies. The first player to earn an Associate Degree, Bachelor’s Degree, Master’s Degree, and finally a Doctorate Degree, wins the game."

Players answer trivia questions as they travel around the board in a roll-and-move mechanism. As players succeed at each "educational" level, they graduate to the next inner board track.

Contents:
Instruction Sheet
Playing Board
Diplomas
Question and answer sheet set
Master Answer Sheet
Four sets of Bonus Cards
Four playing pieces
Two Dice
College Credit Score Sheet Pad

name: Centennial Presidential Game
description:
From the publisher's catalog: "These are large and showy games new in plan and style. Played with an indicator... 56 cards giving the Presidents and Vice Presidents of the U.S. with other useful data... Color numbers and pairs the basis of the game... Essentially very different from anything on our list... An instructive novelty."

This antique card game was produced to coincide with the United States' Centennial. In came in a colorfully illustrated 4.5 x 7.5 inch box. The components included a set of 56 cards (each marked with the name of a President or Vice President and historical data), a spinner, and four numbered sheets (two red and two blue with numbers marked in a 3 x 4 grid.)

The unusual spinner, referred to as an "indicator", was marked with the numbers 1 to 6 and had two spinning arrows. The publisher was apparently particularly proud of this component, as indicated by the information printed on the back of it:

"McLoughlin Bros.' Indicator. A Complete and Unobjectionable Substitute for, and Improvement Upon Dice, Teetotums, &c. It's various uses. 1st--As a substitute for Dice, spin the Arrows, and play with the numbers at the points of both Arrows. 2d--As a substitute for Teetotums, use the number at the point of the black Arrow only. NOTE--Should an Arrow stop on a line, both Arrows should be spun again."

name: Christian's Journey
description: A game inspired by John Bunyan's book Pilgrim's Progress. The object of the game is to be the first player to reach Celestial City. To do so a player must correctly answer questions about the Bible.

name: A Frog He Would A Wooing Go
description:
A children's game based on the poem of the same name. "The Object of the game is to see which player who represents the Froggie can avoid being gobbled up by Lily White Duck." The components consist of 47 cards and a box (with the rules on the inside of the lid.)

Each player, in turn, randomly draws a card from the hand of an adjacent player. If the card makes a pair with another card in the player's hand, the pair is played to the center of the table. This continues until all of the pairs have been played. The player left holding the Lily White card is considered to have been gobbled up.

name: Pilgrim's Progress
description: A "spin and move" board game based on John Bunyan's book Pilgrim's Progress. The board is marked with events from the book, and certain squares have special results. The components include a mounted game board, a spinner, a rulebook, and six colored pawns. The spinner is unusual in that it has three separate concentric circles for results.

name: The Peanut Race
description: An antique board game for two, three or four players. The game consisted of a 10x10 inch box and 24 wooden pawns (divided equally into four different colors.) The instructions are printed inside the box cover. The bottom half of the box serves as the game board. The playing area is a circle divided into four pie-shaped quadrants, each of which has six holes into which the pawns may be inserted.
publishers: C. W. Marsh, I. P. C. Universal Corp., Invicta Games

name: Ting-A-Ling Chimes
description:
An antique dexterity game from Parker Brothers. The playing board contained inside the box bottom consisted of nine inverted metal bells of varying sizes marked with scores from 25 to 100. Using five small metal balls and a spring-arm catapult, the object was to score the most point by flinging the balls into the higher scoring bells.

The colorful box cover shows three dogs playing the game. The rules are printed inside the lid. The game also included a small advertising insert for other Parker Brothers games.

name: Ya-Lo, The Football Card Game
description:
"A Thrill on Every Play. New Thrills in Every Game. Easy to Play. Realistic Football for Real Fans."

This vintage football card game was originally released in the mid-twenties. A 1940 edition, marked on the box cover as the "New Collegiate Edition", was used to prepare the following description. The limited information located regarding the twenties edition indicates that it may have been self-published, but otherwise it is believed to be similar to the later edition.

The 1940 New Collegiate Edition consists of a box, a 16 3/4 x 9 3/4 inch football-field board (a box bottom insert), 55 Offensive cards, 55 Defensive cards, individual card boxes for these two sets of cards, 29 Time-Out cards, a metal football marker, a cardboard "10-Yard Marker" and the rules. Note that there are are tracks on the board for keeping track of the four quarters and four downs, so there may have been additional markers to place on these tracks.

The board depicts a 100-yard football field, marked in one yard increments. The 10-Yard marker is used to determine when enough yardage has been gained for a first down. The metal ball is used to mark the field position of the ball. Movement of the ball up and down the field is determined by the Offensive and Defensive cards.

The 1925 set does not contain Time-Out cards, or mention of time-outs in the rules. The separate board does not have any tracks for quarters or downs. In addition to the Rules, it includes four pages of "Help for the Novice", a summary of the current NCAA football rules.
publishers: American Game Co., Capitol Game Company

name: The Passage
description:
The Passage: The Ultimate Bible Game

(c)2003 NewVentions, Inc.

This is an educational religion game. Players move out from the "Cradle of Creation" and travel through the world as they witness to various countries by using "Passage" cards.

Includes a colorful board, spinner, rules, reference guide, tokens, "Spiritual Gift" dice, cards, timers, missionaries, "Offering" money, plastic stands, and storage insert.

Ages 8 and up.

name: Cape Cod Treasure
description:
AT THE BEACH, IN THE CAR,OR AT HOME...

...this game is for anyone who loves Cape Cod, but especially for those who are looking for a fun way to explore the Cape and experience it as they never have before. As you meander around the map, you'll be asked questions, like any trivia game, but the answers lead to wonderful little-known beaches and natural areas, local legends and language, working farms and festivals, historic sites, golf courses, colorful establishments and more, all of which are waiting to be enjoyed every day in towns all over the Cape and islands if you know where to look.

name: Always in Motion
description:
From the box:
"Vehicles that travel through air, in the sea and on land... Match the mode of transportation to its medium! Match the cards to the boards in a lotto game of photographs!"

Contents:
4 game boards (park, street, air, water).
24 game cards (6 for each board representing a different vehicle with a picture and name).

This game is for children ages 2 to 5. The rules list two ways to play, a "Lotto" game and a "Memory" game.

In the "Lotto" game each player receives a board. Players take turns drawing a card and comparing the vehicle on the card to the vehicles on the player's board. Matching cards are placed on the corresponding board space. The winner is the first player to cover all six spaces on their board.

The "Memory game is played by first choosing a dealer. The dealer gives each player a board. The players study their board for one minute then turn them face down. The dealer shows the top card to all the players. If a player thinks it matches a vehicle on their board they say "Mine" and place the card next to their board. This continues until all the cards have been shown. The players turn their boards face up. For each matching card a player earns 1 point. For each non-matching card a player looses 2 points. The winner is the player with the most points.

name: The Raleigh Cruising Game
description: British promotional cycling game published by the Raleigh Cycle Company just after their 50 year existence.

name: Le Jeu du Tour
description:
French cycling game promoting the Tour the France published in 1937.

This game was published inside L'Auto's 1937 Tour de France programme.

Gameplay is based on the Game of Goose where geese are replaced by riders and fields have been altered to fit the racing theme. It is a roll and move game using a spiral track. Hitting certain fields help players progress faster while others slow them down. The goal is to be the first player to reach Paris.

name: Juego de Salón Vuelta Ciclista a España
description:
Spanish Cycling game promoting the Vuelta, published in the 1950's.

The board is a big two-folded wooden panel with rivets where metal riders are inserted. Riders are moved according to the result of a spinner, it also features three-dimensional mountains!

name: Tarka Cycle Trail
description: British cycling game created in Exeter, Devon. The player who follows the most efficient trail wins.

name: Cheerleader action-figure board game
description: The game begins by shuffling the instructional cards. Each player selects a colored game piece and corresponding matching colored pose-able cheerleader action-figure. The players can combine to form teams instead of individual play. The players are awarded trophy cards upon successfully performing dexterity actions routines with the action figures. Once the deck is exhausted, a winner is declared.

name: Destination Fortune
description:
Together with your fellow players, you are on an extraordinary trip that will take you around the world, into the most prestigious casinos, onto racetracks and into arenas and stadiums where you will challenge each other in all the major sports and game events. These challenges are resolved by rolling the five dice that come with the game.

This was the last game published by Ludodélire.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Méandres
description:
Contents: a board with a spiral divided into four sections, eighteen pawns numbered from 1 to 18 (magnetic set).
The pawns are drawn at random and set face down on the first circles of the spiral. Then the players capture pawns by turning them face up in increasing order. When errors are made pawns must be moved away from the centre into the other areas of the spiral. The winner is he who captured the most pawns.

name: Mr. T Giant Card Game
description: The Mr. T Giant Card Game is a mix & match style cared game in which players are required to complete 'poses' of Mr.T. There are four distinct poses in the 40 card set. The cards are divided into 3 separate categories: a head-shot of Mr. T, a torso of MR.T and a waist/leg card. The player that collects or completes the most poses when the all the cards are dealt, wins the game.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Hannah Montana Fact or Fancy
description:
This game -- for 2 players to a whole slumber party full -- will prove if you know everything about the Hannah Montana show. by testing your knowledge and by letting you do fun activities and fact/fancy games.

Game includes:
58 Trivia Cards
20 Fact/Fantasy Cards
20 Activity Cards
4 "Pop Star" Pendants for voting
and comes in a mini guitar case

Ages 7 and up
Made by Cardinal under license by Disney.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Bluffing, Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game, Trivia

name: War of Liberty:  An Introductory Wargame Rules for the American War of Independence
description:
War of Liberty is a very short and simple game for simulating miniatures battles in the American Revolutionary War. The rules themselves are only four pages long, yet detail the necessary unit structure, turn sequence, movement, fire combat, melee, and morale procedures.

Infantry units are battalions and made up of 3-6 stands (typically 2-3 stands for American and British, and 4-6 for French), cavalry is 1-4 stands (typically 2), and artillery batteries are represented by a single stand. The game is designed to be played with either 15mm or 25mm figures.

Four additional inserts are included:
1) A game summary
2) American and French army organizations
3) British, Tory, and Hessian army organizations
4) List of American Revolutionary battles in chronological order.
categories: Age of Reason, American Revolutionary War, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Robotman & Friends
description: Players guide Robotman and three friends along four differently colored paths. Cards show which color (character) may move. This is a very simple color-matching game for young children.

name: Don't get Nabbed!
description:
This game was produced by a commercial ad agency as its contribution to the Singapore National Council Against Drug Abuse, as part of the Partnership for a Drug Free Singapore programme. Essentially applying the mechanics of the game, Snap, the game uses 60 cards (4 each of 15 designs) with illustrations of grotesque and pitiful creatures that have succumbed to the evils of drug abuse. Each card comes with a little rhyme detailing the sad fate of its character - for example:

MAK THE RABBIT
"I wish you peace" said Mak the rabbit.
His friends gave him drugs,
Now he can't kick the habit.

The cards are dealt out evenly to each player and players take turns to reveal a card from their stack. When two cards of the same design are seen, the first player to shout "NABBED!" gets to keep both stacks of upturned cards adding all of them face down to the bottom of his/her stack.

The name of the agency providing the concept and design of the game was WORK - no individual designer was indentified. The illustrations are credited to Theseus Chan and the rhymes to Jim Aitchison.

The Partnership for a Drug Free Singapore programme began earlier in 2002 and featured the characters in a series of cartoons with anti-drug rhymes. The card game was published in 2004 and was distributed in schools.

name: Kinder der Bibel
description: Theme of this card game are stories about children in the Bible. There are 3 playing variants with 2 different sets of cards. 15 of the cards have a picture with a story from "Everyday Bible".

name: Le Zakhia
description:
Contents: a 13×13 board with 21 special pictured squares, 100 letters (with 3 jokers pictured as cedars), 4 holders for letters, a bag.

Players score points with 10 letters words, but they do not have to cross words. Names are allowed, and when playing upon one of the 21 special squares, the word played must refer to the domain symbolized by the picture on the square.

name: Sails
description:
Sails - A historical miniatures game of combat between Sailing vessels of the 16th, 17th and 18th Centuries.

These rules were designed to be a medium degree of difficulty. More detail rules for fighting and moving sailing ships have been written. However, they are not
playable or enjoyable due to the need to constantly stop play in order to check the rules or a matrix. These rules were written for 1/600 scale vessels. There are also lines of 1/450, 1/900 and 1/1200 vessels on the market which can use these rules as written.

SAILS was designed to reflect ship to ship combat with squadron size the largest size battle. Regardless of the scale, as written each model on the table represents one real ship.

Play tested using many different size boards. The game can be tailored to the size of the table available. SAILS was played tested using 1 to 6 ships per player, games lasting 20 minutes to three hours, table sizes ranging from 3'x3' for 2 players to a 4'x8' for 4 players.

These rules were written using the KISS method: Keep It Short and Simple. If a situation develops that is not covered in the rules: use common sense!

Contains:
Rules
Several ship cards for those lacking
models
Event cards for some random spice
categories: American Revolutionary War, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Print & Play, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: Zodiac
description:
Content : 40 white and yellow pawns, a board with two parts : a fixed glass where pawns are set, and downside an octagonal board showing ten curves (each joining 4 dots) that you can turn by an angle of 45°.

Players at their turn put a pawn above the glass and turn the octagonal board by 45°. First player to set four of his pawns upon the same curve wins.
mechanics: Network and Route Building, Pattern Building

name: Tanks Alot
description:
Tactical combat simplified for miniature battles.

Tanks Alot is a very brief rules set the contains guidelines for creating tank units and then battling it out.
publishers: Tri Tac Games LLC (Tri Tac Talents)

name: Pterroductyl
description: Pterraductyl, #2 in the Duck Trilogy, adds "tactical airborne combat" to the world of Polywumpus. In this installment giant mutant ducks have taken to the sky. Modern technology is of no use, so adventurous pilots have taken to the air in antiques to defend mankind.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Humor, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hexagon Grid, Paper-and-Pencil, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Player Powers, Variable Set-up
publishers: Tri Tac Games LLC (Tri Tac Talents)

name: Frenzied Finance
description:
Object of game is to accumulate the greatest amount of cash and stock value. Game time is predetermined by the players either a set time or when the bank is unable to make a purchase of stock offered it. Game may be played by 4 to 10 players. One player becomes the Banker and issues money and buys and sells stock for the bank. Another player becomes the Caller who spins the price wheel, marks the stocks up or down, keeps a record of the stock prices on the price sheet, and calls the stocks.

Game parts:
One Price Board with Quick Reference Table for Computing Transactions of Over 100 shares
9 "+" up markers
1 "c" corner markers
Game Money in the amount of $2 million
1500 shares of stock in 14 companies represented
50 Price Sheets

Stock Certificates are: Oils, Cons.; Lumber Co.; Coppers, Cons.; Drugs, Inc.; Airways, Inc.; Telephone Co.; Railroad, Cons.;Steel, Cons.; Insurance Co.; Foods, Inc.; Motors, Cons.; Pictures, Inc.; Utilities, Inc.; and Equipments, Inc.

name: Schnitzeljagd
description:
Through field and forest is the Schnitzel Hunt. Up to 10 hunters pursue the goal. This isn't so simple as there are many false trails, detours, and adventures cause many delays. The game takes luck and skill to win.

---

Kreuz und quer durch Feld und Wald führt eine Schnizeljagd. Bis zur 10 jäger versuchen, rasch zum Ziel zu kommen. Dies ist gar nicht so einfach, den viele Fehlspuren, Umwegen, und allerei Abenteuer verursachen immer wieder Auftenhalte. Es gehört neben dem notwendigen Glück auch eine Geschichtlichskeit dazu, als Sieger ans Ziel zu kommen.

name: Monopolo Esperantujo
description: A print-and-play translation of Monopoly into Esperanto. Adds four new cards to each of Chance and Community Chest. The money has different sizes for different denominations and is denominated in 'steloj,' or stars. The property names are changed as well; for example, Pennsylvania Avenue becomes 'Ŝoseo de Zamenhof.'

name: Fingerball
description: A game of fast-action finger flickin' fun! The game materials include a wooden playing field with a goal in each corner, 2 steel marble pucks and 8 rubber "shoes". Each player or team takes 4 matching color "shoes" and places them on the middle and index finger of each hand. The puck is then "kicked" with the finger shoes. Players defend their goals by staying outside of their goal lines. Fouls can be committed and free shots are awarded. The winner is the first player or team to score 5 goals.

name: Port Singapore
description:
In Port Singapore you are paid by the load. So your team of grunts better work hard for you. But making money should not be too hard, this is the busiest port in the world.

The Port Singapore board is divided into bays. Next to the board lie the ships that need to be loaded. Each ship has a hold that needs to line up with one of your bays before you can get your grunts to load the goods (barrels). Along the back of the board is a track on which 4 action cubes sit. On your turn you pick up one of the cubes, do the action, then slide all the cubes forward putting your cube at the end. Cubes usually have a cost involved in choosing them, but they get cheaper the farther they move down from the top of the track. The actions on the faces vary from cube to cube, you may only take the action shown on the top face of the cube when you choose it.

The cubes contain actions like:

Heave ho. Pull a ship along the wharf or send full ships off and get new ships to load. Good for annoying players who may be about to load or bringing a ship to your warehouse bay.
Union meeting. Shuffle you grunts around the wharf and roll one of the action cubes for a random result.
Do business. This gets goods in your ware house to load or lets you hire grunts to do your loading.
Load a ship. Move one load per grunt into a ship's hold opposite to your warehouses.
Take a bribe. Helps you get things done.
The Payoff. Pay one of your opponent's grunts to simply go home for the day.
Brawl. Cause a ruckus in the bay next to one of your bays, good for disrupting opponents.


The game ends when the barrels in the supply run low (depending on the number of players). The player who has made the most money wins.

name: fun-et-iks
description:
"The play on words game"

From the instructions:
Solve the who, what or where questions and race to the center square. At the center square, solve a scrambled question to win the game.

name: Oil Tycoon
description:
From the back of the box:

During the years since Col. E. A. Drake brought in his first oil well in 1859, the Discovery of Oil has made more men wealthy than any other single endeavor. Oil, now as then, is just waiting to be discovered. Yet, only a few men - a special breed of men - seem to solve its Mystery and find it. What do these men possess that sets them apart from the average person?

They are almost always bold and intelligent... they know Land Values and how to collect and analyze clues. Their Business Prowess enables them to expand their oil fortune by Investing in other enterprises. They not only own vast empires, but control them with their own decisions. Indeed! Few people qualify for the extraordinary title of "Oil Tycoon"

CHALLENGE
This game offers you an opportunity to see if you have what it takes to join those elite ranks! You will receive an inheritance to start your own empire. The oil is out there somewhere just waiting. The rest is up to you. With skill and a little luck, you might become the next "Oil Tycoon."

name: Jeux de mots
description:
Contents: a 8×12 board, 2 holders, 280 letter squares, 20 blank squares, 20 symbol squares, a roulette.

There is no less that seven different games submitted there.
“Three letters and more” is an adaptation of a TV game: three letters are set on the board, then each player tries to add a new letter to build a longer word.
“Crossworlds” looks like scrabble, but unused letters are kept in holders and the person who stocks 16 letters or more there loses the game.
In “Scrambled Words” each player tries to guess the secret word of his opponent. Anagrams increase scores.

name: Power Checkers
description:
Power Checkers is an expansion of the traditional game of Checkers. Game play is similar to the original game with the same movement, jumping, and kinging rules. The major difference comes in the expanded board, which allows for more maneuverability and the ability for special "Power" moves.

Players start with their pieces in special territories outside of the regular 8x8 board. To get Power Checker status, the player must get his or her piece all the way through the opponent's home territory to special Power spaces. Once there, the piece may move in any direction, transport to special Power Space Courts outside of the normal play area, and return to their home area.

The game is playable with 2-4 single players or team play.

name: Snapz
description:
(From back of box)

SNAPZ is a fast action family game for 2 to 4 players or teams. It requires the electronic SNAPZ umpire and the category and alphabet cards provided. The random interaction of these cards produce thousands of possible answers to the simple questions posed, (for example: give a name beginning with the letter for the category shown). But watch out!, at any time the game can increase in speed with the MIME TIME cards - momentarily turning the game into a fast and furious round of charades. The aim is to get rid of all of your cards by placing them back on the SNAPS unit or to an opposing player.

name: Marée noire
description:
Contents : a wooden board with 62 holes, 62 wooden pawns with one side coloured blue, the other side black, 126 letters, two 8 pieces puzzles representing a whale and a sinking tanker .
The winner is he who has completed first his puzzle. The pawns are played with the same rules that Othello, and when a player surrounds at least 3 pawns, he gets the right to set one piece of his puzzle.

name: Barbaria
description:
Barbaria represents the history of the west (Europe, N. Africa, Near East) from the fall of the Roman Empire through the Mongol invasion, 406-1250 AD.

Players control several nations (Britannia-like) with differing objectives.

There are two versions using the same map, one using picture-dice combat, 6 turns, 90 minutes, one more detailed and using battle cards (no dice), 11 turns, up to 180 minutes.

In both cases the point scoring is much simplified from Britannia--one 8.5 by 11 inch sheet shows all scoring and appearance, no "nation cards" needed.

name: Zahlen Ritter: Spiel um Burgen und Punkte
description:
Zahlen Ritter is a two player game published in Switzerland by Max Giezendanner.
The game contains
24 tiles of each color (blue and red)
2 wooden pawns
2 wooden towers (score markers)
1 board
(the rules are printed on the box)

The players place alternately their tiles face down on the board and start at the score of 50 points. The aim of the game is to grab all tiles of your opponent. You get points when grabbing these and loose points when getting your own tiles. Each tile is indicating the number of points you win or loose.

Each player also has 4 additional tiles with a treasure chest, lady, dragon, and a ghost - worth respectively 20, 10, 10, or 10 points, when getting your opponents' tiles, or losing the same amount when drawing your own tiles.
